Rationale: The speech acknowledges the risks of upside inflation and emphasizes the importance of maintaining higher rates to contain inflation pressures. However, it leans towards a wait-and-see approach regarding further hikes, suggesting a probability of holding the rate at the next meeting.
description: Dinner speech by Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Money Marketeers of New York University, New York City, 21 September 2023.

author: Philip R Lane
title: The banking channel of monetary policy tightening in the euro area
Key quote: The banking channel is likely to further strengthen in the coming months.
Rationale: Philip R Lane's speech is primarily analytical, focusing on the transmission mechanisms of monetary policy through the banking sector rather than advocating for a specific policy change. While discussing the impact of recent monetary policy tightening, he acknowledges both its effects and limitations, suggesting that the ECB will continue to monitor and assess these channels. This suggests a neutral stance, likely resulting in a 'Hold' decision in the next interest rate meeting.
description: Remarks by Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Panel Discussion on Banking Solvency and Monetary Policy, Summer Institute 2023 Macro, Money and Financial Frictions Workshop, Cambridge, Massachussets, 12 July 2023.

author: Philip R Lane
title: Monetary policy tightening and the financing of firms
Key quote: If the baseline scenario underlying the March ECB's staff macroeconomic projections persists, it will be appropriate to raise rates further.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the necessity of further rate hikes to ensure inflation returns to target, reflecting a strong focus on tightening monetary policy.
description: Keynote address by Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Enterprise Ireland Summit 2023, Dublin, 19 April 2023.

author: Philip R Lane
title: Underlying inflation
Key quote: The current information on underlying inflation pressures suggests that it will be appropriate to raise rates further beyond our March meeting.
Rationale: The focus on underlying inflation dynamics and the anticipation of further rate hikes indicate a somewhat hawkish stance, suggesting a preference for tightening monetary policy to address above-target inflation pressures.
description: Lecture by Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at Trinity College Dublin, Dublin, 6 March 2023.

author: Philip R Lane
title: The euro area hiking cycle - an interim assessment
Key quote: Furthermore, we have also signalled that we intend to raise the deposit facility rate by another 50 basis points at our March meeting.
Rationale: The speech outlines that the ECB has been actively raising rates and indicates a clear intention to continue doing so in the near future, reflecting a somewhat hawkish stance focused on tackling inflation.
description: Dow Lecture by Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the National Institute of Economic and Social Research, London, 16 February 2023.

author: Philip R Lane
title: The transmission of monetary policy
Key quote: In our September monetary policy meeting, the ECB's Governing Council communicated that, over the next several meetings, we intend to raise our key policy rates towards levels that will ensure the timely return of inflation to our two per cent medium-term target.
Rationale: The speech clearly states the intention to raise policy rates over multiple meetings to combat inflation, indicating a hawkish stance towards tightening monetary policy.
description: Speech by Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the 7th SUERF - CGEG|Columbia|SIPA - EIB - Société Générale Conference on "EU and US Perspectives: New Directions for Economic Policy", New York, 11 October 2022.

author: Philip R Lane
title: Monetary policy and the money market
Key quote: The Governing Council last week decided to raise the three key ECB interest rates by 75 basis points. This major step frontloads the transition from the prevailing highly accommodative level of policy rates towards levels that will ensure the timely return of inflation to our two per cent medium-term target.
Rationale: The speech articulates a policy stance focused on further interest rate increases due to persistently high inflation. The decisive tone and the significant rate hike indicate a commitment to tightening monetary policy.
description: Opening remarks by Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Meeting of the Money Market Contact Group, Frankfurt am Main, 14 September 2022.

author: Philip R Lane
title: Monetary policy in the euro area - the next phase
Key quote: Our over-riding goal is to make sure that monetary policy will deliver the timely return of inflation to our medium-term two per cent target.
Rationale: The speech discusses the transition to a new phase of monetary policy focused on normalisation through rate hikes to address high inflation. The emphasis on raising rates to return inflation to the target level suggests a somewhat hawkish stance.
description: Remarks by Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, for the high-level panel "High Inflation and Other Challenges for Monetary Policy" at the Annual Meeting 2022 of the Central Bank Research Association (CEBRA), Barcelona, 29 August 2022.

author: Philip R Lane
title: The euro area outlook - some analytical considerations
Key quote: Our over-riding commitment is that the Governing Council will take whatever action is needed to fulfil the ECB's mandate to pursue price stability and to contribute to safeguarding financial stability.
Rationale: While Philip R. Lane acknowledges various factors affecting inflation dynamics, including high energy prices and supply chain bottlenecks, he emphasizes the need for a data-dependent approach in monetary policy. This suggests a neutral stance as holding rates allows the ECB to respond to changing economic conditions effectively.
description: Speech by Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at Bruegel, Brussels, 5 May 2022.

author: Philip R Lane
title: Monetary policy during the pandemic - the role of the PEPP
Key quote: More than ever, it is important to maintain optionality in the conduct of monetary policy.
Rationale: The speech by Philip R. Lane emphasizes the accommodative stance of the ECB, highlighting the use of extensive asset purchase programs during the pandemic. The overall tone suggests a cautious approach to normalization, focusing on data dependency and being prepared to adjust measures as necessary. This hints at holding rates steady given the uncertain economic backdrop and the focus on maintaining supportive conditions.
description: Speech by Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the International Macroeconomics Chair Banque de France – Paris School of Economics, Paris, 31 March 2022.

author: Philip R Lane
title: Inflation in the short term and in the medium term
Key quote: Given our assessment that the medium-term inflation trajectory remains below our two per cent target, it would be counterproductive to tighten monetary policy at the current juncture.
Rationale: Philip R Lane emphasizes the temporary nature of the current high inflation and the need for continued monetary accommodation to meet medium-term inflation target of two percent. His speech indicates a preference for stability in monetary policy, suggesting a hold on rates rather than a cut or raise.
description: Welcome address by Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the ECB Conference on Money Markets, 8 November 2021.

author: Philip R Lane
title: The monetary policy toolbox and the effective lower bound
Key quote: If the economy is close to the effective lower bound, it is vitally important to adopt especially forceful or persistent monetary policy action to avoid negative deviations from the inflation target becoming entrenched.
Rationale: Lane emphasizes the importance of accommodative monetary policy, especially given the effective lower bound. He discusses the need for 'forceful or persistent monetary policy action' to avoid negative inflation shocks, which aligns with a dovish stance. The focus is on ensuring inflation targets are met over the medium-term rather than immediate rate changes, suggesting a 'Hold' vote.
description: Welcome address by Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the ECB Conference on Monetary Policy "bridging science and practice", Frankfurt am Main, 11 October 2021.

author: Philip R Lane
title: Stabilising the economic outlook
Key quote: To counter these risk factors, it is essential that the ECB acts as a stabilising force and boost confidence by committing to the preservation of favourable financing conditions.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the need for the ECB to preserve favorable financing conditions and suggests that low interest rates and accommodative monetary policy are necessary to counterbalance economic uncertainties. This dovish stance indicates a likelihood of maintaining current rates to support the economy.
description: Remarks by Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at "The Outlook for the Economy and Finance" workshop (fully digital), organised by The European House – Ambrosetti, Frankfurt am Main, 27 March 2021.

author: Philip R Lane
title: The compass of monetary policy - favourable financing conditions
Key quote: Ensuring favourable financing conditions is central to restoring inflation momentum and guiding the formation of inflation expectations through the commitment of the central bank to counter the negative pandemic shock to the inflation path and secure convergence towards the inflation aim over the medium term.
Rationale: Philip R. Lane's speech emphasizes the importance of maintaining favourable financing conditions, highlighting significant policy interventions like the PEPP and TLTRO, and the need for extended monetary accommodation to counter the negative impact of the pandemic on inflation. Such argumentation aligns with a dovish stance, suggesting low probability of proposing rate changes, particularly hikes, in the near term.
description: Speech by Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at Comissão do Mercado de Valores Mobiliários, 25 February 2021.

author: Philip R Lane
title: Monetary policy in a pandemic - ensuring favourable financing conditions
Key quote: Ensuring favourable financing conditions to support the economic recovery and counteract the negative impact of the pandemic on the projected inflation path is essential for several reasons.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the need for supportive monetary policy to counteract the pandemic's negative impacts on inflation and encourage economic recovery, suggesting that the central bank will not tighten its policy and instead opt for holding rates to maintain favorable financing conditions.
description: Speech by Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Economics Department and IM-TCD, Trinity College, Dublin, 26 November 2020.

author: Philip R Lane
title: The ECB's monetary policy in the pandemic - meeting the challenge
Key quote: The Governing Council continues to stand ready to adjust all of its instruments, as appropriate, to ensure that inflation moves towards its aim in a sustained manner, in line with its commitment to symmetry.
Rationale: The speech discusses the need for accommodative policies given the economic slack and deflationary pressures, suggesting no immediate intention to tighten monetary policy. However, the ECB is already operating with negative rates, which limits further rate cuts. Therefore, the speaker is likely to vote for a 'Hold' on rates rather than further easing.
description: Speech by Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the (virtual) 62nd NABE Annual Meeting "Global Reset? Economics, Business, and Policy in the Pandemic", 6 October 2020.

author: Philip R Lane
title: The pandemic emergency - the three challenges for the ECB
Key quote: The pandemic crisis represents a significant negative shock to the inflation outlook, since the disinflationary pressures arising from greater economic slack are likely to outweigh any inflationary forces stemming from negative sectoral supply shocks.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the extraordinary measures taken by the ECB to counteract the disinflationary pressures, indicating a dovish stance as the ECB aims to maintain an accommodative monetary stance to support the economy and ensure recovery. The probability of holding rates is high given the need for continued support in light of the pandemic's impact.
description: Speech by Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at "Navigating the Decade Ahead: Implications for Monetary Policy", an economic policy symposium sponsored by the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, Jackson Hole, Wyoming, 27 August 2020.

author: Philip R Lane
title: The European Central Bank's monetary policy response to the pandemic - liquidity, stabilisation and supporting the recovery
Key quote: The ECB's monetary policy response to the pandemic is not only highly effective in supporting financial conditions, but is also providing crucial support to the real economy and has averted the most severe tail risks.
Rationale: Philip R. Lane's speech indicates a strong dovish stance, highlighting the ECB's extensive measures to maintain accommodative monetary policy and support the economy amid the COVID-19 crisis. The emphasis is on maintaining current measures rather than signaling any immediate rate changes, hence predicting a 'Hold' for the next meeting.
description: Speech by Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Financial Center Breakfast Webinar, organised by Frankfurt Main Finance, 24 June 2020.

author: Philip R Lane
title: International inflation co-movements
Key quote: Under these conditions, there may be prolonged deviations of inflation outcomes away from the inflation aim, with central banks closing inflation gaps over a longer time horizon.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the challenges of reaching inflation targets in a low interest rate environment and implies limited policy action to respond to shocks, indicating a somewhat dovish stance with a likelihood to hold rates.
description: Speech by Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Inflation: Drivers and Dynamics 2020 Online Conference, Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland/European Central Bank, 22 May 2020.

author: Philip R Lane
title: Pandemic central banking - the monetary stance, market stabilisation and liquidity
Key quote: We are fully prepared to further adjust our instruments if warranted. This includes increasing the size of the PEPP and adjusting its composition, by as much as necessary and for as long as needed.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the ECB's commitment to maintaining an accommodative stance and indicates a readiness to expand measures such as the PEPP in response to ongoing economic challenges. This dovish tone suggests a focus on supporting the economy rather than tightening monetary policy, making a rate cut unnecessary in the immediate term.
description: Remarks by Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Institute for Monetary and Financial Stability Policy Webinar, 19 May 2020.

author: Philip R Lane
title: Monetary policy, low interest rates and low inflation
Key quote: Ongoing monetary accommodation is still required in order to ensure the robust convergence of price inflation to our aim.
Rationale: The speech focuses on the need for continued monetary accommodation due to low equilibrium real rates and ongoing low inflation, indicating a bias towards maintaining or slightly easing policy. However, due to the description of current measures successfully supporting wage inflation, it suggests the ECB might hold rates rather than make immediate changes.
description: Dinner remarks by Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Centre for European Reform, London, 27 February 2020.

author: Philip R Lane
title: The monetary policy toolbox - evidence from the euro area
Key quote: Our forward guidance on interest rates, which makes the evolution of our policy rates contingent on the robust convergence of inflation to our aim, captures our monetary reaction function in the current environment of low inflation and low interest rates.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the use of unconventional and accommodative policy measures to stimulate the economy, highlighting the ongoing low inflation environment and the ECB's preparedness to sustain or modify policies to reach inflation targets, which indicates a dovish stance.
description: Keynote speech by Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the 2020 US Monetary Policy Forum, New York City, 21 February 2020.

author: Philip R Lane
title: Interview with RTÉ (Ireland's National Television and Radio Broadcaster)
Key quote: We don't think tighter monetary policy from us is part of the answer.
Rationale: Philip R Lane defends the ECB's current dovish policy stance, emphasizing the need for continuation to support economic growth and inflation targets, while indicating skepticism towards tightening monetary policy.
description: Interview with Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, and RTÉ (Ireland's National Television and Radio Broadcaster), conducted by Mr Robert Shortt on 13 February 2020 and broadcast (in part) on 13 February 2020.

author: Philip R Lane
title: Low inflation - macroeconomic risks and the monetary policy stance
Key quote: In my remarks today, I therefore plan to focus on the conduct of monetary policy when inflation is below target and explain why the ECB is maintaining an accommodative monetary policy stance.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the risks of low inflation and the need for an accommodative stance, reflecting a dovish approach. The ECB is unlikely to cut rates further, leading to a 'Hold' prediction, given the existing negative policy rate and the need to prevent deflationary risks.
description: Keynote speech by Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the financial markets workshop of the Economic Council (Finanzmarktklausur des Wirtschaftsrats der CDU), Berlin, 11 February 2020.

author: Philip R Lane
title: Interview in the Financial Times
Key quote: Our monetary policy remains effective and we do respond to shocks, but it does take longer when you can only do relatively small policy moves.
Rationale: Lane discusses the complexities and current limitations of the ECB's monetary policy, emphasizing patience in achieving the inflation target. His comments indicate no immediate shift towards tightening or easing, suggesting a hold on the policy rate.
description: Interview with Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in the Financial Times, conducted by Mr Martin Arnold on 27 January 2020 and published on 2 February 2020.

author: Philip R Lane
title: Households and the transmission of monetary policy
Key quote: Overall, the spending of the lower-income cohort and the cohort of homeowners with only limited financial assets is much more strongly stimulated by monetary policy easing.
Rationale: Philip R Lane highlights the positive impact of monetary policy easing on consumption, especially for lower-income households. However, he mentions the complexity and limited overall effect of monetary policy on inequality, suggesting a more cautious approach. Given the current policy rate at -0.5% and the nuanced discussion, a 'Hold' stance is likely, with a dovish tilt reflecting the focus on easing's benefits.
description: Speech by Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Central Bank of Ireland/ECB Conference on Household Finance and Consumption, Dublin, 16 December 2019.

author: Philip R Lane
title: Determinants of the real interest rate
Key quote: If the prevailing inflation rate falls short of the inflation aim and the equilibrium real rate is low - or even negative - this may call for a substantially negative policy rate in order to stabilise medium-term inflation.
Rationale: Philip R. Lane discusses the factors contributing to a low natural rate of interest and the implications of this for monetary policy, suggesting a need for potentially negative rates to stabilize inflation. While this context is dovish, the probability of holding rates is slightly higher given the current policy rate is already quite low.
description: Remarks by Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the National Treasury Management Agency, Dublin, 28 November 2019.

author: Philip R Lane
title: The yield curve and monetary policy
Key quote: Our non-standard measures of negative interest rate policy and asset purchases brought down the overall level of the yield curve to a region that is, by definition, unreachable under a zero lower bound and contributed to a considerable flattening of the term structure.
Rationale: Philip R. Lane's speech emphasizes the use of non-standard monetary policies like negative interest rates and asset purchases to lower the yield curve and stimulate the economy. The discussion suggests an accommodative stance aligned with dovish views, though he does not explicitly indicate further policy easing, leading to a 'Hold' prediction.
description: Speech by Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Public Lecture for the Centre for Finance and the Department of Economics, University College London, London, 25 November 2019.

author: Philip R Lane
title: Interview with Sky TG24
Key quote: If it is necessary to put the rate lower, we will be prepared to do so.
Rationale: Philip R. Lane emphasizes that although current interest rates are low and negative, the ECB is still ready to take further action if necessary. He acknowledges concerns about the effects of negative rates but believes the existing policies are appropriate under the current conditions, suggesting a somewhat accommodative stance. Additionally, Lane focuses on external factors such as fiscal policies and investment reforms rather than immediate ECB action, pointing towards continuing the current policy unless conditions change dramatically.
description: Transcript of the interview with Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, and Sky TG24, conducted by Mr Alessandro Marenzi, Sky TG24, with the participation of Mr Federico Fubini, Corriere della Sera, and Mr Franco Bruni, Bocconi University, and broadcast on 23 November 2019.

author: Philip R Lane
title: Interview in La Repubblica
Key quote: Our baseline scenario is a recovery in economic performance, but we have been consistent in highlighting that there's also downside risk.
Rationale: Philip R Lane acknowledges the economic slowdown and downside risks but expresses optimism for a recovery aided by ECB's accommodative policy, suggesting a somewhat dovish stance with an inclination to hold rates as more monetary accommodation is still available if needed.
description: Interview with Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in La Repubblica, conducted by Ms Tonia Mastrobuoni on 14 November 2019 and published on 20 November 2019.

author: Philip R Lane
title: Q&amp;A with Fortune
Key quote: The most important element of the decision in September was: we need to add extra accommodation in our monetary policy, that inflation is too low and we need to demonstrate our commitment to having inflation move back towards its target sooner rather than later.
Rationale: Philip Lane's comments emphasize the need for continued monetary accommodation and the challenges of low inflation. He highlights the ECB's commitment to keeping accommodative policies as long as necessary, which is a dovish stance.
description: Q&amp;A with Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, and Fortune, conducted by Ms Maithreyi Seetharaman at Fortune Global Forum, Paris, 18 November 2019.

author: Philip R Lane
title: The international transmission of monetary policy
Key quote: Recent ECB staff analysis suggests that the net impact of a monetary policy expansion on the trade balance is positive.
Rationale: The speech discusses the effects of accommodative monetary policy and its positive impact on trade balance and global liquidity but does not aggressively push for further easing measures, indicating a somewhat dovish tone. The speaker doesn't explicitly press for a rate cut, suggesting a 'Hold' on the next policy rate decision.
description: Keynote speech by Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the CEPR International Macroeconomics and Finance Programme Meeting, Frankfurt am Main, 14 November 2019.

author: Philip R Lane
title: Globalisation and monetary policy
Key quote: In turn, the deterioration in the inflation outlook prompted the further accommodative measures that we adopted in our recent monetary policy meeting.
Rationale: The speech recognizes the impact of global factors on the euro area slowdown and discusses the ECB's accommodative measures. Given the external pressures and mentions of previous accommodative decisions, the likelihood is for holding the policy rate rather than immediate further cuts.
description: Speech by Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the University of California, Los Angeles, California, 30 September 2019.

author: Philip R Lane
title: Q&amp;A with Reuters
Key quote: It's very important to say this is really not a dramatic policy move, it's a recalibration.
Rationale: Philip Lane emphasizes the need for recalibration of policy in light of the lower inflation forecast, rather than dramatic measures. He highlights the strong labor and services markets and suggests the euro area will maintain growth, indicating a bias towards keeping policies supportive but not aggressively easing further.
description: Q&amp;A with Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, conducted by Mr Daniel Burns, at Reuters Newsmaker, New York City, 27 September 2019.

author: Philip R Lane
title: Interview in Handelsblatt
Key quote: Yes, we see enough leeway for further interest rate cuts, should they be necessary.
Rationale: Philip R Lane's comments indicate a willingness to continue supporting the economy with low interest rates and asset purchases, despite some criticism. His acknowledgment of potential further cuts if needed shows a dovish stance prioritizing economic recovery and inflation convergence to target.
description: Interview with Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in Handelsblatt, conducted by Mr Jan Mallien and Mr Frank Wiebe on 24 September 2019 and published on 26 September 2019.

author: Philip R Lane
title: Reflections on monetary policy
Key quote: The case for a monetary policy response was clear, and a comprehensive package of measures was judged to be the most effective way to support the convergence of inflation to our aim.
Rationale: The speech focuses on addressing downside risks to growth and a persistent shortfall in inflation, indicating a need for expansionary measures, including rate cuts and asset purchases.
description: Keynote speech by Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at Bloomberg, London, 16 September 2019.

author: Philip R Lane
title: Monetary policy and below-target inflation
Key quote: Furthermore, the effectiveness of the policy toolkit means that we can add further monetary accommodation if it is required to deliver our objective.
Rationale: The speech by Philip R Lane indicates a willingness to provide further monetary accommodation if needed, emphasizing the effectiveness of measures like negative interest rates, APP, and TLTROs. The tone suggests a predisposition to cut rates or implement additional easing to achieve inflation targets, reflecting a somewhat dovish stance.
description: Speech by Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Bank of Finland conference on Monetary Policy and Future of EMU, Helsinki, 2 July 2019.

author: Philip R Lane
title: Interview with Yle
Key quote: So if you like the main conclusion of my talk today is that we should be confident that even under these conditions the ECB has the policy measures to allow it to respond to shocks to the economy, shocks to inflation.
Rationale: Philip R Lane acknowledges potential downside risks while maintaining an overall optimistic forecast, suggesting a readiness to maintain accommodative policies, but not an immediate need for further easing, leading to a more dovish stance.
description: Interview with Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, and Yle (Finnish public service broadcasting company), conducted by Mr Aapo Parviainen and broadcast on 1 July 2019.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: Reassessing monetary policy tools in a volatile macroeconomic environment
Key quote: Raising policy rates quickly has proven highly effective in reigning in inflation by dampening the growth in aggregate demand and anchoring inflation expectations.
Rationale: Isabel Schnabel's speech discusses the importance of agility in monetary policy, the effectiveness of rate hikes in controlling inflation, and the cautious use of QE, implying a somewhat hawkish stance as she reflects on current high domestic price pressures and the need for quick adjustments.
description: Speech by Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the ECB, at the 25th Jacques Polak Annual Research Conference

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: The ECB’s balance sheet reduction: an interim assessment
Key quote: My main message is that, while excess liquidity is remaining ample, the ECB’s balance sheet reduction is progressing smoothly and has helped improve market functioning.
Rationale: The speech indicates a gradual reduction in the ECB's balance sheet and overall economic stability, suggesting some tightening. However, with the ample excess liquidity and market stability, a 'hold' decision is likely at the next interest rate meeting to assess the ongoing impact of these measures.
description: Speech by Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the ECB, at the annual ECB Conference on Money Markets

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: Escaping stagnation: towards a stronger euro area
Key quote: With signs of softening labour demand and further progress in disinflation, a sustainable fall of inflation back to our 2% target in a timely manner is becoming more likely.
Rationale: Schnabel acknowledges both the challenges and opportunities facing the euro area and indicates that the peak impact of monetary tightening is behind us, suggesting a neutral stance. However, she does not provide clear signals for immediate changes in monetary policy.
description: Speech by Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the ECB, at a lecture in memory of Walter Eucken

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: The euro area inflation outlook - a scenario analysis
Key quote: In the current environment, monetary policy should remain focused on bringing inflation back to our target in a timely manner, for three main reasons.
Rationale: Schnabel acknowledges the progress in disinflation but emphasizes the persistence of inflationary pressures, particularly in services. The speech is balanced, indicating a cautious approach to adjusting monetary policy, hence the prediction to 'Hold' rates.
description: Lecture by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Ragnar Nurkse Lecture Series, organised by Eesti Pank, Tallinn, 30 August 2024.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: Is monetary policy dominated by fiscal policy?
Key quote: This was a remarkable success for monetary policy, which contributed to our decision yesterday to lower interest rates by 25 basis points.
Rationale: Schnabel emphasizes the ECB's recent decision to cut interest rates and highlights the successes of monetary policy, but also notes uncertainties in the future inflation outlook, suggesting a dovish tilt to ensure stability.
description: Speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at a conference organised by Stiftung Geld und Währung on 25 years of the euro – Perspectives for monetary and fiscal policy in an unstable world, at a panel on "Inflation and public budget. Is monetary policy dominated by fiscal policy?", Frankfurt am Main, 7 June 2024.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: The benefits and costs of asset purchases
Key quote: Central banks can only credibly communicate about the likely future direction of monetary policy in a 'Delphic' way - that is conditional on how the economy evolves.
Rationale: The speech extensively discusses the benefits and costs of asset purchases, highlighting their effectiveness during crises but also noting their side effects and limited impact in normal times. Ms. Schnabel does not strongly advocate for immediate policy responses, suggesting a neutral stance.
description: Speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the 2024 BOJ-IMES Conference "Price Dynamics and Monetary Policy Challenges: Lessons Learned and Going Forward", hosted by the Institute for Monetary and Economic Studies, Tokyo, 28 May 2024.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: The future of inflation (forecast) targeting
Key quote: The question we are facing today is whether, in view of the recent normalisation of forecast errors, central banks should return to the strict inflation forecast targeting that prevailed most of the time before the pandemic.
Rationale: The speech acknowledges the challenges and errors in inflation forecasting but ultimately underscores the resilience and validation of the inflation targeting framework. This suggests a neutral stance, neither particularly dovish nor hawkish, but cautious and data-driven. With the policy rate already high, this indicates a likely 'Hold' on rates with moderate probability.
description: Keynote speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the thirteenth conference organised by the International Research Forum on Monetary Policy "Monetary Policy Challenges during Uncertain Times", at the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, Washington, DC, 17 April 2024.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: The Eurosystem's operational framework
Key quote: The changes to our operational framework do not have any implications for our monetary policy stance, neither for our interest rate policy nor for our monetary policy bond portfolios, which we expect to continue to be run off.
Rationale: The speech primarily addresses the operational framework rather than signaling any change in monetary policy stance. The emphasis is on continuity in monetary policy execution without direct implications for interest rates, suggesting a likely hold on rates.
description: Speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Money Market Contact Group meeting, Frankfurt am Main, 14 March 2024.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: From laggard to leader? Closing the euro area's technology gap
Key quote: In this environment, monetary policy needs to remain restrictive until we can be confident that inflation will sustainably return to our medium-term target.
Rationale: The speech primarily focuses on structural issues in Europe's productivity and does not explicitly advocate for changes in monetary policy. However, the reference to maintaining restrictive policy until inflation is controlled suggests a neutral stance with a slight emphasis on caution.
description: Inaugural lecture of the EMU lab by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the European University Institute, Florence, 16 February 2024.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: The last mile
Key quote: This also means that we cannot close the door to further rate hikes.
Rationale: The speech points to persistent risks of inflation and the need for vigilance and perseverance. Despite progress in disinflation, uncertainties remain about future inflation dynamics, requiring readiness for further tightening if needed.
description: Keynote speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the annual Homer Jones Memorial Lecture, St Louis, Missouri, 2 November 2023.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: The risks of stubborn inflation
Key quote: We thus need to keep raising interest rates until we see convincing evidence that developments in underlying inflation are consistent with a return of headline inflation to our 2% medium-term target in a sustained and timely manner.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the risks of inflation persistence and the need for continued interest rate hikes to ensure price stability, indicating a strong hawkish stance.
description: Speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Euro50 Group conference on "New challenges for the Economic and Monetary Union in the post-crisis environment", Luxembourg, 19 June 2023.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: Monetary and financial stability – can they be separated?
Key quote: The ECB can continue to do whatever is needed to bring inflation back to our 2% target in a timely manner. This implies raising rates to a sufficiently restrictive level and keeping them at that level for as long as necessary.
Rationale: The speech highlights concerns over high inflation and discusses previous and potential strategies to address financial instability without compromising the focus on raising rates to ensure price stability, indicative of a somewhat hawkish stance.
description: Speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Conference on Financial Stability and Monetary Policy in the honour of Charles Goodhart, London, 19 May 2023.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: Back to normal? Balance sheet size and interest rate control
Key quote: It is therefore prudent to start reviewing the options available to ensure that the ECB maintains control over the level of short-term money market rates during the process of balance sheet normalisation.
Rationale: The focus on quantitative tightening signals a move towards normalization of monetary policy, which is typically a hawkish stance. However, the detailed discussion on frameworks for steering interest rates amidst an uncertain demand for reserves indicates caution, suggesting a 'Hold' on rates decision in the immediate term.
description: Speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at an event organised by Columbia University and SGH Macro Advisor, New York, 27 March 2023.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: Quantitative tightening - rationale and market impact
Key quote: QT will gradually unwind this accommodative impact.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the importance of quantitative tightening as a part of policy normalization, aiming to regain policy space and withdraw monetary accommodation, which is consistent with a hawkish policy stance focused on controlling inflation.
description: Speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Money Market Contact Group meeting, Frankfurt am Main, 2 March 2023.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: Monetary policy tightening and the green transition
Key quote: We judge that interest rates will still have to rise significantly at a steady pace to reach levels that are sufficiently restrictive to ensure a timely return of inflation to our 2% medium-term target.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the need to continue raising interest rates to manage inflation, despite potential negative effects on green transition investments. The consistent focus on controlling inflation indicates a hawkish stance.
description: Speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the International Symposium on Central Bank Independence, panel on "Central bank independence and new risks: climate", organised by Sveriges Riksbank, Stockholm, 10 January 2023.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: Finding the right mix - monetary-fiscal interaction at times of high inflation
Key quote: Central banks, for their part, must remain determined to bring inflation back to target in a timely manner, so as to prevent current high inflation from becoming entrenched in expectations.
Rationale: Isabel Schnabel emphasizes the necessity of further interest rate hikes to combat inflation and prevent its entrenchment. The tone is clearly hawkish as she signals a determination to tighten monetary policy despite risks of recession.
description: Keynote speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Bank of England Watchers' Conference, organised by the Money Macro Finance Society and King's Business School at King's College, London, 24 November 2022.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: Monetary policy in a cost-of-living crisis
Key quote: Considering these data and the above-target medium-term inflation outlook, further increases in our key policy rates will be needed to ensure that inflation returns to our 2% target in a timely manner.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the need for a 'robust control' approach to address persistent inflation pressures, indicating a strong likelihood of rate hikes despite slowing aggregate demand.
description: Speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at a panel on the "Fight against inflation" at the IV Edition Foro La Toja, La Toja, 30 September 2022.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: Reconciling the macro and micro evidence on the effects of monetary policy
Key quote: The ECB raised its policy rates by 50 basis points in July and by another 75 basis points last week. Based on our current assessment, over the Governing Council's next several meetings, we expect to raise interest rates further towards levels that will ensure the timely return of inflation to our 2% medium-term target.
Rationale: The speech clearly indicates a strong commitment to further raising interest rates, responding to high inflation rates, which signals a hawkish stance towards monetary policy.
description: Welcome address by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the seventh ECB Annual Research Conference, Frankfurt am Main, 12 September 2022.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: Monetary policy and the Great Volatility
Key quote: For the first time in four decades, central banks need to prove how determined they are to protect price stability.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the need for a 'forceful response' to inflation, stipulating that central banks should act with determination, even at the risk of lower growth and higher unemployment. This strongly indicates a hawkish stance, pointing towards an interest rate raise to combat persistent inflation.
description: Speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the "Reassessing Constraints on the Economy and Policy" economic policy symposium sponsored by the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, Jackson Hole, Wyoming, 27 August 2022.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: United in diversity - challenges for monetary policy in a currency union
Key quote: We will not tolerate changes in financing conditions that go beyond fundamental factors and that threaten monetary policy transmission.
Rationale: The speech highlights the ECB's commitment to counteract market fragmentation that may impair the transmission of monetary policy, indicating a cautious approach to maintaining current policy. While acknowledging the need to address high inflation, the speech emphasizes flexibility and readiness to respond to market disruptions rather than immediate tightening.
description: Commencement speech by Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, to the graduates of the Master Program in Money, Banking, Finance and Insurance of the Panthéon-Sorbonne University, Paris, 14 June 2022.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: The globalisation of inflation
Key quote: The urgency for monetary policy to take action to protect price stability has increased in recent weeks.
Rationale: The speech clearly indicates a concern that high inflation is becoming entrenched in expectations and underscores the need for monetary policy action, suggesting a somewhat hawkish stance with probable support for raising rates.
description: Speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at a conference organised by the Österreichische Vereinigung für Finanzanalyse und Asset Management, Vienna, 11 May 2022.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: Managing policy trade-offs
Key quote: Continuing the path of policy normalisation is therefore the appropriate course of action.
Rationale: The speech argues for continuing the process of policy normalization, highlighting persistent inflationary pressures and the necessity of maintaining price stability, suggesting a somewhat hawkish stance.
description: Speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at a workshop organised by the European House – Ambrosetti on "The Agenda for Europe: Macroeconomic and Structural Policy Challenges", Cernobbio, 2 April 2022.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: Finding the right sequence
Key quote: The inflation outlook has firmed since the start of the year. Inflationary pressures have broadened and have become more persistent.
Rationale: The speech acknowledges inflation pressures and suggests a need for policy normalisation, yet signals a gradual, data-dependent approach. Thus, while somewhat hawkish due to concerns over inflation, the stance indicates a likely hold on rates in the immediate term.
description: Speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at a virtual policy panel on "Unwinding QE" at the first annual Bank of England Agenda for Research (BEAR) conference, Frankfurt am Main, 24 February 2022.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: Asset purchases – from crisis to recovery
Key quote: Given the remaining uncertainty regarding the pandemic and the economic and inflation outlook, our asset purchases - both under the PEPP and the APP - will remain crucial in the time to come, paving the way out of the pandemic and towards reaching our inflation target.
Rationale: The emphasis on continuing asset purchases and the importance of maintaining a supportive monetary policy stance suggest a somewhat dovish position, although not entirely dovish due to the recognition of improving economic conditions. The commitment to existing programs implies a likely vote to hold rates.
description: Speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Annual Conference of Bank of Latvia on "Sustainable Economy in Times of Change", Frankfurt am Main, 20 September 2021.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: New narratives on monetary policy – the spectre of inflation
Key quote: A premature monetary policy tightening in response to a temporary rise in inflation would choke the recovery and be most harmful to those who are already suffering from the current spike in inflation.
Rationale: The speech indicates a belief that the current inflation spike is temporary and suggests that tightening policy prematurely could harm the recovery, indicating a somewhat dovish stance despite rising inflation rates.
description: Speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the 148th Baden-Baden Entrepreneurs' Talk, Frankfurt am Main, 13 September 2021.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: A new strategy for a changing world
Key quote: We have changed our definition of price stability to a clear and symmetric 2% target in the medium term. We have also clarified that, when our policy rates are close to the lower bound, we intend to react especially forcefully or persistently to disinflationary shocks.
Rationale: The speech outlines the ECB's revised monetary policy strategy, emphasizing a symmetric 2% inflation target and the need for forceful action at the lower bound. While this could suggest dovish tendencies, the overall tone remains balanced, with a focus on maintaining inflation expectations, resulting in a neutral stance.
description: Speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at a virtual event series, hosted by the Peterson Institute for International Economics, 14 July 2021.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: Escaping low inflation?
Key quote: For it to become sustained, monetary policy needs to remain expansionary to avoid choking off the incipient recovery.
Rationale: Schnabel emphasized the need for continued monetary support to ensure recovery, highlighting a cautious optimism for future inflation but making clear that persistent monetary expansion is necessary, indicating a somewhat dovish stance.
description:
Speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Petersberger Sommerdialog
Frankfurt am Main, 3 July 2021.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: Societal responsibility and central bank independence
Key quote: Central banks today need to exhibit the same degree of persistence, courage and commitment.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the importance of central bank independence, societal responsibility, and addressing climate change, while reiterating the commitment to stable prices. The speech does not explicitly indicate an immediate shift in monetary policy stance, preserving a balanced or neutral tone.
description: Keynote speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the "VIII. New Paradigm Workshop", organised by the Forum New Economy, Frankfurt am Main, 27 May 2021.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: Paving the path to recovery by preserving favourable financing conditions
Key quote: Preserving favourable financing conditions is a powerful policy response to the challenges we are currently facing.
Rationale: The speech by Isabel Schnabel emphasizes the importance of maintaining favorable financing conditions and highlights the ECB's commitment to preserving these conditions without further lowering rates. This indicates a dovish stance, focusing on supporting economic recovery rather than tightening monetary policy. The speech suggests holding rates steady while ensuring sufficient monetary accommodation.
description: Speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at New York University Stern Fireside Chat, Frankfurt am Main, 25 March 2021.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: Unconventional fiscal and monetary policy at the zero lower bound
Key quote: In the vicinity of the lower bound, the central bank needs to weigh more carefully the evolving balance of the benefits and costs of lowering short- and long-term rates further.
Rationale: The speech suggests that monetary policy should remain supportive and emphasizes the need for a combination of monetary and fiscal policies to address low inflation. It indicates caution in further rate cuts and a focus on maintaining favorable financing conditions. Thus, the ECB is likely to hold rates steady while assessing economic conditions.
description: Keynote speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Third Annual Conference organised by the European Fiscal Board on "High Debt, Low Rates and Tail Events: Rules-Based Fiscal Frameworks under Stress", Frankfurt am Main, 26 February 2021.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: The sovereign-bank-corporate nexus – virtuous or vicious?
Key quote: The ECB, for its part, has committed to preserve favourable financing conditions for as long as necessary, reinforcing the fiscal response.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the importance of maintaining supportive monetary and fiscal policies to avert financial instability, suggesting a cautious approach to changing rates. However, it acknowledges the effectiveness of current measures, hinting at a preference to hold rates steady.
description: Speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the LSE conference on Financial Cycles, Risk, Macroeconomic Causes and Consequences, Frankfurt am Main, 28 January 2021.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: The importance of trust for the European Central Banks's monetary policy
Key quote: The ECB has thus introduced negative interest rates and bond-buying programmes to safeguard price stability in the euro area.
Rationale: The focus of the speech on trust and measures taken by the ECB to ensure stability during the pandemic signals a somewhat dovish stance. However, given the economic uncertainties and existing negative rates, a prediction to 'Hold' rates with a moderate probability seems appropriate.
description: Speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, as part of the seminar series "Havarie Europa. Zur Pathogenese europäischer Gegenwarten" at the Hamburg Institute for Social Research (Hamburger Institut für Sozialforschung), Frankfurt am Main, 16 December 2020.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: COVID-19 and monetary policy - reinforcing prevailing challenges
Key quote: Preserving them for as long as needed will be essential to ensure that inflation returns to our aim in the medium term.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes low inflation, risks of disinflation, and the importance of maintaining accommodative financial conditions, without explicitly stating a need for further loosening, aligning with a somewhat dovish stance.
description: Speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at The Bank of Finland Monetary Policy webinar "New Challenges to Monetary Policy Strategies", Frankfurt am Main, 24 November 2020.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: Shifting tides in euro area money markets - from the global financial crisis to the COVID-19 pandemic
Key quote: Most importantly, the decisive policy response by the Eurosystem prevented localised tensions from turning into a broader liquidity crisis, thereby ensuring the smooth transmission of our monetary policy.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes structural changes and resilience in money markets while highlighting the supportive role of low rates and monetary interventions, suggesting a preference for maintaining current accommodative conditions.
description: Speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the ECB Conference on Money Markets, Frankfurt am Main, 23 November 2020.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: COVID-19 and the liquidity crisis of non-banks - lessons for the future
Key quote: Forceful monetary policy action, on both sides of the Atlantic, ultimately filled the void that was left by asset managers and regulators having limited liquidity management tools to curb systemic stress.
Rationale: Isabel Schnabel's speech highlights the importance of monetary policy in stabilizing markets during the COVID-19 pandemic, expressing concern about vulnerabilities in the non-bank sector. This indicates a dovish stance focused on maintaining current policies to support financial stability.
description: Speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Financial Stability Conference on "Stress, Contagion, and Transmission", organised by the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland and the Office of Financial Research, Frankfurt am Main, 19 November 2020.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: Monetary policy in changing conditions
Key quote: Summing up, I have argued that, in light of the second wave of COVID-19 infections and renewed lockdowns, further monetary policy support is required to safeguard favourable financial conditions and underpin economic activity in the face of a deteriorating growth outlook.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the need for continued monetary policy support due to the second wave of COVID-19, suggesting a cautious approach rather than immediate tightening. The emphasis on support, coupled with the current negative policy rate, indicates a somewhat dovish stance, leaning towards maintaining the current stance rather than cutting rates further.
description: Speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the second EBI Policy Conference on "Europe and the Covid-19 Crisis - Looking back and looking forward", Frankfurt am Main, 4 November 2020.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: Pulling together - fiscal and monetary policies in a low interest rate environment
Key quote: These are not the times to worry that rising government debt today could undermine price stability tomorrow.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the importance of fiscal and structural policies to support the economy and suggests that monetary policy will remain supportive. This indicates a somewhat dovish stance, as it downplays inflation concerns and prioritizes recovery over immediate monetary tightening.
description: Speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Interparliamentary Conference on Stability, Economic Coordination and Governance in the European Union, Frankfurt am Main, 12 October 2020.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: Unequal scars - distributional consequences of the pandemic
Key quote: The decisive measures taken by fiscal policy makers at national and European level as well as the ECB's monetary policy will help to mitigate a looming economic divergence between individual European countries.
Rationale: The speech primarily discusses the economic impact of COVID-19 rather than current monetary policy. It emphasizes the importance of fiscal policy and the ECB’s role in alleviating financial stress during the pandemic, suggesting the existing measures are appropriate, leading to a neutral stance.
description: Speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the panel discussion "Sharing the burden of the pandemic", Deutscher Juristentag 2020, 18 September 2020.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: The shadow of fiscal dominance - misconceptions, perceptions and perspectives
Key quote: The ECB will be careful to not choke the incipient recovery by initiating a tighter policy too early.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the importance of maintaining accommodative monetary policy in light of low interest rates and ongoing recovery from the COVID-19 crisis. The focus is on supporting economic recovery with fiscal policy playing a larger role in stabilizing the economy, which suggests a dovish tilt but stops short of indicating a rate cut.
description: Speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Centre for European Reform and the Eurofi Financial Forum on "Is the current ECB monetary policy doing more harm than good and what are the alternatives?" Berlin, 11 September 2020.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: Going negative - the ECB's experience
Key quote: I will argue that the transmission of negative rates has worked smoothly and that, in combination with other policy measures, they have been effective in stimulating the economy and raising inflation.
Rationale: The speech acknowledges the effectiveness of negative rates in stimulating the economy and increasing inflation but also highlights potential side effects. The overall assessment is balanced but slightly leans towards maintaining current policies with a dovish outlook on future rate cuts.
description: Speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Roundtable on Monetary Policy, Low Interest Rates and Risk Taking at the 35th Congress of the European Economic Association, Frankfurt am Main, 26 August 2020.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: The European Central Bank's policy in the COVID-19 crisis - a medium-term perspective
Key quote: Further strong policy support was needed to prevent medium-term inflation from moving further away from our inflation aim of below, but close to, 2%.
Rationale: The speech acknowledges significant economic challenges and emphasizes the ECB's accommodative stance through measures like the PEPP to support the economy. The speech reflects a bias toward maintaining supportive conditions without further immediate easing, suggesting a 'Hold' on rates.
description: Remarks by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at an online seminar hosted by the Florence School of Banking &amp; Finance, Frankfurt am Main, 10 June 2020.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: The European Central Bank's response to the COVID-19 pandemic
Key quote: The ECB has responded forcefully to this historic crisis by adopting a wide-ranging set of carefully calibrated measures that collectively help mitigate the economic and financial fallout from the pandemic.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the ECB's comprehensive and accommodative response to the COVID-19 pandemic by introducing various measures, such as asset purchases and lending operations, to ease financial conditions and maintain liquidity. These actions signal a dovish stance aimed at supporting the economy during a period of crisis, despite the policy rate already being at -0.5%.
description: Remarks by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at a 24-Hour Global Webinar co-organised by the SAFE Policy Center on "The COVID-19 Crisis and Its Aftermath: Corporate Governance Implications and Policy Challenges", Frankfurt am Main, 16 April 2020.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: Interview in To Vima
Key quote: The ECB has made it clear that, within its mandate, it will do everything needed in order to safeguard the full transmission of its monetary policy in all euro area countries.
Rationale: The speech highlights the ECB's commitment to maintain and expand its accommodative measures to counter the adverse economic impact of the pandemic, placing a strong emphasis on flexibility and additional monetary easing measures such as the PEPP. It signals a very dovish stance aimed at supporting the economy. However, given the already negative policy rate, a further cut is less likely, leading to a 'Hold' prediction.
description: Interview with Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in To Vima (Greek daily newspaper), conducted by Mr Angelos Athanasopoulos and published on 4 April 2020.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: Interview in Frankfurter Allgemeine Sonntagszeitung
Key quote: For now we need to concentrate on mitigating the effects of this crisis.
Rationale: The overall tone of the speech is dovish, emphasizing the need for continued support and the inappropriateness of talking about rate hikes during the crisis. There is a clear indication of readiness to use further measures if needed, highlighting a desire to support the economy rather than restrict it.
description: Interview with Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in Frankfurter Allgemeine Sonntagszeitung, conducted by Mr Patrick Bernau and Mr Dennis Kremer and published on 21 March 2020.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: Interview in Die Zeit
Key quote: The ECB stands ready to do everything within its mandate to counter market disruptions that impair the transmission of its monetary policy, because monetary policy cannot otherwise be effective.
Rationale: The focus on providing abundant liquidity, readiness to take necessary measures, and emphasis on coordinated fiscal response suggests a dovish stance, aiming to support the economy amid crisis.
description: Interview with Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in Die Zeit, conducted by Ms Lisa Nienhaus on 16 March 2020 and published on 18 March 2020.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: How long is the medium term? Monetary policy in a low inflation environment
Key quote: Such sizeable and persistent supply-side shocks pose a dilemma for central banks. On the one hand, they call for a lengthening of the horizon over which the ECB should steer inflation back to its aim.
Rationale: The speech suggests patience in monetary policy due to structural factors affecting inflation, indicating a somewhat dovish stance. While there is an acknowledgment of the challenges present, immediate rate cuts are not suggested, so holding rates becomes the most probable decision.
description: Speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Barclays International Monetary Policy Forum, London, 27 February 2020.

author: Isabel Schnabel
title: Narratives about the ECB's monetary policy - reality or fiction?
Key quote: I will demonstrate that the ECB's current monetary policy stance is necessary in order to achieve sustained price stability in the euro area.
Rationale: The speech defends the use of low interest rates and unconventional monetary policy to achieve price stability, suggesting a somewhat dovish stance. The emphasis on structural factors outside the ECB's control implies a reluctance to change the current policy, supporting a 'Hold' prediction.
description: Speech by Ms Isabel Schnabel, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Juristische Studiengesellschaft, Karlsruhe, 11 February 2020.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Two insights concerning the latest developments in price stability and financial stability
Key quote: We decided yesterday a second rate cut.
Rationale: The speech highlights a recent rate cut, a commitment to being data-driven, and a focus on undershooting inflation risks, all of which are dovish indicators. The speaker clearly indicates that further rate cuts may be forthcoming, leading to a strong prediction of continued easing.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the 2024 Eurofi Financial Forum, Budapest, 13 September 2024.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Central banks' exit from the Garden of Eden
Key quote: Our pragmatic gradualism is consistent with a gradually higher weight given to the projected outlook - and giving gradually lower weight to the inflow of data.
Rationale: The speech acknowledges both the success of recent disinflation efforts and the potential for continued volatility, suggesting a balanced view. Furthermore, the Governor highlights the importance of maintaining the inflation target and suggests a non-reactive approach to minor data changes, indicating a 'Hold' in policy stance.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Global Interdependence Center Conference, Paris, 28 June 2024.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Central banks between economic soft landing and growing public expectations
Key quote: Therefore, as we are confident enough about reaching our 2% target, the time had come for a first cut by 25 bp and having a somewhat less restrictive monetary policy.
Rationale: The speech indicates confidence in reaching the inflation target, emphasizes a recent rate cut, and suggests a gradual approach to future cuts, implying a somewhat dovish stance.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Oesterreichische Nationalbank, the Austrian central bank, and SUERF Conference, Vienna, 11 June 2024.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Presentation of the 2023 Annual Report of the Prudential Supervision and Resolution Authority
Key quote: Following the rise in interest rates up until September 2023 in order to - successfully - combat inflation, we are set to reverse the interest rate cycle - most probably next week.
Rationale: The speech indicates a likely reversal of the interest rate cycle, suggesting a cut, which is dovish in nature.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France and Chair of the Prudential Supervision and Resolution Authority (ACPR), at the ACPR press conference, Paris, 29 May 2024.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Releasing the screw? Monetary policy at a crossroad
Key quote: This is why the time has come, in the euro area, to ease monetary restriction: following our Governing Council meeting last week, we should, barring major shocks or surprises, decide on a first rate cut at our next meeting on 6 June.
Rationale: The speech suggests that it is time to ease monetary restrictions with a rate cut at the next meeting and further cuts likely throughout the year. The focus on controlled disinflation and gradualism underscores a dovish stance.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, to the Economic Club of New York, New York City, 16 April 2024.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Anatomy of a fall in inflation - from a successful first phase to the conditions for a controlled landing
Key quote: The time has come to insure against this second risk, by starting to lower rates.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes cautious optimism regarding inflation but signals concern about economic growth, suggesting a preference for an interest rate cut to support economic activity. The advocacy for 'agile gradualism' indicates a somewhat dovish stance, supporting an early rate cut despite inflation projections nearing the target.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at Paris-Dauphine University, Paris, 28 March 2024.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Monetary and fiscal policy-mix addressing the disease of inflation
Key quote: Monetary policy is the first line of defence, and the main remedy for this disease.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the priority of fighting inflation and suggests a need for coordinated monetary and fiscal policies to manage inflation effectively. While the commitment to reach the 2% inflation target is strong, there is no explicit call for further rate hikes, resulting in a somewhat hawkish stance with an expected hold on rates at the next meeting.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Eurofi Financial Forum 2023, Santiago de Compostela, 15 September 2023.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: The euro as a complementary asset in a more multilateral system
Key quote: We decided yesterday a 25 basis point increase, in line with the slower pace adopted early May. And our future decisions will be data driven, meeting by meeting.
Rationale: While there is acknowledgment of recent rate increases, the focus on data-driven decisions and observations that inflation has peaked suggest a neutral approach moving forward. The speech indicates a wait-and-see stance rather than a clear inclination towards raising or cutting rates.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the conference "The internationalisation of the euro and the creation of the EU Capital Markets Union", Paris, 16 June 2023.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Monetary policy transmission
Key quote: We already have completed most of our rate-hiking journey, and we are clearly in restrictive territory.
Rationale: The speech highlights the effectiveness of past rate hikes, indicates reduced pace, and emphasizes maintaining restrictive rates to curb inflation, suggesting some hawkishness. The focus on monitoring effects and allowing for potential pauses, however, leads to a 'Hold' prediction.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Annual General Meeting of the International Capital Market Association (ICMA), Paris, 25 May 2023.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Monetary policy transmission - where do we stand?
Key quote: Persistence is now more important than speed; the duration for which we will maintain rates is now more important than the precise terminal level we will reach.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the extensive impact of current rate hikes and suggests that further rate increases may not be necessary immediately, but the focus is on maintaining rates rather than increasing them aggressively.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the 2023 International Symposium, National Association for Business Economics, Paris, 22 May 2023.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Banking turmoil - three blessings and a funeral
Key quote: An intrusive and effective supervision; a regulation implemented everywhere; and some soul-searching on resolution.
Rationale: The speech by François Villeroy de Galhau emphasizes the importance of active supervision, regulation, and the Basel framework, highlighting the resilience provided by these tools in the face of banking turmoil. While not explicitly advocating for rate hikes, the focus on strict regulation and supervision suggests a somewhat hawkish stance aimed at maintaining financial stability.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Eurofi High-level Seminar 2023, Stockholm, 28 April 2023.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: The role of central banks in the "macroeconomics of climate change"
Key quote: Higher volatility is likely, which means shocks on both activity and inflation. This is where we central banks have to do our job in order to maintain a solid anchoring of long term inflation expectations despite higher volatility.
Rationale: The speech focuses on climate change and its potential impacts on the macroeconomy, stressing the importance of orderly transition and stability in inflation expectations. It does not suggest imminent changes to interest rates, aligning with a 'Hold' prediction at the current rate of 3%.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the City Week, London, 24 April 2023.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: How central banks should face instability and fragmentation
Key quote: Our commitment at the ECB is unambiguous: to make sure that inflation returns towards 2% by the end of 2024 or the end of 2025.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the ECB's commitment to controlling inflation and hints at further possible rate hikes but also suggests a transition to a more cautious approach—the 'long distance run.' This indicates a 'somewhat hawkish' stance with a likelihood of holding rates at the next meeting based on the progress already made in rate hikes.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Macro Week 2023, Peterson Institute for International Economics, Washington DC, 12 April 2023.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: European resilience and Parisian momentum
Key quote: Rest assured that the ECB Governing Council is fully committed to rein in inflation, and to ensure that it returns towards 2% by end 2024 or end 2025.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the ECB's commitment to control inflation and the possibility of further rate hikes, indicating a leaning towards tightening monetary policy.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Paris Europlace, New York, 11 April 2023.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Hearing before the Finance Committee of the French National Assembly
Key quote: I would like to emphasise not only our forecast, but also our commitment to bring inflation down to 2% by the end of 2024-25.
Rationale: The speech highlights the need for continued vigilance and a commitment to reduce inflation to the target of 2%, suggesting future rate hikes. While the economic outlook is mixed with some positive data, inflation remains a concern that needs addressing, indicating a somewhat hawkish stance.
description: Hearing of Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, before the Finance Committee of the French National Assembly, Paris, 1 March 2023.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: How monetary policy will defeat inflation - channels and locks
Key quote: Let me reiterate firmly here today, not just our forecast but also our commitment, alongside Christine Lagarde, to bring inflation back towards 2% in the euro area and France by end-2024/2025.
Rationale: Governor Villeroy de Galhau emphasized the need to combat inflation and expressed a commitment to continue raising rates if required, signaling a somewhat hawkish stance. He highlighted the resilience of the euro area economy, which allows for continued monetary tightening.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Centre des professions financières, Paris, 17 February 2023.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: New Year wishes 2023
Key quote: Inflation must not become entrenched. It is the number one concern for French people, and defeating it is our number one mission.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the importance of controlling inflation and hints at further interest rate increases to achieve monetary stabilization, signaling a somewhat hawkish stance.
description: New Year wishes to the Paris financial centre by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France and Chairman of the Autorité de contrôle prudentiel et de resolution (ACPR), Paris, 5 January 2023.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: The magnitude and distribution of the energy and trade shocks in the euro area and in France
Key quote: Overall, this shock, along with the associated spike in inflation, is likely to have a sizeable negative impact on growth for several quarters at least.
Rationale: The speech focuses on the negative impact of external shocks like rising energy prices on the economy, suggests fiscal support, and advises caution in public finance management. However, it does not strongly signal a need for immediate interest rate changes, suggesting a 'Hold' stance with a somewhat dovish leaning.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Toulouse School of Economics, Toulouse, 8 December 2022.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: How solid is our financial system in the new economic landscape?
