Key quote: As a result, we, the central banks, are working steadfastly to bring inflation back towards 2% in the next two to three years.
Rationale: The speech indicates a commitment to addressing rising inflation and hints at possible further rate increases, suggesting a somewhat hawkish stance. The focus on gradually raising rates aligns with a likely decision to raise rates at the upcoming meeting.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France and Chairman of the Autorité de contrôle prudentiel et de resolution (ACPR), at the Conference of ACPR, Paris, 5 December 2022.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: From a couple under pressure to a Europe in transition
Key quote: Beyond this, I believe that we will probably continue to raise rates, but we may do so in a more flexible and possibly less rapid manner - 'jumbo' rate hikes will not become a new habit.
Rationale: The speech acknowledges the necessity of further rate hikes to control inflation, showing resolve to continue tightening monetary policy but suggesting a more measured pace. This indicates a somewhat hawkish stance given the current high inflation rates.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the French German Business Forum, Paris, 16 November 2022.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Overcoming the energy crisis - a European perspective (and beyond)
Key quote: Therefore a normalisation in our stance has been clearly warranted over the last year.
Rationale: The central banker emphasizes the need for normalisation of monetary policy to combat inflation, indicating further rate hikes, albeit in a possibly more flexible manner.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Paris EUROPLACE Tokyo International Financial Forum 2022, Tokyo, 15 November 2022.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Fiscal policy and the debt challenge in the present crisis
Key quote: As monetary policy is, fiscal policy should be tightening too.
Rationale: The speaker emphasizes the need for fiscal policy to align with anti-inflationary monetary policy, suggesting a tightening stance but acknowledges complexities and nuances in implementation. This indicates a balanced approach, suggesting a neutral stance where the speaker would likely vote to hold rates.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the G30 37th Annual International Banking Seminar, Washington DC, 15 October 2022.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: What monetary policy narrative after forward guidance?
Key quote: Current inflation levels require that we clearly show our monetary determination.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes determination to act against inflation with a frontloaded approach to monetary policy normalization and a clear forecast to bring inflation back to 2%. This indicates a strong likelihood of raising rates in the near term.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Columbia University, New York, 11 October 2022.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Ethics of currency - a possible guide for central bankers?
Key quote: Inflation has accelerated significantly over the past year, reaching 9.1% in the euro area in August and 8.3% in the United States. Monetary normalisation is consequently fully warranted in the euro area among others.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the need for monetary normalization amidst high inflation rates, indicating a readiness to raise interest rates to ensure price stability. The speaker mentions the need to reach the neutral rate and possibly tighten beyond that if necessary, showcasing a hawkish stance.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Michel Camdessus Central Banking Lecture, Washington DC, 14 September 2022.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Mobilization of the Eurosystem against inflation
Key quote: We decided to frontload on our monetary policy normalisation. We did it because inflation is too high.
Rationale: The speaker emphasizes the need to act against high inflation, mentioning the recent decision to frontload monetary policy normalization and the commitment to returning inflation to 2%. The intention to proceed towards a neutral rate suggests a 'Raise' prediction.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Eurofi 2022 Financial Forum, Prague, 9 September 2022.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Monetary policy post-pandemic - balancing between science and art, predictability and reactivity
Key quote: But have no doubt that we at the ECB would if needed raise rates further beyond normalization: bringing inflation back to 2 % is our responsibility; our will and our capacity to deliver on our mandate are unconditional.
Rationale: The speech highlights concerns about inflation and discusses steps towards normalization and potentially tightening monetary policy. This indicates a somewhat hawkish stance, suggesting a focus on controlling inflation, possibly through raising rates.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the "Reassessing Constraints on the Economy and Policy" economic policy symposium sponsored by the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, Jackson Hole, Wyoming, 27 August 2022.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: In a highly uncertain world, refocusing Europe's goals and means of actions
Key quote: Inflation is not only too high, but also too broad, looking at core inflation (3.8% for May). This requires a normalisation of monetary policy.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the need to focus on reining in inflation and acknowledges the current broad nature of inflation. The phrase 'This requires a normalization of monetary policy' suggests a shift towards raising rates.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Centre for Economic Policy Research (CEPR) Spring Symposium, Paris, 2 June 2022.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Presentation of the 2021 Annual Report of the Prudential Supervision and Resolution Authority
Key quote: The latest inflation figures for May, for France and the other countries, confirm a rise that we were already expecting, and the need for a gradual but resolute process of normalisation.
Rationale: The speech discusses the need for a 'gradual but resolute process of normalisation' in response to rising inflation, indicates optimism about the financial sector's ability to handle rate increases, and views this as beneficial, suggesting a lean towards raising rates.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, Chair of the Prudential Supervision and Resolution Authority (ACPR) and Chair of the Board of Directors of the Bank for International Settlements, at the ACPR press conference, Paris, 31 May 2022.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Multipolarity and the role of the euro in the International Financial System
Key quote: To fight an inflation which is not only higher but broader, we now have to normalise our monetary policy.
Rationale: The speech discusses the need to normalize monetary policy to combat inflation, suggesting a somewhat hawkish stance. The mention of a 'decisive June meeting, and an active summer' indicates a likelihood of raising interest rates.
description: Welcome remarks by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Emerging Market Forum, Paris, 16 May 2022.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: The sustainability of French debt, between rising interest rates and European rules
Key quote: Our Governing Council will do whatever it takes to fulfil our primary price stability mandate; have no doubt about that.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes a clear intention to normalize monetary policy and raise rates in response to rising inflation, hinting at a more disciplined fiscal approach, which aligns with a 'Somewhat hawkish' stance.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Conference of the Haut Conseil des Finances Publiques, Paris, 10 May 2022.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: The Eurosystem and its monetary policy - from an "impossible dilemma" to a possible roadmap for normalisation
Key quote: Let me say it for the wider public of 340 million Europeans: you can trust us, your central bank, to ensure price stability and bring inflation back firmly and durably to 2%.
Rationale: The speech is leaning towards raising interest rates due to concerns about inflation and the need to normalize monetary policy. The mention of 'lift off' for interest rates later in the year suggests a somewhat hawkish stance.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Global Interdependence Center, GIC's Central Banking Series, Paris, 6 May 2022.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Looking up to achieve a Financing Union
Key quote: We will assess in our Governing Council in March the more indirect consequences on inflation and growth, and we will be facts driven: more than ever, optionality - about the right monetary stance - and flexibility - to guarantee the right monetary transmission - are the two names of the game for our policy.
Rationale: The speech focuses on European financial infrastructure improvements, mentioning optionality and flexibility in monetary policy in response to geopolitical developments. This indicates a balanced approach, suggesting no immediate change.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France and Chair of the Board of Directors of the Bank for International Settlements, at the EUROFI High Level Seminar 2022, Paris, 23 February 2022.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Monetary policy in uncertain times
Key quote: We will do what is necessary to bring inflation back firmly and durably to around 2% within our projection horizon.
Rationale: The speaker acknowledges high inflation and indicates that two out of the three criteria for considering interest rate hikes have been met, showing some hawkishness despite recognizing the importance of optionality and uncertainty. Therefore, a 'Hold' vote is likely as they balance current inflation trends with future uncertainty.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the London School of Economics, London, 15 February 2022.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Twenty years later- and twenty years ahead
Key quote: Yesterday, in the face of increasing uncertainty on inflation, our key word was « more than ever » optionality.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes a cautious approach to monetary policy with 'optionality' in the face of inflation uncertainty, suggesting a preference to wait for more data before making significant policy changes. This implies a supportive stance towards maintaining current rates rather than tightening, resulting in a 'Hold' prediction.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Warwick Economics Summit, virtual, 4 February 2022.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Rising temperatures - inflation, climate change and digital transformation
Key quote: The ECB remains very vigilant about prices and wages dynamics, and will gradually adjust its monetary policy to firmly ensure that inflation recedes soon and then stabilises around its 2% target over the medium term.
Rationale: The speech indicates a willingness to address rising inflation and gradually move from accommodative monetary policy, but also signals caution and a gradual approach. Villeroy de Galhau stresses vigilance and flexibility, suggesting a 'Hold' stance at the next meeting, with a potential for future tightening.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the World Economic Forum, virtual, 19 January 2022.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Making the post-Covid era a success for the French and European economy
Key quote: Should inflation prove to be more persistent, rest assured that we will be willing and able to adjust our monetary policy more quickly, to ensure a return to our 2% objective.
Rationale: The speech indicates that while inflation is currently high, it is expected to decrease throughout the year, with a possibility of needing to adjust monetary policy if it persists. This suggests a neutral stance, balancing inflation concerns with current economic growth forecasts.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Association Dauphine Discussion Débat / House of Finance, Paris, 18 January 2022.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: New Year wishes to the Paris financial centre
Key quote: We should then return not to the low inflation of the past, but to a new inflation regime close to our 2% target, with monetary policy normalising in stages accordingly.
Rationale: Villeroy de Galhau discusses optimism for overcoming the pandemic and short-term inflation pressures. He mentions a gradual normalization of monetary policy towards a 2% inflation target, suggesting a somewhat dovish stance due to caution and a measured approach to policy changes.
description: New Year wishes to the Paris financial centre by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France and Chairman of the Autorité de contrôle prudentiel et de resolution (ACPR), Paris, 4 January 2022.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Monetary strategy and inflation in Europe - what's new?
Key quote: This calls for a continued accommodative monetary policy.
Rationale: François Villeroy de Galhau emphasizes the ECB's commitment to maintaining an accommodative monetary policy and dismisses concerns about tapering as the pandemic recedes, suggesting a dovish outlook. However, he does acknowledge vigilance, reflecting a somewhat dovish stance overall.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the SUERF Conference, New York City, 12 October 2021.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Press Conference
Key quote: As the health and economic situation gradually normalises, there will be no reason to maintain the exceptional crisis support measures beyond next year.
Rationale: The speech focuses on financial stability, resilience through COVID-19, and non-monetary factors such as structural challenges and the need for innovation and climate action. This indicates a neutral stance on immediate monetary policy changes, suggesting a hold in the interest rate.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Presentation of the 2020 Annual Report of the Autorité de contrôle prudentiel et de résolution (ACPR), 28 May 2021.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Inflation and monetary policy in a post-Covid-19 world
Key quote: Our monetary policy can remain as accommodative as necessary, for as long as necessary.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the ECB's commitment to maintaining accommodative monetary policy and its willingness to accept inflation above 2% temporarily, signaling a dovish stance. While concerns about inflation exist, the overall tone suggests a readiness to persist with current accommodative measures.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Nordic Summit 2021, 25 May 2021.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: How to revisit central banking and financial stability?
Key quote: The time to exit has not yet arrived. We will continue PEPP net asset purchases 'until at least the end of March 2022 and, in any case, until [we] judge that the coronavirus crisis phase is over'.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the continuation of accommodative monetary policies and the non-imminent exit from the PEPP, suggesting a somewhat dovish stance with a focus on maintaining support rather than tightening.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Peterson Institute for International Economics, Washington DC, virtual event, 13 April 2021.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Europe's growth gap - reconciling Keynes and Schumpeter
Key quote: But according to many American economists, it could create a risk of the economy running above potential, 'making monetary policy more difficult to use in the future'.
Rationale: The speech reflects a balanced view on the current economic situation in Europe and the need for a mix of fiscal and structural policies. It does not explicitly advocate for monetary tightening or easing, but rather emphasizes execution speed and efficiency, suggesting a hold on the current rate.
description: High-level lecture by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the College of Europe, 31 March 2021.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: The tale of the three stabilities - price stability, financial stability and economic stability
Key quote: To achieve the ECB inflation objective, we are determined to maintain, as long as necessary, a very accommodative monetary stance.
Rationale: Villeroy de Galhau emphasizes maintaining a very accommodative monetary policy stance to achieve the inflation objective, indicating a somewhat dovish position, but also acknowledges financial stability concerns, suggesting an inclination to hold rather than cut rates.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Financial Stability Review Conference, 3 March 2021.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: French financial institutions faced with the crisis
Key quote: Our first objective must be to ensure that these financing conditions remain very favourable for everyone for as long as necessary.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the need to maintain favorable financing conditions to support the economy during prolonged uncertainty. The mention of a forthcoming recalibration of instruments suggests a cautious approach, supporting current policies rather than signaling immediate changes.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France and Chairman of the Autorité de contrôle prudentiel et de resolution (ACPR), at the virtual ACPR Day, 27 November 2020.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Central banks' response to the "tragedy on the horizon"
Key quote: I still think today that our present very accommodative monetary stance is appropriate. But steady hands are not tied hands: we have free hands for the future, and will be ready to act further if needed.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the importance of maintaining an accommodative monetary policy and suggests readiness to act further if necessary, indicating a somewhat dovish stance focused on supporting economic recovery and mitigating risks.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the SUERF - Online Conference, 14 October 2020.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: The role of central banks in the heart of the ecosystem
Key quote: Have no doubt about our determination to act as much as needed, and about our capacity to act.
Rationale: The speech highlights the ECB’s readiness to act with ample room for maneuver while expressing a commitment to keep inflation close to 2%. It acknowledges current inflation is not where desired and suggests more accommodative action if needed, reflecting a somewhat dovish stance.
description: Keynote address (virtual) by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Official Monetary and Financial Institutions Forum webinar, 25 September 2020.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Macro-economic and monetary challenges - towards a stronger economic union post-Covid?
Key quote: Inflation, even if only temporarily negative, remains subdued. And hence we will maintain our very accommodative monetary policy for as long as needed.
Rationale: Although the speaker acknowledges the need for long-term fiscal strategies and financial reforms, the emphasis is on maintaining accommodative monetary policy and being prepared to do more if necessary. This suggests a dovish stance, with some room for action if required, leaning towards holding current policy rates.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the EUROFI Forum 2020, Berlin, 11 September 2020.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: France and Germany facing European challenges in the crisis
Key quote: The ECB's monetary policy must continue to support economic activity, for the sake of its own mandate of price stability.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the need for continuing monetary support and addresses the deflationary pressures brought about by the crisis, indicating a dovish stance. Despite the dovish tone, the likelihood of any immediate rate cut is low given the policy rate is already at -0.5%, hence a 'Hold' prediction.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Berlin Academy, Berlin, 10 September 2020.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Presentation of the 2019 Annual Report of the ACPR
Key quote: Low rates, which are now likely to be with us for the long haul, place pressure on banks' and insurers' profitability.
Rationale: The speech acknowledges the challenges posed by low rates, while also emphasizing the need for rapid and powerful actions during the crisis. The supportive measures and easing regulations suggest a somewhat dovish stance, though the acknowledgment of banks' strengthened positions reduces the full dovish classification.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France and Chairman of the Autorité de contrôle prudentiel et de resolution (ACPR), at the press conference, Paris, 28 May 2020.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Monetary policy in the face of the Covid crisis
Key quote: We are ready to maintain very low interest rates and very abundant liquidity for as long as necessary.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes maintaining low interest rates and abundant liquidity to support the economy, a dovish stance. However, it also stresses the importance of price stability and independence. Given the negative policy rate and the need to support economic recovery during the pandemic, the most likely immediate action is to hold rates.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, to the Société d'économie politique, Paris, 25 May 2020.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: European solidarity put to the test by the health crisis
Key quote: In the present context, this mandate does not prevent action: in the very name of our mandate, we will probably have to do more, and maintain low interest rates and abundant liquidity for longer.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes maintaining low interest rates and abundant liquidity due to low inflation and a disinflationary shock, signaling a somewhat dovish stance. However, the emphasis on European policies and an accommodative monetary policy suggests that rates will likely be held stable in the short term.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the digital conference at the Bocconi University, Milan, 14 May 2020.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: From the emergency crisis response to initial thinking on the post-crisis environment
Key quote: This will thus mean that we not only have the possibility, but also the obligation to maintain very low interest rates and ample non-conventional instruments, including public and private sector purchase programmes, long into the future.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes maintaining low interest rates and ample non-conventional instruments to support the economy amidst the crisis, indicating a dovish stance. However, the governor does not explicitly advocate for further rate cuts, suggesting a 'Hold' prediction for the next meeting.
description: Hearing of Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, before the Section for the Economy and Finance of the French Economic, Social and Environmental Council, Paris, 8 April 2020.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: New Year wishes to the Paris financial centre
Key quote: Seen from today's perspective, like the markets do, it is [therefore] reasonable to expect that over the coming months our policies and interest rates will remain stable.
Rationale: The speech indicates an expectation of policy and interest rates remaining stable in the near future. There is no indication of a change in the policy rate, which suggests a neutral stance likely leading to a decision to hold rates.
description: New Year wishes to the Paris financial centre by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, Paris, 15 January 2020.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Low rates - what are the causes and what are the effects for France?
Key quote: To respect the mandate entrusted to us under the Treaties, one thing remains certain: in the face of the too-low level of inflation caused by the cooling of the economy since the end of 2018, it is our duty to maintain an accommodative monetary policy to support economic activity.
Rationale: The speech discusses the necessity of maintaining low interest rates to support economic activity, although it mentions that policy might stabilize if economic stabilization holds. This indicates a somewhat dovish stance, but also a readiness to hold rates steady if conditions allow.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Paris Dauphine University/House of Finance, Paris, 9 January 2020.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: European and French economic outlook and post-Brexit financial architecture
Key quote: Clearly, monetary policy will be all the more effective if it will no longer be the only game in town.
Rationale: The speech conveys a somewhat dovish stance by emphasizing the importance of fiscal policy to complement monetary policy, rather than relying solely on interest rates. He acknowledges the current low level of rates and suggests they are close to bottoming out, but stops short of advocating for further lowering, suggesting a hold in rates might be preferable while encouraging fiscal support.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the 2019 Paris Europlace International Financial Forum, Tokyo, 28 November 2019.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: The future of the European Economic and Monetary Union
Key quote: Given the recent slowdown in economic activity starting with Germany these low short-term rates must and will remain in place: it would undeniably be a mistake to raise ECB rates now.
Rationale: The speech indicates that the ECB will maintain low interest rates due to current economic conditions, aligning more with dovish than hawkish stances, but also emphasizes a desire for structural changes, suggesting some balance in the view.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Economy day 2019,Volksbanken and Raiffeisenbanken, Frankfurt am Main, 14 November 2019.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Insuring in the long term in a short-term world
Key quote: Given the context of prolonged uncertainty, we are compelled to pursue an accommodative monetary policy. It would go against all logic to raise interest rates now.
Rationale: The speech clearly supports maintaining low interest rates, describes the economic situation as requiring accommodative policy, and seems against raising rates under current circumstances.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France and Chairman of the Autorité de contrôle prudentiel et de resolution (ACPR), at the 11th International Insurance Conference, Paris, 25 October 2019.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Causes of and answers to the European slowdown
Key quote: We have to maintain an accommodative monetary policy in the face of the economic slowdown and low inflation.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the need for maintaining an accommodative monetary policy and suggests a reliance on fiscal measures to complement monetary efforts. The commitment to hold rates at their present levels or lower until inflation converges to target indicates a dovish stance, albeit not the most dovish possible, hence 'Somewhat dovish.' The pragmatic approach to the current monetary policy environment suggests holding rates steady, rather than cutting or raising.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the New York University, New York City, 16 October 2019.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Household expectations
Key quote: One important question for monetary policy is what kind of communication tools can be used to better communicate with the general public and influence their inflation expectations.
Rationale: While Villeroy de Galhau acknowledges the challenge posed by falling market-based inflation expectations, his emphasis on improving communication and understanding of household expectations rather than immediate policy action leans towards a somewhat dovish stance. Therefore, it's likely that he would support holding rates.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Joint Deutsche Bundesbank-Bank of France Conference on Household Expectations, Frankfurt am Main, 26 September 2019.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Current challenges of monetary policy
Key quote: Monetary policy has, once more, done its duty. It is now up to other policy makers to do theirs, starting with the fiscal authorities.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes that monetary policy has played its role and suggests a pause by not supporting further QE, pointing to the need for government fiscal action. While acknowledging the effectiveness of past policies, it signals caution against over-reliance on monetary tools, hence a somewhat dovish tone, suggesting a hold on immediate further easing.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Conference of the Chair Bank of France/Paris School of Economics, at the Paris School of Economics, Paris, 24 September 2019.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Presentation of the 2018 Annual Report of the ACPR
Key quote: The maintenance of a low interest rate environment is completely justified and necessary in light of the economic situation in the euro area.
Rationale: The speaker acknowledges the necessity of maintaining low interest rates to support the economy, reflecting a dovish stance. However, there is mention of concerns over bank profitability, which tempers the dovishness to some extent, leading to a 'somewhat dovish' classification.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France and Chairman of the Autorité de contrôle prudentiel et de resolution (ACPR), at the press conference, Paris, 28 May 2019.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: The euro area - staying the course through uncertainties
Key quote: As these deflationary risks have now receded, there is obviously no reason to go more negative on interest rates.
Rationale: The speech balances the recognition of past deflationary risks and their mitigation, while adopting a cautious and flexible approach to future uncertainties, indicating a neutral stance towards maintaining the current policy rate.
description: Introductory remarks by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Bank of France Symposium &amp; 34th SUERF Colloquium on the occasion of the 20th anniversary of the euro, Paris, 28 March 2019.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: The challenges of the euro area at the dawn of 2019
Key quote: In this context, I still believe that the gradual normalisation of our monetary policy is desirable.
Rationale: The speech by François Villeroy de Galhau focuses on a balanced view of potential temporary factors causing economic slowdown and flexibility in monetary policy guidance. While expressing readiness to adapt, he underscores the desirability of gradual monetary policy normalization, indicating a neutral stance with a tilt towards slight adjustment.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at a seminar at the Bank of Portugal, Lisbon, 22 February 2019.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: New Year wishes to the Paris financial centre
Key quote: In this environment, the normalisation of our monetary policy, which started with the successful termination of our net asset purchases in December, remains desirable.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the continuation of monetary policy normalization and acknowledges sound economic fundamentals, suggesting a mildly proactive stance but still advocating for gradualism due to uncertainties.
description: New Year wishes to the Paris financial centre by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, Paris, 16 January 2019.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Twenty years after the introduction of the euro, what are the economic prospects for Europe?
Key quote: Against this backdrop, I am convinced that the normalisation of our monetary policy - which has already begun - remains desirable. But it must be gradual, and consistent with the three principles that have sustained us for the past 20 years.
Rationale: The speech reflects a balanced view with a recognition of economic uncertainties and a gradual approach to policy normalization, indicating a neutral stance. Villeroy de Galhau emphasizes the need to keep options open, suggesting holding rates to maintain flexibility in the face of economic conditions.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at The Bridge Forum Dialogue conference, Luxembourg, 10 January 2019.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: What are the economic prospects for the euro area?
Key quote: The Governing Council takes its decisions collectively and independently, free from outside influence, and its position is clear: no country's national fiscal policy should influence our single monetary policy, either now or in the future.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the importance of price stability and maintaining focus on inflation targets, without indicating an immediate need to change interest rates either upwards or downwards. This suggests a neutral stance towards future monetary policy.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Conference at LUISS University, Rome, 29 November 2018.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Challenges and opportunities in Europe and beyond
Key quote: We are very clear about our objective - normalisation following non-standard policies - and about our sequence, but we should remain very pragmatic along our path.
Rationale: The speech indicates a gradual move towards policy normalization, with a plan to maintain current interest rate levels until at least the summer of 2019, indicating a somewhat hawkish stance due to the anticipation of future tightening.
description: Keynote address by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the 2018 Paris Europlace International Financial Forum, Tokyo, 19 November 2018.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Exiting unconventional monetary policies in an uncertain world
Key quote: We at the Governing Council are thus increasingly confident in the sustained adjustment in inflation back to our objective.
Rationale: While the speech highlights growing uncertainties, it also expresses confidence in inflation returning to target, indicating a preference for holding rates while maintaining flexibility to adjust as necessary.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Euro 50 - CF40 - CIGI Roundtable, Paris, 25 October 2018.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Monetary policy in the present environment - reconciling clarity and flexibility, as well as independence and cooperation
Key quote: We are increasingly confident in the sustained adjustment in inflation back to our objective, with our forecast for 1.7% in each of 2018, 2019 and 2020, vindicating our unanimous decision in June to pursue a course of gradual normalisation.
Rationale: The speech indicates confidence in the economic expansion and labor market improvements in the Euro area, with a gradual move towards policy normalisation. While uncertainties are recognized, the approach remains cautious and flexible, suggesting a 'hold' stance until more clarity is necessary around mid-2019.
description: Remarks by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Group of Thirty's annual International Banking Seminar, Bali, Indonesia, 14 October 2018.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Europe in a disruptive world
Key quote: The ECB Governing Council is now implementing its strategy of gradual and predictable normalisation.
Rationale: The speech indicates a movement towards the end of unconventional monetary policies with a possible interest rate rise in the future, signaling a somewhat hawkish stance. However, the lack of immediate action suggests that the policy rate will likely remain unchanged in the upcoming meeting.
description: Opening address by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Paris Europlace International Financial Forum, Paris, 11 July 2018.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Monetary policy making under uncertainty
Key quote: We have gone well beyond what people thought possible and we will do whatever is necessary to deliver on our price stability mandate - no more and no less.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the central bank's commitment to maintaining price stability and sticking to their mandate, highlighting the uncertainty of future economic conditions. The balanced approach suggests a neutral stance, indicating little inclination towards immediate rate changes.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Bank of France/Deutsche Bundesbank conference, Paris, 21 June 2018.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: A perspective on the ECB's Asset Purchase Programme
Key quote: We are not there yet, but we are more and more confident that the three criteria of this 'SAPI', namely convergence, confidence, and resilience, will be met.
Rationale: The speaker expresses confidence that the criteria for ending asset purchases will soon be met, but emphasizes patience and prudence in exiting policy measures, indicating a cautious approach to policy normalization.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the GIC Central Banking Series Conference, Paris, 14 May 2018.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Between "shadow" banking and an angelic vision of the market - towards a balanced development of non-bank finance
Key quote: So no irrational fears in the face of the shadows; but no angelic vision either.
Rationale: The speech discusses both opportunities and regulatory challenges of non-bank finance, advocating for balanced and appropriate regulatory measures without favoring any one sector over another.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the presentation of the 22nd Financial Stability Review, Paris, 25 April 2018.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Beyond Brexit, our common challenges and our common answers
Key quote: Financial stability is our common good, and we should also face a more subtle threat to it: debt complacency on a global level, in the context of accommodative monetary policies which will be less warranted in the near future.
Rationale: Despite discussing future threats and the potential for monetary policy to become less accommodative, the speech is balanced with an emphasis on stability and caution. There’s no strong push towards tightening or easing policy, suggesting a neutral stance and likelihood to hold rates.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the City Week 2018, London, 24 April 2018.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: The sustainability of European Monetary Union and institutional reform
Key quote: We confirmed last week our course of gradual normalisation, with the removal of the so-called 'easing bias' on the APP.
Rationale: The speaker emphasizes patience and a gradual normalisation of policy, suggesting a somewhat dovish stance. While acknowledging strong economic conditions, Villeroy de Galhau stresses the continuity of current policy and the importance of vigilance, indicating reluctance to change rates imminently.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at The ECB and Its Watchers XIX Conference, organised by the Institute for Monetary and Financial Stability, Frankfurt am Main, 14 March 2018.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: External imbalances - challenges and policy responses
Key quote: Speaking of the Governing Council of the ECB, let me say a few words on our monetary policy. It is following, with confidence and with patience, a path of gradual normalisation.
Rationale: Villeroy de Galhau discusses global imbalances and the importance of policy coordination, but makes it clear that the existing monetary policy is on a 'path of gradual normalisation', suggesting a neutral stance with a preference for holding rates unless there are significant changes in inflation outlook.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the "Financial Globalisation" conference, Central Bank of Ireland Symposium, Dublin, 2 February 2018.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: New Year wishes to the Paris financial centre
Key quote: This does not so much concern our monetary policy, which has entered a gradual normalisation phase, and which is a success; I will not discuss it further this evening during the 'silent period'.
Rationale: The speech highlights optimism in economic growth and reforms, but does not express a strong stance on altering the current monetary policy which is described as successful and in normalisation. The governor avoids discussing changes due to the 'silent period', suggesting a preference to maintain the status quo.
description: New Year wishes to the Paris financial centre by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, Paris, 18 January 2018.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: The challenges of the multilateral economic order - what European responses?
Key quote: The robust economic recovery in the euro-area now enables us to pursue a path of gradual normalisation of our monetary policy.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the importance of international cooperation, addresses risks like financial instability and protectionism, and mentions the path of gradual monetary policy normalization. However, there is no specific indication leaning towards an imminent rate change, suggesting a neutral stance.
description: Special lecture by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank, at the Waseda University, Tokyo, 4 December 2017.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Europe, France and the United Kingdom - facing our common economic challenges
Key quote: The ECB's accommodative monetary policy has contributed to this acceleration of growth in the euro area. Yet monetary policy cannot be the only game in town.
Rationale: The speech emphasized the need for structural reforms and long-term economic strategies while acknowledging monetary policy's role. However, it did not indicate any immediate change in the policy stance, suggesting a 'Hold' on rates.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank, at the Annual Financial Lunch of the French Chamber of Great Britain, London, 23 November 2017.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Economic Union, Financing Union, Banking Union
Key quote: Taking into account our progress, the Governing Council decided at the end of October to pursue a gradual normalisation.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes a path of gradual normalization of monetary policy without overburdening it and highlights various structural reforms rather than an immediate change in policy rates. This suggests a balanced, neutral stance likely leading to a hold on rates.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Annual General Meeting of the Foreign Bankers' Association, Amsterdam, 16 November 2017.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: The euro - which way to go?
Key quote: These forecasts, including a positive but still subdued inflation, confirm the adequacy of the gradual normalisation of our monetary policy we are engaged in.
Rationale: The speech discusses the gradual normalization of monetary policy in light of positive growth and subdued inflation, indicating a somewhat hawkish stance. However, due to the ongoing normalisation rather than immediate tightening, a hold on rates is the likely outcome.
description: Keynote speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the EconPol Europe (European Network for Economic and Fiscal Policy Research) Founding Conference and first Annual Meeting "The Euro - Which Way to Go?", Brussels, 9 November 2017.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Are the regulations implemented to guarantee financial stability compatible with the required acceleration in euro area growth?
Key quote: Financial stability is therefore a common good that needs to be guaranteed.
Rationale: The speech largely focuses on financial regulation and its impact on financial stability and economic growth, with a balanced view on the necessity of regulation and the need for implementation without impeding growth. There is no strong indication of advocating for immediate monetary policy changes, suggesting a neutral stance leaning towards maintaining the current rate.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Académie des sciences morales et politiques (Academy of Moral and Political Sciences), Paris, 6 November 2017.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Insurance in a world of disruption
Key quote: Yesterday, at the Governing Council presided by Mario Draghi, we took the important decision to reduce our net monthly asset purchases by half - to EUR 30 billion - until September 2018.
Rationale: The speech acknowledges a reduction in asset purchase, indicating confidence in economic recovery. The emphasis on gradual normalization suggests a somewhat hawkish stance, while still maintaining ample monetary support, which implies a likely decision to hold the rates in the near term.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the 9th International Insurance Conference, Paris, 27 October 2017.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: The euro area's monetary policy in the context of economic recovery
Key quote: We have to reduce the intensity of our net asset purchases, while maintaining overall a substantially accommodative monetary policy.
Rationale: The speech acknowledges the start of monetary policy normalization due to economic recovery and progress towards the inflation target but also emphasizes maintaining a substantial degree of monetary accommodation, suggesting a somewhat hawkish stance with a focus on gradual adjustment.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, for the public lecture "The euro area's monetary policy in the context of economic recovery" at the Central Bank of the Republic of Austria, Vienna, 6 October 2017.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: With economic recovery underway in Europe, what monetary policy?
Key quote: We have to reduce the intensity of our net asset purchases, while maintaining overall a substantially accommodative monetary policy.
Rationale: The speech acknowledges economic recovery but emphasizes that inflation is still below the target, with a focus on maintaining accommodative policy. This indicates a cautious approach towards tightening, suggesting a hold on rates.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at a lunch-debate at the Centre des Professions Financières, Paris, 28 September 2017.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: The future of the euro area - from the "impossible trinity" to the "growth triangle"
Key quote: Our responsibility as the Eurosystem is to deliver a monetary policy that is in line with the mandate entrusted to us, and to make proposals for improving the efficiency of other economic policies.
Rationale: The speech primarily focuses on the need for structural reforms within the European Union and economic policy coordination rather than altering monetary policy through interest rate changes. Therefore, the stance is neutral towards immediate monetary policy action.
description: Text of the 6th Annual Tommaso Padoa-Schioppa Lecture by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the 6th Annual Tommaso Padoa-Schioppa Brussels Economic Forum 2017, Brussels, 1 June 2017.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Ensuring confidence in the currency
Key quote: Today, the euro is alive and well. It is the currency of 340 million Europeans, is recognised worldwide and is trusted by the people of France.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes confidence in the euro and the benefits of current monetary stability, indicating a preference for continuation of existing policies rather than adopting changes that could be considered more aggressive or hawkish.
description: Introduction by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the conference on "Recent monetary policy developments", Paris, 4 May 2017.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: European Central Bank monetary policy and the resilience of the eurozone
Key quote: Our current monetary policy stance remains fully appropriate based on current information, as Mario Draghi has stressed, and should not be adjusted before we see more concrete signs that inflation can be sustained at levels closer to our target.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes that the current monetary policy is appropriate and does not need changing until inflation shows sustained improvement, indicating a cautious and somewhat dovish stance.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at Columbia University, New York City, 19 April 2017.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: The future of the finance industry - between austerity and innovation
Key quote: At this stage, the answer is clearly no. Without monetary stimulus, the recovery in inflation would not yet be self-sustained or durable throughout the euro area.
Rationale: The speaker acknowledges the progress made in economic recovery and inflation increase but highlights that the conditions for a self-sustained recovery are not yet in place, suggesting that maintaining the current policy stance is appropriate, which aligns with a neutral position.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Süddeutsche Zeitung Finance Day 2017, Frankfurt am Main, 22 March 2017.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: The euro - 25th anniversary of the Maastricht Treaty
Key quote: As of 2013, inflation has even been too low in the euro area, and this is why the ECB has been successfully conducting an active monetary policy since 2014.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes maintaining price stability and acknowledges recent deflationary pressures, which have led to an active monetary policy by the ECB. The focus is on stability and supporting growth, suggesting a dovish stance, but not aggressively so, hence 'somewhat dovish'. The likelihood of holding rates is based on the need to maintain current supportive measures.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Osservatorio Permanente Giovani-Editori, Florence, 7 February 2017.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Euro area monetary policy and businesses
Key quote: It is not our aim to keep interest rates low for too long: low interest rates are not a goal in themselves; they are merely the necessary condition today for gradually returning towards our inflation target.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the achievements of current monetary policies in preventing deflation and indicates a willingness to stay the course until target inflation is achieved, which suggests a somewhat dovish stance. However, it also recognizes the limitations and the eventual end of current policies, suggesting no immediate further easing. Thus, holding rates would be the expected action.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Vereinigung der Bayerischen Wirtschaft, Munich, 26 January 2017.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Prospects, challenges and promises -  New Year wishes to the Paris financial centre
Key quote: But in a world of uncertainty, European monetary policy is a very valuable source of predictability: our decision of 8 December 2016 clarified financing prospects for economic players over the next twelve months.
Rationale: The speech acknowledges economic uncertainties but highlights stability in the euro area, a gradual rise in inflation, and ongoing monetary policy, suggesting a balanced view without leaning towards rate changes.
description: New Year wishes to the Paris financial centre by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, 12 January 2017.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Recent European economic challenges
Key quote: But I can emphasize that, in response to weak inflation and heightened uncertainties, the Eurosystem, of which the Banque de France is a member, has acted decisively.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes existing positive developments in the economy, like recovery and improvements in labor markets, without indicating a significant shift in monetary policy stance. Given the policy rate of -0.4% and the acknowledgment of recent actions taken, the speech suggests maintaining current policy settings.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Paris Europlace International Financial Forum, Tokyo, 5 December 2016.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Europe facing a new political economy
Key quote: I am fully confident that in our next monetary meetings, in the coming months, we will decide, in a pragmatic approach, about the best evolution after March of all our available tools: QE, TLTRO and forward guidance on interest rates.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the need to continue current monetary policies without significant changes until more data is available. The encouragement of continued vigilance suggests no immediate significant shift in monetary policy, implying a stance to 'Hold' rates at the next meeting.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Asociación de Mercados Financieros Annual Financial Convention, Madrid, 21 November 2016.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Savings glut, or investment deficit?
Key quote: Monetary policy is active and efficient; but it cannot remain the only game in town.
Rationale: The speech discusses the need for both economic and financial strategies to address investment deficits, points out that monetary policy cannot be the sole solution, and calls for structural reforms. This suggests a neutral stance, as there is no direct advocacy for immediate monetary policy action such as cutting or raising rates.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at  The future of savingsŽ conference, Paris, 4 November 2016.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: The future of Europe - a central banker's view
Key quote: In a world of uncertainty, European monetary policy is today a yardstick of stability.
Rationale: The speech highlights the effectiveness of the European Central Bank's current monetary policy in aiding economic recovery and boosting inflation. However, it stops short of suggesting further expansionary measures. Instead, it underlines the need for complementary fiscal and economic policies, indicating a preference to maintain the status quo rather than make immediate changes to the policy rate.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, before the Hearing of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the European Parliament, Brussels, 28 September 2016.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Low interest rates and the implications for financial stability
Key quote: The ECB was clear in saying that policy rates would remain at current levels or lower for the necessary period of time.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the accommodative stance of monetary policy and the intention to keep rates low to address low inflation, suggesting a dovish stance. The prediction is to 'Hold' given the existing negative policy rate and the focus on sustaining current levels until inflation rises.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the first annual conference of the ESRB, Frankfurt am Main, 23 September 2016.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Addressing Brexit, and unlocking Europe's investment potential
Key quote: Low interest rates are not the disease, but the symptom of an imbalance between savings and investment; and low interest rates are probably an opportunity to speed up the cure towards productive investment.
Rationale: The speech focuses on addressing the fallout of Brexit and boosting investment without signaling any immediate change in monetary policy stance. Despite uncertainties, it indicates confidence in current projections and stability, suggestive of a neutral stance.
description: Welcome address by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Paris Europlace International Financial Forum, Paris, 6 July 2016.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Europe at a crossroads - how to improve economic governance and growth performance of the Eurozone?
Key quote: Monetary policy cannot be the only game in town.
Rationale: The speech highlights the limitations of monetary policy and stresses the importance of economic governance and fiscal coordination in the Eurozone. The speaker acknowledges that monetary policy has been accommodative with QE and low rates, suggesting a reluctance to tighten policy without broader economic reforms, hence a 'Hold' prediction at the next meeting.
description: Presentation by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the German Institute for Economic Research - DIW Berlin, Berlin, 8 June 2016.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Central bank role to support a strong and sustainable growth in the medium and long term
Key quote: Our monetary policy accommodation has made the cost of investment considerably cheaper but its effectiveness is blunted somewhat if entrepreneurs feel constrained by structural impediments and a lack of economic reform.
Rationale: The speech highlights the importance of accommodative monetary policies and structural reforms to support growth, while acknowledging the significant measures already taken by the ECB. It suggests a somewhat dovish stance, advocating for maintaining current policies rather than easing or tightening monetary conditions.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the global economic symposium "Reigniting Global Growth: Headwinds and Tailwinds", co-hosted by The National Association for Business Economics (NABE) and the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), Paris, 23 May 2016.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Numerous challenges for the international monetary system
Key quote: We will look closely at these financial conditions in the future and if needed, we could act further.
Rationale: The emphasis on potential for further action if needed, along with the recognition of current challenges, suggests a bias towards ensuring supportive monetary conditions. However, there is no immediate suggestion of easing, resulting in a 'Somewhat dovish' stance.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the High Level Seminar on International Financial Architecture, Paris, 31 March 2016.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Present challenges for France's central bank
Key quote: The Eurosystem is determined to fight the low inflation that we are facing today and thus underpin economic activity.
Rationale: The speech highlights the commitment to fight low inflation and supports measures to bolster economic activity. While the tone is supportive of current easing measures, it does not indicate an immediate need for further rate cuts, implying a dovish stance with a probable preference to hold rates.
description: Hearing of Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, by the Senate Finance Committee, Paris, 30 March 2016.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: The role of monetary policy
Key quote: Monetary policy is doing a great deal to counter weak inflation and support economic activity - it is our duty and we will continue to do so with steadfast resolve.
Rationale: The speech acknowledges the challenges posed by persistently low inflation and expresses a commitment to maintaining highly accommodative monetary policy to counter these pressures and support economic activity. There is no indication towards tightening policy; on the contrary, the speaker emphasizes readiness to continue and even extend current measures, suggesting a dovish stance.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Global Interdependence Center - Central Banking Series "Inflation expectations, implications and policy response in a new paradigm for commodities", Session I "Central bankers outlook", Paris, 21 March 2016.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: What can monetary policy do?
Key quote: Monetary policy is thus doing a great deal to counter weak inflation and support economic activity - it is our duty and we will continue to do so with steadfast resolve.
Rationale: The speech indicates a strong focus on using monetary policy tools to address low inflation and deflationary risks, suggesting a preference to maintain or lower rates to support economic activity. Despite acknowledging some risks, the emphasis on accommodative measures implies dovishness.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the House of Finance Days of Paris-Dauphine University, Paris, 14 March 2016.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Identifying various forms of savings in France
Key quote: The question is even more relevant in light of our current financial and monetary policy stance: interest rates are low and are likely to remain so for a significant length of time.
Rationale: The speech indicates an acceptance of the low interest rate environment and a focus on adapting savings behavior to it, which suggests a dovish stance. However, it doesn't explicitly push for further rate cuts, hence a 'Hold' is likely for the next meeting.
description: Speech by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the 25th Parliamentary Conference on Savings, Paris, 2 February 2016.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Challenges for France's economy and financial sector in 2016
Key quote: Monetary policy is proving to be effective: in 18 months, since June 2014 and the announcement of non-standard policies, bank lending rates to business have fallen by around 80 basis points in the euro area.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the effectiveness of current monetary policy and highlights a moderate economic recovery. The governor does not call for further easing or tightening, indicating a neutral stance and likely preference for holding rates in the near term.
description: New Year Address by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, Paris, 18 January 2016.

author: François Villeroy de Galhau
title: Ultra-low interest rates and challenges for central banks
Key quote: CBs' mandates push them to avoid the risks of the first type, related to inaction, rather than those of the second type, related to pro-action; in other words, be ready to risk doing too much rather than too little.
Rationale: The speech discusses the necessity of continued accommodative monetary policy and the possible use of non-conventional measures alongside maintaining low interest rates, indicating a dovish stance but with some caution about being overly accommodative.
description: Welcome address by Mr François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of the Bank of France, at the Farewell Symposium for Honorary Governor Christian Noyer, held by the Bank of France and the Bank for International Settlements, Paris, 12 January 2016.

author: Joachim Nagel
title: Current monetary policy topics
Key quote: It is important for me to see inflation stable at the 2% target as soon as possible. To get there, we will not pre-commit to any path in our decisions going forward.
Rationale: The speech highlights ongoing inflation pressures and the need for monetary policy to remain tight, but also acknowledges signs of progress in achieving price stability. This points towards maintaining the current policy stance while being open to adjustments based on incoming data.
description: Speech by Dr Joachim Nagel, President of the Deutsche Bundesbank, at the Commerzbank AG event "Geldpolitik in Zeiten der Inflation", Frankfurt am Main, 18 September 2024.

author: Joachim Nagel
title: What can we learn from the recent disinflation episode?
Key quote: Therefore, we need to be careful and must not lower policy rates too quickly.
Rationale: Nagel acknowledges the progress in reducing inflation but stresses caution in monetary policy adjustments, indicating a somewhat hawkish stance with a likelihood to hold rates steady at the next meeting.
description: Dinner speech by Dr Joachim Nagel, President of the Deutsche Bundesbank, at the Central Bank Research Association (CEBRA) Annual Conference, Frankfurt am Main, 29 August 2024.

author: Joachim Nagel
title: Speech delivered at the change of office ceremony at the Regional Office in Saxony and Thuringia
Key quote: Given the big picture, which I have only briefly outlined here, the Governing Council of the ECB lowered the key ECB interest rates last Thursday.
Rationale: The speaker acknowledges the recent key interest rate cut and emphasizes the need for caution amid economic uncertainty. This suggests a moderate stance without clear push toward further easing or tightening, indicating a likely 'Hold' in future rate decisions.
description: Speech by Dr Joachim Nagel, President of the Deutsche Bundesbank, at the change of office ceremony at the Regional Office in Saxony and Thuringia, Leipzig, 10 June 2024.

author: Joachim Nagel
title: Too low, too high - what's next for inflation?
Key quote: But if there is more price pressure in the medium-term, we must take action against it.
Rationale: Dr. Nagel highlights potential structural factors that may lead to increased inflationary pressures and the need for vigilance to prevent inflation expectations from becoming de-anchored. His focus on possibly needing to counteract future price pressures suggests a somewhat hawkish stance.
description: Speech (virtual) by Dr Joachim Nagel, President of the Deutsche Bundesbank, at the Joint Spring Conference 2024 "Structural Changes and the Implications for Inflation", Eltville am Rhein, 7 May 2024.

author: Joachim Nagel
title: Central bank money in the 21st century
Key quote: If they help to increase our confidence in a timely and sustained return to 2 percent, I would be in favour of a rate cut in June.
Rationale: Dr. Nagel acknowledges the progress in reducing inflation, yet remains cautious about declaring victory as risks still persist. Although he suggests a possibility for a future rate cut, it is contingent on further economic data and assurance of sustained inflation targets, indicating a somewhat dovish stance but without commitment to immediate action.
description: Speech by Dr Joachim Nagel, President of the Deutsche Bundesbank, at the DZ Bank Capital Markets Conference 2024, Berlin, 24 April 2024.

author: Joachim Nagel
title: Presentation of the Deutsche Bundesbank's Annual Report 2023
Key quote: Even though it may be very tempting, it is too early to cut interest rates.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes progress toward price stability but notes that the target has not yet been fully met. The speaker suggests that it is too early to cut rates, indicating a balanced view, hence 'Neutral'.
description: Introductory statement by Dr Joachim Nagel, President of the Deutsche Bundesbank, at the press conference presenting the Annual Report 2023, Frankfurt am Main, 23 February 2024.

author: Joachim Nagel
title: Inflation tide after peak - what next?
Key quote: It is my conviction that we must not loosen policy until we are certain of returning to price stability on a lasting basis.
Rationale: Dr. Joachim Nagel emphasizes the necessity of maintaining current restrictive monetary policy to ensure inflation returns to target, and he explicitly states it would be premature to lower rates. This indicates a hawkish stance focused on sustaining the fight against inflation, suggesting the likelihood of holding rates steady rather than cutting them.
description: Speech by Dr Joachim Nagel, President of the Deutsche Bundesbank, at the Central Bank of Cyprus, Nicosia, 28 November 2023.

author: Joachim Nagel
title: Monetary policy in challenging times
Key quote: Premature easing would jeopardise the timely return of inflation to our target of 2%.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the ongoing battle against inflation and the risk of easing monetary policy too soon, highlighting the need for patience in ensuring inflation is firmly on track to target. This indicates a somewhat hawkish stance, with a likely vote to hold rates at current levels until there is greater confidence in achieving price stability.
description: Introductory remarks by Dr Joachim Nagel, President of the Deutsche Bundesbank, at the Forum Analysis, Milan, 23 November 2023.

author: Joachim Nagel
title: Are we there yet?
Key quote: Against this backdrop, it would be unwise to start cutting interest rates too soon.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the need to maintain high interest rates to ensure a return to the 2% inflation target and explicitly mentions that it is too early to declare victory over inflation. It suggests patience and a continued high rate policy, indicating a somewhat hawkish stance but not advocating for further immediate rate hikes.
description: Keynote speech by Dr Joachim Nagel, President of the Deutsche Bundesbank, at the 33rd Frankfurt European Banking Congress, Frankfurt am Main, 17 November 2023.

author: Joachim Nagel
title: Fiscal policy challenges in a high inflation environment
Key quote: To do this, we will need to keep key interest rates high enough for long enough.
Rationale: Dr. Joachim Nagel emphasizes the importance of maintaining high interest rates to ensure price stability amidst high inflation. However, he stops short of indicating an immediate need to raise rates further, suggesting a holding pattern unless inflation does not decrease according to forecasts.
description: Speech by Dr Joachim Nagel, President of the Deutsche Bundesbank, at the Forum Finanzpolitik und Steuerrecht, Baden-Baden, 10 November 2023.

author: Joachim Nagel
title: Maintaining price stability – the role of the Eurosystem and other economic agents
Key quote: We will stay the course. I am firmly convinced and personally committed: The Eurosystem will ensure that inflation returns to our 2% target.
Rationale: Joachim Nagel emphasizes the importance of maintaining price stability and indicates a commitment to the current monetary policy strategy to curb inflation, suggesting a preference for continued tight monetary policy. However, the decision to hold rates at the last meeting suggests stability over further immediate tightening.
description: Speech by Dr Joachim Nagel, President of the Deutsche Bundesbank, at the European Economic and Financial Centre, London, 8 November 2023.

author: Joachim Nagel
title: Trade challenges in a changing world
Key quote: Nevertheless, inflation rates in the euro area are still too high. And they have been too high for too long.
Rationale: Although Dr. Nagel notes that the ECB has achieved a significant degree of tightening, he emphasizes that inflation remains above target and suggests vigilance, indicating a somewhat hawkish stance. However, the recent decision to leave rates unchanged points to a probable 'Hold' in the upcoming meeting.
description: Speech by Dr Joachim Nagel, President of the Deutsche Bundesbank, at the German-British Chamber of Industry & Commerce, London, 7 November 2023.

author: Joachim Nagel
title: Is it time for a prosperity update? - Productivity, competition and stable money in the digital age
Key quote: Our tight monetary policy is yielding results, but we must not ease up too soon.
Rationale: The speaker emphasizes the need to maintain high interest rates to ensure inflation returns to target, indicating a somewhat hawkish stance but given the recent hold, suggests a 'Hold' prediction for the next meeting.
description: Ludwig Erhard Lecture by Dr Joachim Nagel, President of the Deutsche Bundesbank, organised by the Initiative New Social Market Economy (INSM), Berlin, 31 October 2023.

author: Joachim Nagel
title: Germany - generally healthy, but facing challenges
Key quote: However, inflation remains high. Along with uncertainty. On the Governing Council of the ECB, we discuss and assess developments in economic activity and the inflation outlook. The decisions we take there are data-dependent.
Rationale: While Dr. Nagel acknowledges that inflation has fallen since its peak, he also points out that uncertainty remains high and monetary policy decisions will remain data-dependent. This suggests a balanced view, leaning neither towards immediate tightening nor easing, and indicates a likelihood to hold rates steady pending further economic data.
description: Keynote speech by Dr Joachim Nagel, President of the Deutsche Bundesbank, at the Capital City Reception, Berlin, 17 October 2023.

author: Joachim Nagel
title: How is the economy developing – and what is monetary policy doing to overcome the high inflation?
Key quote: We need to continue until our engine has cooled down not just on the surface, but also at its core.
Rationale: Dr. Nagel's speech emphasizes the need for continued monetary policy tightening to address persistent high core inflation, suggesting further interest rate hikes are likely.
description: Speech by Dr Joachim Nagel, President of the Deutsche Bundesbank, at the "DEKRA Dialog", Stuttgart, 6 July 2023.

author: Joachim Nagel
title: Banking supervision in dialogue
Key quote: As things stand, interest rates will need to rise further.
Rationale: The speech clearly indicates a belief that interest rates need to continue to rise to combat inflation, even though the exact future path is uncertain. This suggests a strong hawkish stance likely to lead to a vote for raising rates.
description: Introductory remarks by Dr Joachim Nagel, President of the Deutsche Bundesbank, at the Deutsche Bundesbank symposium "Banking supervision in dialogue", Frankfurt am Main, 5 July 2023.

author: Joachim Nagel
title: Welcoming speech – Lithuanian evening
Key quote: We will do what is necessary to bring it back to 2%.
Rationale: Dr. Joachim Nagel's speech highlights the central bank's commitment to fighting inflation and achieving price stability, suggesting a steady stance on monetary policy. The speech does not indicate any imminent change in the policy rate, thus suggesting a 'Hold' prediction.
description: Welcoming speech by Dr Joachim Nagel, President of the Deutsche Bundesbank, at the Lithuanian evening, Frankfurt am Main, 4 July 2023.

author: Joachim Nagel
title: Challenges for monetary policy
Key quote: It is crucial that we bring inflation back down to 2% in a sustainable manner. To achieve that, interest rates will have to be at levels that are sufficiently restrictive.
Rationale: Dr. Joachim Nagel expressed concern over the persistent high inflation and emphasized the need for continued restrictive monetary policy. He supported further interest rate hikes, indicating a hawkish stance towards managing inflation.
description: Introductory remarks by Dr Joachim Nagel, President of the Deutsche Bundesbank, at the Frankfurt Euro Finance Summit, Frankfurt am Main, 3 July 2023.

author: Joachim Nagel
title: Anchoring monetary stability in people's minds
Key quote: I do not think this is high enough yet. As I have already mentioned, the extent to which interest rates will actually have to rise will depend on the incoming data.
Rationale: The speaker emphasizes the need to raise key interest rates to convince markets and the public of their commitment to fighting inflation. Dr. Nagel's discussion points towards further tightening monetary policy to achieve price stability, suggesting he would support raising rates.
description: Speech by Dr Joachim Nagel, President of the Deutsche Bundesbank, at the conference marking the tenth anniversary of the Alliance for Monetary and Financial Stability (Aktionskreis Stabiles Geld), Frankfurt am Main, 22 June 2023.

author: Joachim Nagel
title: The macroeconomic outlook - growth, inflation, and risks
Key quote: We may need to keep raising rates after the summer break.
Rationale: The speaker indicates a need for further rate hikes, emphasizing the need to bring inflation down to target levels. This suggests a hawkish stance on monetary policy.
description: Introductory statement by Dr Joachim Nagel, President of the Deutsche Bundesbank, at the 89th Plenary meeting of the Group of Thirty, Amsterdam, 16 June 2023.

author: Joachim Nagel
title: Is Germany's "business model" at risk?
Key quote: Monetary policymakers therefore cannot and will not falter in the fight against inflation. We need to be even more stubborn than the current rate of inflation.
Rationale: Dr. Joachim Nagel emphasizes the need for further interest rate hikes and maintaining high rates to combat inflation, which indicates a very hawkish stance on monetary policy. The focus on fighting inflation and the mention of several interest rate steps suggest a strong inclination to raise rates in upcoming meetings.
