Key quote: We therefore remain committed to preserving the very substantial amount of monetary support that is embedded in our staff projections and that - barring a fundamental change in sentiment and in the underlying momentum driving the recovery - remains necessary to secure a return of inflation to levels below, but close to, 2% over the medium term.
Rationale: The speech acknowledges modest economic recovery and the effectiveness of accommodative monetary policy but highlights low inflation and the dependency on current monetary support, suggesting a need to maintain the current policy stance.
description: Remarks by Mr Peter Praet, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Morgan Stanley Roundtable "What next for Europe", Washington DC, 6 October 2016.

author: Peter Praet
title: Monetary policy and the euro area banking system
Key quote: Monetary policy will continue its accommodative stance until inflation returns to our aim, which will remove some of the cyclical drivers of weak profitability linked to disappointing nominal growth.
Rationale: The speech indicates a commitment to maintaining accommodative monetary policy for an extended period due to low inflation and ongoing challenges in the banking sector. This is a somewhat dovish stance, suggesting interest rates will remain low, but not necessarily indicative of further cuts. The focus is more on holding rates steady to support recovery.
description: Speech by Mr Peter Praet, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the VII Financial Forum, organised by Expansión and KPMG, Madrid, 4 October 2016.

author: Peter Praet
title: Interview in L'Opinion
Key quote: Our monetary policy has been extremely accommodative since spring 2014... We will maintain the very substantial amount of monetary support necessary to fulfil our mandate.
Rationale: The speech indicates a commitment to continuing accommodative monetary policies to support growth and inflation, suggesting dovishness. However, some acknowledgment of problematic external imbalances shows a slight shift towards caution, thus a 'somewhat dovish' label. The stance suggests a hold on rates with a moderate probability.
description: Interview with Mr Peter Praet, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in L'Opinion, conducted by Mr Luc de Barochez on 15 September 2016, and published on 20 September 2016.

author: Peter Praet
title: Remarks at the BNYM 20th anniversary dinner on the dynamics of TARGET2 balances and monetary policy implementation
Key quote: At its last meeting, the Governing Council underlined the need to preserve the very substantial amount of monetary support that is necessary in order to secure a return of inflation rates towards levels that are below, but close to, 2%.
Rationale: The speaker emphasizes the necessity of maintaining significant monetary support, indicating a dovish stance. However, there is an expectation to continue current accommodative policies rather than implement new easing measures, leading to a 'Hold' prediction.
description: Dinner address by Mr Peter Praet, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the BNYM 20th anniversary, Brussels, 15 September 2016.

author: Peter Praet
title: Financial cycles and monetary policy
Key quote: Today our leaning-against-the-wind orientation clearly backs our prevailing accommodative monetary policy stance.
Rationale: Peter Praet acknowledges the role of monetary policy in supporting the economy and stabilizing prices, while stressing the importance of maintaining accommodative policies to support financial stability. His focus on the ECB's accommodative stance and the role of other policy tools suggests that the ECB is not leaning towards tightening policy imminently.
description: Speech by Mr Peter Praet, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in the context of a panel on "International Monetary Policy", Beijing, 31 August 2016.

author: Peter Praet
title: Transmission channels of monetary policy in the current environment
Key quote: We expect our policy rates to remain at present or lower levels for an extended period of time.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the need for prolonged accommodative monetary policy, with record low rates and further rate cuts possible. It highlights the benefits of the current policy and expresses concerns about uncertainties that could hinder economic recovery.
description: Speech by Mr Peter Praet, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Financial Times Festival of Finance, London, 1 July 2016.

author: Peter Praet
title: Interview in Público
Key quote: In our guidance on interest rates we have said that rates will remain at present or lower levels.
Rationale: Peter Praet highlights the continued risk of low inflation and stresses the importance of the ECB's actions to prevent deflation, emphasizing the tools and measures still in use and prepared as needed. This overall indicates a somewhat dovish stance, yet with an inclination not to cut rates further immediately.
description: Interview with Mr Peter Praet, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in Público, conducted by Mr Sérgio Anibal, published on 23 May 2016.

author: Peter Praet
title: Interview in Expansión
Key quote: But deploying negative rates again in the future would require a distinct worsening of the inflation outlook.
Rationale: Peter Praet indicates that negative rates have been effective so far but cannot be lowered indefinitely. He highlights that interest rates remain a tool if needed, but suggests no worsening conditions necessitating immediate action, which points to maintaining the current policy stance.
description: Interview with Mr Peter Praet, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in Expansión, conducted by Mr Daniel Badía González and Mr Agustín Monzón Peña on 25 April 2016 and published on 29 April 2016.

author: Peter Praet
title: The European Central Bank's monetary policy response to disinflationary pressures
Key quote: If further adverse shocks were to materialise, our measures could be recalibrated once more commensurate with the strength of the headwind.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the actions taken to expand monetary policy in response to disinflationary pressures, indicating a dovish stance. Despite acknowledging the lack of significant inflation recovery, the speaker stresses continued accommodation and the possibility of further easing, pointing to a preference for maintaining or lowering rates to support the economy.
description: Speech by Mr Peter Praet, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the conference "The ECB and Its Watchers XVII", organised by the Center for Financial Studies, Frankfurt am Main, 7 April 2016.

author: Peter Praet
title: The European Central Bank's fight against low inflation - reasons and consequences
Key quote: The prolonged period of low inflation we are in today has increased the risks that inflation misses might become persistent, which would be deeply damaging for the economy.
Rationale: Peter Praet emphasizes the threat of persistently low inflation and the ECB's commitment to using accommodative monetary policy to address it. He argues for the necessity of unconventional tools to prevent inflation expectations from de-anchoring, indicating a dovish stance focused on addressing low inflation and avoiding deflationary risks.
description: Speech by Mr Peter Praet, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at Luiss School of European Political Economy, Rome, 4 April 2016.

author: Peter Praet
title: Interview in La Repubblica
Key quote: If new negative shocks should worsen the outlook or if financing conditions should not adjust in the direction and to the extent that is necessary to boost the economy and inflation, a rate reduction remains in our armoury.
Rationale: Peter Praet emphasizes a strong accommodative stance with the possibility of using further tools if needed. However, given the recent measures, a hold on rate changes is likely until the effects are further observed.
description: Interview with Mr Peter Praet, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in La Repubblica, conducted by Mr Ferdinando Giugliano and Ms Tonia Mastrobuoni on 15 March 2016 and published on 18 March 2016.

author: Peter Praet
title: The European Central Bank and its role as lender of last resort during the crisis
Key quote: Inducing banks to arrest and reverse asset redemptions and keep credit flowing to the real economy became our policy priority.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the ECB's focus on providing liquidity and stability rather than tightening monetary policy, indicating a dovish stance. However, given the complex economic conditions and ongoing recovery efforts, a 'hold' on rates is more likely to maintain current monetary support.
description: Speech by Mr Peter Praet, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at "The Lender of Last Resort: An International Perspective", a conference sponsored by the Committee on Capital Markets Regulation, Washington DC, 10 February 2016.

author: Peter Praet
title: Interview in NRC Handelsblad
Key quote: The economic recovery is still vulnerable; it is cyclical and not genuinely structural. New risks have arisen, such as the growth slowdown in emerging countries. And inflation expectations are still markedly disappointing.
Rationale: Peter Praet expresses concern over the cyclical and vulnerable nature of the economic recovery, mentions new risks, and refers to disappointing inflation expectations, all signs leaning towards dovishness. However, there is no definitive statement indicating an immediate rate cut, making a 'Hold' prediction more likely.
description: Interview with Mr Peter Praet, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in NRC Handelsblad, conducted by Mr Mark Beunderman and published on 30 January 2016.

author: Peter Praet
title: The ECB's monetary policy - back to medium-term price stability of below, but close to, 2%
Key quote: Too low inflation is damaging in the long term and deflation is dangerous.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the dangers of low inflation and deflation, highlights effective dovish measures like APP expansion and negative rates, but does not explicitly call for further cuts, aligning with a dovish stance and likely a decision to hold rates at the next meeting.
description: Opinion piece by Mr Peter Praet, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, published in Süddeutsche Zeitung, 13 January 2016.

author: Peter Praet
title: Interview in Knack
Key quote: The ECB will continue pursuing its policy for as long as necessary.
Rationale: The speech indicates that the ECB is committed to maintaining its current policy to achieve its inflation target, acknowledging that inflation remains low and that exceptional policy is necessary. However, it balances this with recognition of risks and unintended consequences, suggesting a somewhat dovish stance aiming to maintain, rather than further ease, policies unless conditions change significantly.
description: Interview with Mr Peter Praet, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in Knack, conducted by Mr Ewald Pironet and published on 6 January 2016.

author: Yves Mersch
title: Legal aspects of the European Central Bank's response to the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic - an exclusive but narrow competence
Key quote: Our crisis measures must be temporary and targeted. They are justified only in the light of the exceptional circumstances seen during the pandemic.
Rationale: The speech discusses the ECB's extensive measures in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, including liquidity provisions and asset purchase programs, emphasizing their temporary and targeted nature. While these actions are typically associated with a dovish stance, the focus on their temporary nature suggests a less aggressive commitment to easing, hence a 'somewhat dovish' label and a likely 'Hold' prediction on rates.
description: Keynote speech by Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank and Vice-Chair of the Supervisory Board of the European Central Bank, at the ESCB Legal Conference, Frankfurt am Main, 2 November 2020.

author: Yves Mersch
title: The European Central Bank's monetary policy amid the pandemic
Key quote: The Governing Council continues to stand ready to adjust all of its instruments, as appropriate, to ensure that inflation moves towards its aim in a timely and sustained manner.
Rationale: Given the context of the pandemic and the ECB's tools being aimed at maintaining price stability, combined with statements about being ready to adjust instruments as needed, the overall message is dovish. The emphasis on needing continued fiscal support and the readiness to adjust tools suggests a holding stance, with a higher probability leaning towards maintaining the current course.
description: Introductory remarks by Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank and Vice-Chair of the Supervisory Board of the European Central Bank, at the MNI Connect Roundtable, 19 October 2020.

author: Yves Mersch
title: European economic governance - early lessons from the crisis
Key quote: The ECB has taken far-reaching exceptional monetary policy decisions.
Rationale: The speech highlights both the substantial monetary support provided by the ECB and the importance of coordination at the EU level but does not indicate a clear inclination towards altering interest rates.
description: Keynote speech by Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank and Vice-Chair of the Supervisory Board of the European Central Bank, at the Conference "The Werner Report, 50 Years on", organised by the Luxembourg Centre for Contemporary and Digital History in cooperation with EUI, 8 October, 2020.

author: Yves Mersch
title: In the spirit of European cooperation
Key quote: I see no obstacle to the Bundesbank continuing its purchases under the PSPP after 5 August.
Rationale: The speech focuses on the legal context and cooperation, not potential changes to policy settings. Mersch expresses confidence in ongoing operations like the PSPP, suggesting no immediate shift in direction.
description: Introductory remarks by Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank and Vice-Chair of the Supervisory Board of the European Central Bank, at the Salzburg Global webinar, 2 July 2020.

author: Yves Mersch
title: The world economy transformed
Key quote: The ECB's immediate response to the coronavirus (COVID-19) shock was crucial in maintaining market functioning and the monetary policy transmission mechanism.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the sustained supportive role of monetary policy due to the uncertainty induced by the pandemic, showing a dovish outlook but not suggesting further immediate easing, which points towards maintaining rather than cutting rates.
description: Remarks by Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank and Vice-Chair of the Supervisory Board of the European Central Bank, at the Reinventing Bretton Woods Committee Webinar Series, 25 June 2020.

author: Yves Mersch
title: Asset price inflation and monetary policy
Key quote: This vigilance is particularly warranted in the light of some signs that monetary policy is encouraging increased risk-taking and contributing to elevated asset price inflation and income inequality.
Rationale: Although Yves Mersch expresses concerns about risk-taking and asset price inflation, he acknowledges the need for highly accommodative monetary policy due to current economic conditions. The focus on monitoring side effects and the strategic incorporation of financial stability concerns into policy reflect a somewhat hawkish stance, but not enough to indicate an immediate rate increase, suggesting a hold on current rates.
description: Keynote speech by Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank and Vice-Chair of the Supervisory Board of the European Central Bank, at the celebration of INVESTAS' 60th anniversary, Luxembourg, 27 January 2020.

author: Yves Mersch
title: Opening remarks
Key quote: The Governing Council decided on a comprehensive package of measures with a view to ensuring that inflation moves towards the ECB's aim in a sustained manner.
Rationale: The speech outlines recent loose monetary policy measures including a rate cut and resumption of net asset purchases, indicating a dovish stance. The focus on measures already implemented suggests a tendency to hold rates while assessing their impact.
description: Opening remarks by Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank and Vice-Chair of the Supervisory Board of the European Central Bank, at the "Getting to know the EU Institutions and Organisations in Luxembourg" event, Luxembourg, 11 November 2019.

author: Yves Mersch
title: Economic and monetary policy at a turning point - where is the economy heading in Europe, the United States and China?
Key quote: We now expect them to remain at their present levels at least through the first half of 2020, and in any case for as long as necessary to ensure the continued sustained convergence of inflation to levels that are below, but close to, 2% over the medium term.
Rationale: The speech highlights the ECB's decision to maintain interest rates at low levels through at least the first half of 2020, which is somewhat dovish, indicating a focus on supporting growth and giving clarity about rate hikes being unlikely in the near term.
description: Speech by Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Petersberger Sommerdialog, Königswinter, 29 June 2019.

author: Yves Mersch
title: Necessity, proportionality and probity - central bank independence in unconventional times
Key quote: The best protection against - unjustified - attacks on the independence of monetary policy is therefore a narrower mandate combined with a high degree of transparency and the strict interpretation of legal limits.
Rationale: The speech defends the need for unconventional monetary measures amidst criticism, hinting at continued support for these measures. The emphasis on necessity and proportionality of actions suggests a cautious stance, likely favoring holding rates steady rather than raising or cutting them.
description: Speech by Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the conference "The ECB and its watchers XX", Frankfurt am Main, 27 March 2019.

author: Yves Mersch
title: Remarks at the "Challenges in Understanding the Monetary Transmission Mechanism" conference
Key quote: Our unconventional measures have proven sufficient to meet the challenges of low inflation.
Rationale: The speech discusses the effectiveness of existing measures and the lack of motivation to fundamentally change policy, suggesting a neutral stance with no immediate need for further easing or tightening of monetary policy.
description: Remarks by Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the "Challenges in Understanding the Monetary Transmission Mechanism" conference, Warsaw, 22 March 2019.

author: Yves Mersch
title: Monetary policy in the euro area - a brief assessment
Key quote: Rates are expected to remain at their present levels at least through the summer of 2019, and in any case for as long as necessary to ensure the continued sustained convergence of inflation to levels that are below, but close to, 2% over the medium term.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes confidence in the economy's strength and ongoing monetary policy support but doesn't indicate an urgent move towards tightening or easing, suggesting a continued 'hold' approach with a neutral stance.
description: Speaking points by Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the MNI Connect Roundtable, Singapore, 10 October 2018.

author: Yves Mersch
title: Are the economy and monetary policy at a turning point - and where are the European and US economies headed?
Key quote: Looking ahead, monetary policy will be firmly guided by the outlook for price stability and our stance will evolve in a data-dependent and time consistent manner.
Rationale: The speech suggests confidence in underlying economic strength and a probable end to net asset purchases, indicating a shift towards policy normalization. However, continued caution regarding interest rate projections suggests they would likely hold rates at the next meeting.
description: Speech by Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Panel at the Petersberger Sommerdialog, Königswinter, 30 June 2018.

author: Yves Mersch
title: Central bank risk management in times of monetary policy normalisation
Key quote: As monetary policy begins to normalise, there are three areas in particular where our risk management framework needs to be reviewed.
Rationale: Yves Mersch discusses the need for careful review and potential normalisation of monetary policy tools, hinting at a shift towards more conventional policy. However, he stops short of suggesting immediate tightening, leading to the expectation of holding rates steady.
description: Speech by Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the International Risk Management Conference, Paris, 8 June 2018.

author: Yves Mersch
title: Reflections on monetary policy in the euro area
Key quote: Overall, the underlying strength in the euro area economy continues to support our confidence that inflation will converge towards our aim over the medium term. Yet, inflation convergence will likely proceed only gradually, and remains contingent on a highly accommodative monetary policy stance.
Rationale: The emphasis on patience and prudence, along with the conditions for policy normalization being contingent on continued accommodative policies, suggests a somewhat dovish stance. The numeric score reflects continued reliance on monetary support, and with inflation yet to clearly pick up, holding rates seems the most likely course.
description: Speaking points by Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Eurofi conference, Sofia, 27 April 2018.

author: Yves Mersch
title: Monetary policy in the euro area - solid expansion with timid price pressure
Key quote: An ample degree of monetary accommodation remains necessary to secure a return of inflation rates towards levels that are below, but close to, 2% over the medium term.
Rationale: Despite solid economic growth, Yves Mersch emphasizes the need for continued monetary accommodation due to subdued inflation pressures and the need to secure a return to target inflation rates. This indicates a somewhat dovish stance, suggesting that a change in interest rates is unlikely in the immediate future.
description: Contribution by Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, to the EUROFI magazine, submitted on 21 March 2018 and published on 26 April 2018.

author: Yves Mersch
title: Challenges facing monetary policy in the euro area
Key quote: The improving inflation trajectory means that we can gradually scale back our net purchases and keep monetary policy sufficiently accommodative to continue to support the convergence of inflation towards our aim.
Rationale: The speech highlights the strengthening economy and inflation trajectory, suggesting a readiness to gradually exit from the purchase programme but also the need to be cautious in order not to disrupt the recovery. This signals a somewhat hawkish stance, balancing the acknowledgment of economic improvement with cautious policy change, likely leading to a hold in rates.
description: Speech by Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, to the Schweizerisch-Deutscher Wirtschaftsclub, Frankfurt am Main, 19 March 2018.

author: Yves Mersch
title: Interview with Reuters
Key quote: So the message is patience, persistence and prudence.
Rationale: The speech by Yves Mersch indicates a cautiously optimistic outlook with a need for more data confirmation before any policy changes, implying a 'Hold' stance on interest rates for now.
description: Interview with Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, conducted by Mr Balazs Koranyi on 14 March 2018 and published on 16 March 2018.

author: Yves Mersch
title: Interview in Luxemburger Wort
Key quote: We are not yet ready at this stage to change interest rates.
Rationale: The speaker indicates a cautious approach to changing interest rates, suggesting that the ECB is not yet ready to make moves towards tightening monetary policy. This aligns more with a 'somewhat dovish' stance, suggesting they would likely vote to hold rates steady.
description: Interview with Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in Luxemburger Wort, conducted by Mr Pierre Sorlut and Ms Barbara Tasch on 8 March and published on 14 March 2018.

author: Yves Mersch
title: Interview in Börsen-Zeitung
Key quote: The more confident we are of meeting our objective, the more the likelihood of a further increase in our purchase programme trends towards zero.
Rationale: Yves Mersch expresses confidence in achieving the inflation objective and hints at reducing the easing bias, signaling a move towards policy normalization. However, he also emphasizes careful, gradual changes, aligning more with holding rates in the short-term.
description: Interview with Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in Börsen-Zeitung, conducted by Mr Mark Schrörs und Mr Detlef Fechtner on 18 December and published on 29 December 2017.

author: Yves Mersch
title: Economic policy and the need for humility
Key quote: The ECB has shown great flexibility and ingenuity in dealing with the financial crisis.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the pervasive uncertainty in monetary policy, advocating for humility and careful judgment without suggesting a clear directional change in policy. This suggests a neutral stance, leaning towards holding rates.
description: Speech by Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Conference "Banking and Financial Regulation", Bocconi University, Milan, 9 October 2017.

author: Yves Mersch
title: The European Central Bank's monetary policy stance
Key quote: A very substantial degree of monetary accommodation is still needed for underlying inflation pressures to gradually build up.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the need for continued monetary accommodation due to subdued inflation levels and pressures. Although the economic recovery is acknowledged, the lack of strong inflation dynamics suggests a somewhat dovish stance may be more appropriate. Hence, the likely approach would be to hold interest rates steady to support ongoing inflation growth.
description: Speech by Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at an MNI connect event, Singapore, 25 July 2017.

author: Yves Mersch
title: Central banking in times of technological progress
Key quote: Given the overall level of uncertainty of data and economic models, policymakers should act in a prudent fashion and only take actions that are necessary for the fulfilment of the price stability mandate and proportionate to the challenge in hand.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the need for adaptability and prudence in response to technological advances rather than indicating a clear direction for interest rate adjustments. It reflects a careful approach without suggesting immediate changes in monetary policy, supporting a 'Hold' prediction.
description: Speech by Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Central Bank of Malaysia (Bank Negara Malaysia) Monetary Policy Conference, Kuala Lumpur, 24 July 2017.

author: Yves Mersch
title: Monetary policy challenges for Europe - banking on the recovery
Key quote: Market expectations regarding deflationary risks and further policy rate cuts by the ECB have faded and focus is beginning to shift towards a normalisation of policy in the future.
Rationale: The speech acknowledges a robust recovery and discusses eventual policy normalization, but emphasizes a continued accommodative stance, suggesting a balanced yet slightly hawkish outlook. The probability of holding rates is higher because the normalization discussion is framed as future-oriented and needs careful structuring.
description: Speech by Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the 2017 Institute of International Finance (IIF) Spring Membership Meeting, Tokyo, 8 May 2017.

author: Yves Mersch
title: Remarks on the future of economic governance in Europe and the euro
Key quote: Our monetary policy measures played a key role in stabilising the European economy.
Rationale: While the speech discusses the role of monetary policy in stabilizing the euro area economy, it primarily focuses on the importance of economic governance and structural reforms to complement monetary policy. There is no indication of a need for immediate policy change, suggesting a neutral stance.
description: Introductory address by Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the panel "The Agenda for Europe", at Ambrosetti's Finance Forum on "The Outlook for the Economy and Finance", Villa d'Este, Cernobbio, 8 April 2017.

author: Yves Mersch
title: Behaving responsibly in a low interest rate environment - a central banker's perspective
Key quote: The recovery has started. However, for it to be sustainable, we must first and foremost address the causes of this global low interest rate environment.
Rationale: The speech indicates a cautious stance, acknowledging improved economic growth but also remaining aware of political risks and uncertainties. The emphasis on keeping measures in place and monitoring conditions suggests no immediate change in the policy rate, hence a neutral standpoint.
description: Speech by Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Stiftung Marktwirtschaft: Expertentagung "5th Kadener Gespräch", Alveslohe, 10 February 2017.

author: Yves Mersch
title: Ructions in the repo market - monetary easing or regulatory squeezing?
Key quote: Our mandate is clear: to deliver price stability. This is our primary objective and the sole orientation for our policy.
Rationale: The speech outlines the stresses in the repo market and acknowledges potential negative side effects of the ECB's APP but emphasizes the primary mandate of price stability. The overall tone suggests a balanced view, neither leaning towards easing further nor tightening, leading to a 'Hold' prediction.
description: Speech by Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the GFF (Deutsche Börse Group Global Funding and Financing) summit, Luxembourg, 26 January 2017.

author: Yves Mersch
title: The causes of monetary policy measures and their impact - a review
Key quote: Low interest rates and an accommodative policy remain appropriate in the current context.
Rationale: The speech acknowledges the need for continued accommodative policy to support the fragile recovery and address low inflation, suggesting rates should remain low, characteristic of a dovish stance. However, there is caution about future rate cuts, indicating a somewhat dovish position rather than fully dovish.
description: Speech by Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Euro Finance Week, FAROS Institutional Investors Forum, Frankfurt am Main, 17 November 2016.

author: Yves Mersch
title: Low interest rate environment - an economic, legal and social analysis
Key quote: The longer we remain in this low interest rate environment, the stronger the side effects of our measures will be.
Rationale: The speech discusses the risks of low interest rates and the need for vigilance, but reaffirms the benefits of the ECB's monetary policy and the potential need to continue these measures, indicating a somewhat dovish stance. Given the context and risks mentioned, it is likely the speaker would support holding rates to monitor the situation.
description: Speech by Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the University of the Deutsche Bundesbank, Hachenburg, 27 October 2016.

author: Yves Mersch
title: Speaking points for an event organised by MNI Connect
Key quote: The hesitant pace of recovery has weighed on inflation dynamics which remain subdued.
Rationale: Yves Mersch highlights the ECB's expansionary measures and their positive impact on credit conditions, but he notes inflation remains subdued and downside risks remain. This suggests a somewhat dovish stance, likely voting to hold rates given the current economic context.
description: Speech by Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank.

author: Yves Mersch
title: The European Central Bank and the Federal Reserve - an ocean apart?
Key quote: In a world of very low interest rates, monetary policy cannot be the only game in town - and we should not pretend it can be.
Rationale: The speech discusses the challenges facing central banks, noting accommodative monetary policies and structural challenges without strongly indicating a shift towards tightening or easing, suggesting a hold position on rates.
description: Speech by Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at Harvard University, Boston, Massachusetts, 12 October 2016.

author: Yves Mersch
title: The challenge of low interest rates for banks within the banking union
Key quote: Interest rates have to stay low until the economic recovery in the euro area has gained sufficient momentum to lift the inflation rate to a level in line with our definition of price stability.
Rationale: Yves Mersch acknowledges the challenges of low interest rates for banks' profitability but affirms the need for rates to remain low to support economic recovery and achieve price stability goals. His caution against further rate cuts suggests a preference for maintaining current policy settings rather than making them even more accommodative.
description: Speech by Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Public Roundtable at the University of Luxembourg on "Banking Union - Quo Vadis?", Luxembourg, 3 October 2016.

author: Yves Mersch
title: Banks adapting to the new normal - striking a balance
Key quote: Banks are crucial: they ensure that our accommodative monetary policy reaches the real economy as they translate lower refinancing costs into more favourable lending conditions for euro area households and companies.
Rationale: The speech by Yves Mersch is largely focused on addressing financial regulation and challenges faced by banks in the current low growth, low interest environment. While acknowledging the criticism of low interest rates, the speech does not indicate a strong shift in monetary policy stance, suggesting a continuation of the current policy approach.
description: Dinner speech by Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Mandarine Gestion Investment Conference, Munich, 19 September 2016.

author: Yves Mersch
title: Monetary policy in the euro area - scope, principles and limits
Key quote: But the surest way to reach that point is to stay true to the course we are on now. If we were to change speed or direction too soon, it would only set back the recovery of inflation and delay the day that interest rate normalisation can happen.
Rationale: The speech signals a continuation of accommodative policy (APP and other measures) to combat deflationary pressures, but acknowledges limits and a future need to phase out such measures. This indicates somewhat dovish intentions with an understanding that policy cannot indefinitely remain highly accommodative.
description: Keynote speech by Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Natixis Meeting of Chief Economists, Paris, 23 June 2016.

author: Yves Mersch
title: Scope and limits of monetary policy
Key quote: The ECB's monetary policy measures have prevented inflation from falling much further and probably helped avoiding a deflationary spiral.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the ECB's use of a wide array of non-standard monetary policy measures to prevent deflation and stabilize prices, which reflects a somewhat dovish approach given concern over low inflation. However, there is no indication of further easing, suggesting a 'Hold' recommendation.
description: Introductory remarks by Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the panel "Europe's Economic and Monetary Policy" during the Ambrosetti Conference on the Outlook for the Economy and Finance, Villa d'Este, Cernobbio, 9 April 2016.

author: Yves Mersch
title: Policy needs, knowns and unknowns in the aftermath of the crisis
Key quote: It would be preferable, in my view, for policymakers to admit the uncertainties they face in this new environment and be humble about what they can achieve within it.
Rationale: The speech discusses the complexities and uncertainties in economic measurement and the limitations of monetary policy in the current environment. It suggests a cautious approach, indicating no immediate shift in policy such as rate changes.
description: Keynote speech by Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at UBS, Zurich, 4 February 2016.

author: Yves Mersch
title: Interview in Wall Street Journal
Key quote: Yes, we will continue to have an accommodative monetary policy.
Rationale: The interview suggests a continuation of accommodative policy and reassessment of the economic situation. However, there is no strong commitment to immediate further stimulus, implying a somewhat dovish stance with a leaning towards holding rates at the next meeting.
description: Interview with Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in Wall Street Journal, conducted by Mr Brian Blackstone and Mr Tom Fairless and published on 1 February 2016.

author: Yves Mersch
title: Current developments in the German banking market
Key quote: Intensified competition within an environment of low interest rates over a longer time period could markedly reduce earnings in the future.
Rationale: The speech reflects concerns about narrow interest rate margins, low returns on savings, and the challenges for banks in a low interest rate environment. There's a focus on financial stability, but no strong indication of a move toward tightening monetary policy, suggesting a likelihood to maintain current rates.
description: Speech by Mr Yves Mersch, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at an event organised by the Bayerischer Sparkassenverband, Munich, 27 January 2016.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Monetary policy - lifting the veil of effectiveness
Key quote: Central banks are likely to have to navigate in a low-growth, low-inflation environment with the risk of repeatedly failing to deliver inflation in line with their aim.
Rationale: The speech highlights the challenges of low inflation despite accommodative policy, suggesting potential further easing if necessary. However, it stops short of advocating immediate action, thus leaning towards a hold stance.
description: Speech by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the ECB colloquium on "Monetary policy: the challenges ahead" held in his honour, Frankfurt am Main, 18 December 2019.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview in Libération
Key quote: In September, the euro area was facing the risk of a further slowdown and inflation was remaining too far away from our 2% objective.
Rationale: Mr. Cœuré discusses the need for accommodative monetary policy due to economic slowdown risks, defending quantitative easing and highlighting low inflation. However, he also acknowledges internal dissent and potential risks of prolonged low rates, making his stance slightly dovish but not entirely dovish.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in Libération, conducted by Mr Jean Quatremer on 4 December 2019, and published on 16 December 2019.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: The single currency - an unfinished agenda
Key quote: The single monetary policy has to shoulder the burden of macroeconomic stabilisation in the face of adverse shocks.
Rationale: The speech reflects concerns about economic growth and productivity in the Eurozone, emphasizing the need for structural reforms, fiscal support, and integration measures rather than immediate monetary policy tightening. This suggests a somewhat dovish stance amid acknowledgment of broader challenges.
description: Speech by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the ECB Representative Office, Brussels, 3 December 2019.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: A tale of two money markets - fragmentation or concentration
Key quote: Today, large excess reserve holdings are, by and large, a reflection of the accommodative monetary policy that central banks have conducted in recent years, and that many, including the ECB, are still conducting today in view of stubbornly low inflation rates.
Rationale: The speech is balanced in its discussion of current monetary policy, highlighting complexities in liquidity management without suggesting immediate policy changes. The focus on maintaining accommodative policy suggests a neutral stance with a 'Hold' vote likely.
description: Speech by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the European Central Bank workshop on money markets, monetary policy implementation and central bank balance sheets, Frankfurt am Main, 12 November 2019.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Exchange of views with members of the High Council of Public Finance
Key quote: Looking ahead, the Governing Council is determined to act in case of adverse contingencies and also stands ready to adjust all of its instruments, as appropriate, to ensure that inflation continues to move towards the Governing Council's inflation aim in a sustained manner.
Rationale: Benoît Cœuré highlights the ECB's readiness to act in response to downside risks and maintain monetary accommodation to support inflation, reflecting a somewhat dovish stance. However, the lack of imminent action suggests a preference to hold rates while being prepared for dovish actions if necessary.
description: Introductory remarks by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, prior to an informal exchange of views with the High Council of Public Finance, Paris, 17 July 2019.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Inflation expectations and the conduct of monetary policy
Key quote: The protracted period of low inflation has caused concerns among financial market participants that current subdued underlying price pressures will persist in the medium term.
Rationale: The speech highlights concerns over persistent low inflation and the credibility of central bank policy, yet it also mentions the stability of consumer expectations and the resilience of household inflation expectations. It leans towards a cautious approach without explicitly advocating for immediate easing, indicating some dovish sentiment while suggesting the ECB remains attentive to concerns.
description: Speech by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at an event organised by the SAFE Policy Center, Frankfurt am Main, 11 July 2019.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview with BFM Business TV
Key quote: Monetary policy needs to be accommodative until that objective is met.
Rationale: Benoît Cœuré emphasizes the ongoing need for accommodative monetary policy to achieve the ECB's inflation target, noting global risks and a slowdown. While he's open to acting on new risks, he leans towards holding the current policy unless conditions significantly worsen.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, and BFM Business TV, conducted by Ms Hedwige Chevrillon, and published on 9 July 2019.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview in the Financial Times
Key quote: Risk has increased. And that required reassurance from the Council that we're ready to address these risks, should they materialise.
Rationale: Benoît Cœuré acknowledges the broadening of risks and discusses the preparedness to use tools like rate cuts and QE if necessary. However, the immediate action suggested is contingency planning, not a direct move to cut rates, indicating a somewhat dovish stance but not full-on immediate dovish action.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in the Financial Times, conducted by Ms Claire Jones on 12 June 2019, and published on 17 June 2019.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: The effects of APP reinvestments on euro area bond markets
Key quote: The Governing Council is determined to act in case of adverse contingencies and stands ready to adjust all of its instruments, as appropriate, to ensure that inflation continues to move towards the Governing Council's inflation aim in a sustained manner.
Rationale: The speech highlights the ECB's commitment to maintaining accommodative monetary policy, with a focus on utilizing the APP's effects to ensure favorable financial conditions. The forward guidance for rates remaining unchanged through the first half of 2020 indicates a dovish stance, given the existing policy rate of -0.4%.
description: Closing remarks by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the ECB's Bond Market Contact Group meeting, Frankfurt am Main, 12 June 2019.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: The rise of services and the transmission of monetary policy
Key quote: One of the biggest mysteries currently facing central banks around the world is why inflation has failed to pick up more forcefully after years of extraordinary monetary stimulus.
Rationale: The speech acknowledges the sluggish response of inflation to economic activity, despite significant monetary stimulus, suggesting a continuation of current policy rather than tightening or easing. This implies a somewhat dovish stance leaning towards holding rates.
description: Speech by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the 21st Geneva Conference on the World Economy, Geneva, 16 May 2019.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Exchange of views with members of the French Parliament
Key quote: The ECB Governing Council confirmed that an ample degree of monetary accommodation remains necessary to safeguard favourable financing conditions and support the economic expansion.
Rationale: The speech highlights the need to maintain accommodative monetary policy due to uncertainties and downside risks, suggesting a somewhat dovish stance. However, it stops short of discussing further easing, indicating a hold on rates for now.
description: Introductory remarks by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, prior to an informal exchange of views with the Finance Committee of the National Assembly, Paris, 15 May 2019.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview in Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung
Key quote: We are not abandoning the prospect of normalisation, but it has been delayed by the economic downturn.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes monitoring economic developments and acknowledges a delay in normalizing monetary policy due to an economic slowdown. Coeuré recognizes concerns about prolonged low interest rates but indicates no immediate change, suggesting a cautious approach to rate adjustments.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, conducted by Mr Johannes Pennekamp and Mr Philip Plickert on 17 April 2019 and published on 23 April 2019.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview in Risques
Key quote: The normalisation of our monetary policy will depend on economic indicators and, in any case, it will be a very long and gradual process.
Rationale: Benoît Cœuré emphasizes that monetary policy normalization will be gradual and dependent on economic indicators, indicating no immediate shift in policy. The overall tone reflects a measured and balanced viewpoint, suggesting a likelihood of holding rates steady for the time being.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in Risques, conducted by Messrs Jean-Hervé Lorenzi, François-Xavier Albouy, Arnaud Chneiweiss, Pierre-Charles Pradier and Philippe Trainar, on 4 February 2019 and published on 2 April 2019.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Heterogeneity and the European Central Bank's monetary policy
Key quote: To protect this achievement, we decided at our last monetary policy meeting in March to launch a new series of targeted long-term refinancing operations, 'TLTRO-III', starting in September 2019.
Rationale: The speech indicates support for non-standard policy measures and highlights the continuity of accommodative monetary policies despite uncertainties, suggesting a somewhat dovish stance with a bias towards maintaining the current policy rate.
description: Speech by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Bank of France Symposium &amp; 34th SUERF Colloquium on the occasion of the 20th anniversary of the euro on "The Euro Area: Staying the Course through Uncertainties", Paris, 29 March 2019.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview in Corriere della Sera
Key quote: We are adjusting to the new reality rather than reversing our course; we don't see signs of a recession at present.
Rationale: Benoît Cœuré acknowledges the stronger than expected economic slowdown and suggests that while additional stimulus measures have been considered, a reversal in policy is not deemed necessary yet. The ECB is committed to keeping rates low and providing liquidity, which aligns with a somewhat dovish outlook, hence a 'Hold' prediction.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in Corriere della Sera, conducted by Mr Danilo Taino on 7 March 2019 and published on 11 March 2019.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview in Barron's
Key quote: Because we changed our vision of the risks ahead, markets drew their conclusions and the eurozone yield curve is flatter than it was in December.
Rationale: Benoît Cœuré acknowledges worsening downside risks to the eurozone economy and emphasizes that forward guidance itself serves as a monetary easing tool. He indicates readiness to act if necessary but suggests a wait-and-see approach to assess data, hence a somewhat dovish stance with likely preference to hold rates.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in Barron's, conducted by Mr Pierre Briançon on 5 February 2019 and published on 7 February 2019.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview with Bloomberg TV
Key quote: We are monitoring the data. We have this rate guidance: we say we are not going to move before through the summer. We could change it, we could extend it.
Rationale: The ECB is facing significant downside risks from global trade and Brexit. Coeuré suggests potential future policy adjustments and emphasizes data-driven decisions, pointing towards caution rather than immediate rate hikes.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, and Bloomberg TV, conducted by by Ms Francine Lacqua on 25 January 2019.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview with France Inter
Key quote: In addition, the short-term interest rates that the ECB controls directly are going to stay at their current level, i.e. at zero and even below zero, at least through the summer of 2019, and for as long as required for inflation to return towards 2%, which is our aim.
Rationale: Benoît Cœuré emphasizes that interest rates will remain low for an extended period, suggesting a dovish stance. The ECB stopping net purchases does not equate to tightening, and the commitment to keeping rates low reflects a focus on ensuring adequate monetary accommodation to support inflation targets.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, and France Inter, conducted by Mr Ali Baddou and Ms Alexandra Bensaid and broadcast on 4 January 2019.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: The international dimension of the European Central Bank's asset purchase programme - an update
Key quote: In the euro area, this means that significant monetary policy stimulus is still needed to support the further build-up of domestic price pressures and headline inflation developments over the medium term.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the need for continued monetary policy stimulus to support inflation and dismisses concerns about negative impacts from ending asset purchases. Benoît Cœuré speaks about maintaining favorable liquidity conditions and the necessity of stimulus, which suggests a dovish stance keen on holding rates steady.
description: Speech by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at a conference on "Exiting Unconventional Monetary Policies", organised by the Euro 50 Group, the CF40 forum and CIGI, Paris, 26 October 2018.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview in Der Tagesspiegel
Key quote: Ample monetary stimulus will remain needed to support a sustained convergence of euro area inflation towards our aim of below, but close to 2%.
Rationale: The speech acknowledges the growth and falling unemployment, but emphasizes the need for continued monetary stimulus and gradual normalization, implying a cautious approach towards tightening monetary policy.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in Der Tagesspiegel, conducted by Ms Carla Neuhaus on 19 September 2018 and published on 1 October 2018.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Forward guidance and policy normalisation
Key quote: Empirical evidence demonstrates that the enhanced forward guidance that the Governing Council adopted in June 2018 has been effective in reducing uncertainty around the expected future path of short-term interest rates.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the importance of forward guidance and transparency during the policy normalization phase but stops short of signaling an imminent rate hike. The focus is on managing uncertainty rather than suggesting any immediate change in policy, indicating a neutral stance with a likelihood of holding rates steady.
description: Speech by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Deutsches Institut für Wirtschaftsforschung (The German Institute for Economic Research), Berlin, 17 September 2018.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview with Bloomberg TV
Key quote: The expectation is that rates will remain low, at the current level, at least through the summer of 2019.
Rationale: Benoît Cœuré mentions that the ECB intends to maintain low rates at least through the summer of 2019, indicating a continuation of accommodative monetary policy despite external risks.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, and Bloomberg TV, conducted by Ms Caroline Connan and broadcast on 9 July 2018.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview in Le Figaro
Key quote: We expect our policy rates to remain unchanged until at least through the summer of 2019.
Rationale: The speech indicates a commitment to maintaining accommodative monetary policy with unchanged rates until at least the summer of 2019, despite some robustness in growth and ending asset purchases. This implies a somewhat dovish stance, focused on sustaining support for the economy amidst uncertainties.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in Le Figaro, conducted by Mr Fabrice Nodé-Langlois and published on 25 June 2018.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview with Europe 1
Key quote: We're going to keep interest rates very low, at their current levels, in other words close to zero, at least through the summer of 2019.
Rationale: The statement suggests a neutral stance as asset purchases are set to end, indicating confidence in the economy, while interest rates are expected to remain low to continue supporting the economy, resulting in a hold position at the next meeting.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, and Europe 1, conducted by Mr Patrick Cohen on 15 June 2018 and broadcast on 15 June 2018.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview in Die Zeit
Key quote: We expect the economic expansion to continue, and we are increasingly confident that inflation will rise towards our aim of below, but close to, 2%.
Rationale: Benoît Cœuré expresses confidence in economic growth and inflation nearing the ECB's target, suggesting a somewhat hawkish stance. However, there is no explicit call for immediate rate changes, indicating a likely hold on rates with plans to wind down asset purchases gradually.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in Die Zeit, conducted by Ms Lisa Nienhaus and Mr Mark Schieritz on 16 May 2018 and published on 23 May 2018.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Scars that never were? Potential output and slack after the crisis
Key quote: Ample monetary policy accommodation therefore continues to be necessary for inflation to reach levels closer to 2% sustainably.
Rationale: The speech suggests that the current monetary policy is suitable for the economic conditions. While acknowledging uncertainty in slack estimates, Benoit Cœuré emphasizes the need for continued accommodation, but also suggests that future recalibration might be possible as conditions change. This balanced view indicates a neutral stance, favoring a 'Hold' on rates.
description: Speech by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the CEPII 40th Anniversary Conference, Paris, 12 April 2018.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview with France Info
Key quote: We know that monetary policy will need to remain very accommodative for quite some time.
Rationale: Benoît Cœuré emphasizes the need for an accommodative monetary policy stance given the current inflation and growth trends, suggesting no immediate changes to policy rates or significant tapering of the asset purchase program. This indicates a somewhat dovish stance, likely resulting in a 'Hold' decision at the next meeting.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, and France Info, conducted by Mr Jean Leymarie on 9 April 2018 and published on 10 April 2018.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: The consequences of protectionism
Key quote: Protectionism is not the right answer to these challenges, however. It is unlikely to solve the distributional consequences of globalisation while it is certain to reduce aggregate global living standards.
Rationale: Benoît Cœuré's speech emphasizes the negative economic consequences of protectionism, such as lower global growth and increased uncertainty. While cautious about the impacts of trade barriers, the focus on downside risks suggests a somewhat dovish stance, favoring continued policy support rather than tightening.
description: Panel contribution by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the 29th edition of the workshop "The Outlook for the Economy and Finance", "Villa d'Este", Cernobbio, 6 April 2018.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Making our monetary union stronger and more resilient
Key quote: Even today, euro area growth still relies too much on monetary policy support.
Rationale: The speech discusses the need for reforms to make the monetary union more resilient but highlights existing reliance on current monetary policy support. This suggests a neutral stance, as the current policies appear necessary for stability at this juncture.
description: Speech by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Finanzmarktklausur of the CDU Wirtschaftsrat, Berlin, 14 March 2018.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview with BFM Business TV
Key quote: It is too early to declare victory. We are going in the right direction and the decision taken by the ECB's Governing Council last week, which entails changing our communication very slightly to show that we no longer intend to increase the scale of the central bank's monthly asset purchases, represents a small communication step which shows our confidence.
Rationale: Benoît Cœuré highlights that while growth is strong, inflation is not at the desired level and international risks persist. The ECB's recent decision reflects growing confidence but not enough to alter interest rates, suggesting a neutral stance leaning towards holding rates.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, and BFM Business TV, conducted by Mr Stéphane Soumier on 12 March 2018.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: The persistence and signalling power of central bank asset purchase programmes
Key quote: The non-linear nature of the stock effect implies that the amount of purchases needed to deliver a given compression of the term premium is likely to fall over time as the acquired stock of assets increases.
Rationale: The speech discusses the effectiveness and reduced necessity of asset purchases over time as fit into the broader monetary policy strategy. While some hint of a shift from asset purchases to rate guidance indicates caution on tightening, it's not overtly hawkish or dovish, thereby suggesting a preference to 'Hold' rates for now as the ECB evaluates market conditions.
description: Speech by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the 2018 US Monetary Policy Forum, New York City, 23 February 2018.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: The euro area's three lines of defence
Key quote: Depending on the nature of the next crisis, policy action might require taking short-term rates much deeper into negative territory.
Rationale: The speech highlights concerns about the potential need for further easing measures, such as deeper negative rates, suggesting a somewhat dovish stance. However, the emphasis on structural reforms as a necessity for future stability balances the tone, leaning towards a hold prediction in the absence of immediate crisis signs.
description: Speech by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the conference "Deepening of EMU", Ljubljana, 2 February 2018.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: What yield curves are telling us
Key quote: Accordingly, an ample degree of monetary stimulus remains necessary for underlying inflation pressures to continue to build up, and we expect the ECB's key interest rates to remain at their present levels for an extended period of time, and well past the horizon of our net asset purchases.
Rationale: The speech highlights that inflation expectations are well anchored, and there is no immediate pressure to raise rates. It emphasizes the necessity of continuing monetary stimulus to support inflation, indicating a somewhat dovish stance.
description: Speech by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Financial Times European Financial Forum "Building a New Future for International Financial Services", Dublin, 31 January 2018.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview in Caixin Global
Key quote: Indeed, our monetary policy will remain very accommodative. It has a single objective, which is to bring euro area inflation back to a level below, but close to, 2% over the medium term.
Rationale: Although the economic expansion is strong in Europe, Benoît Cœuré emphasizes maintaining accommodative monetary policy due to inflation not yet reaching the 2% target. This suggests a cautious approach without immediate tightening, likely resulting in holding the rates steady.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in Caixin Global, conducted by Mr Liwei Wang on 17 December and published on 30 December 2017.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Central banks as risk managers
Key quote: Monetary policy is a forward-looking enterprise and policymakers always have to think in terms of risks.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes a cautious approach to monetary policy, acknowledging past inflation forecasting errors and the reduction in asset purchases, reflecting a somewhat dovish stance aimed at tapering economic support without rushing to tighten conditions. He underscores the importance of being data-driven, especially concerning political risks, indicating a preference for holding steady based on current economic assessments.
description: Speech by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the 53rd SEACEN Governors' Conference/ High-Level Seminar and the 37th Meeting of the SEACEN Board of Governors, Bangkok, 16 December 2017.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview in Handelsblatt
Key quote: There is very broad agreement in the Governing Council that monetary policy needs to remain accommodative until inflation moves back towards 2% in a sustainable way.
Rationale: Benoît Cœuré acknowledges a strong economic recovery but notes the persistent weakness in inflation, advocating for a continued accommodative monetary policy. The somewhat hawkish sentiment is reflected in the hope that asset purchases might end by September, suggesting a cautious approach to tightening monetary policy, but not explicitly advocating for rate increases yet.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in Handelsblatt, conducted by Mr Jan Mallien and Mr Frank Wiebe on 15 November and published on 21 November 2017.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Asset purchases, financial regulation and repo market activity
Key quote: The present inflation outlook requires financing conditions to remain accommodative for a considerable period of time.
Rationale: While Coeuré highlights the importance of the repo market in monetary policy transmission, he also emphasizes the need for accommodative financing conditions due to the inflation outlook. This indicates a somewhat dovish stance, suggesting he is more likely to hold current rates than to raise them.
description: Speech by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the ERCC General Meeting on "The repo market: market conditions and operational challenges", Brussels, 14 November 2017.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview with France Info TV
Key quote: Monetary policy supports growth and job creation. For that reason we won't be withdrawing support now.
Rationale: The speaker acknowledges the risks of low rates but emphasizes the need to support growth and job creation, indicating no immediate intent to tighten policy or raise rates, hence a dovish stance but not the most dovish due to awareness of financial stability risks.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, and France Info TV, conducted by Mr Jean-Paul Chapel on 9 November 2017.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Monetary policy, exchange rates and capital flows
Key quote: Asset purchases are monetary policy actions that can be anticipated by market participants, just like changes in key policy rates.
Rationale: Benoît Cœuré's speech provides a detailed analysis of how asset purchase programs affect exchange rates, emphasizing their complex influence on both signaling and portfolio rebalancing channels without making explicit policy recommendations, which suggests a balanced, neutral stance towards future rate adjustments.
description: Speech by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the 18th Jacques Polak Annual Research Conference, hosted by the International Monetary Fund, Washington DC, 3 November 2017.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview in Le Journal du Dimanche
Key quote: The ECB's monetary policy will remain very accommodative: in particular, our asset purchases will continue until inflation clearly moves towards 2%.
Rationale: Benoît Cœuré emphasizes that the ECB's monetary policy will remain accommodative, with continued asset purchases and low interest rates until inflation moves towards 2%. This indicates a somewhat dovish stance, as they are not in a rush to tighten policy, supporting the prediction to hold rates.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in Le Journal du Dimanche, conducted by Ms Bruna Basini on 27 October, and published on 29 October 2017.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: The use of local currencies in EU canddate and potential candidate countries
Key quote: The euro area too is now contributing to global growth, rather than subtracting from it, in large part thanks to the range of monetary policy measures taken by the ECB in recent years.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes ongoing global and regional economic recovery and the need for structural reforms, but doesn't signal significant changes in monetary policy or interest rates, suggesting a neutral stance.
description: Speech by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the International Conference on the occasion of the 20th anniversary of the Central Bank of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Sarajevo, 22 September 2017.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: The transmission of the ECB's monetary policy in standard and non-standard times
Key quote: Monetary policy is far from being ineffective in stimulating aggregate demand, also when approaching the effective lower bound.
Rationale: The speech highlights the effectiveness of ECB's non-standard monetary policy measures and suggests that monetary policy may remain accommodative for longer to support growth, indicating a 'somewhat dovish' stance. The speaker emphasizes the impact of monetary policy on financial conditions and suggests careful monitoring, implying a cautious, yet supportive approach, likely to result in holding the rates at the next meeting.
description: Speech by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the workshop "Monetary policy in non-standard times", Frankfurt am Main, 11 September 2017.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: The international dimension of the ECB's asset purchase programme
Key quote: Asset purchase programmes have been instrumental in easing monetary policy at the effective lower bound in major advanced economies.
Rationale: Coeuré highlights the positive effects of the ECB's asset purchase program and suggests that these measures are supporting growth and price stability. The lack of emphasis on tightening indicates a dovish stance, but due to global and domestic considerations, he is likely to vote to hold rates.
description: Speech by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Foreign Exchange Contact Group meeting, Frankfurt am Main, 11 July 2017.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview in Le Monde and La Stampa
Key quote: In the light of these observations, there is no reason to change our strategy.
Rationale: While the speech recognizes the economic recovery within the eurozone, it also stresses caution due to continuing weak underlying inflationary pressures. Cœuré suggests a balanced approach, making adjustments carefully and only as needed based on the inflation outlook. This indicates a neutral stance with a likelihood of maintaining current policies.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in Le Monde and La Stampa, conducted by Ms Marie Charrel (Le Monde) and Mr Alessandro Barbera (La Stampa) on 3 July 2017 and published on 7 July 2017.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Convergence matters for monetary policy
Key quote: The recent broadening of the euro area recovery and the marked drop in cross-country dispersion in a number of economic indicators is an encouraging development.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the progress made in reducing economic disparities in the euro area and the effectiveness of current monetary policies, but it also highlights persistent structural issues, implying a cautious approach to monetary policy adjustments.
description: Speech by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Competitiveness Research Network (CompNet) conference on "Innovation, firm size, productivity and imbalances in the age of de-globalization", Brussels, 30 June 2017.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview with Bloomberg TV
Key quote: We are still not seeing inflation where we would like it to be; we're still not seeing the criteria that we've set for inflation to be sustainable all being met.
Rationale: While the ECB acknowledges improving economic conditions, Benoît Cœuré emphasizes the need for patience due to inflation not yet meeting the target criteria, indicating a cautious approach to policy change.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, and Bloomberg TV, conducted by Ms Francine Lacqua on 12 June 2017.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Greece - progress, challenges and the way forward
Key quote: Clarity about debt measures is also a necessary condition for Greek government bonds to be potentially eligible under the ECB's public sector purchase programme (PSPP).
Rationale: The speech highlights concerns about the fragile state of Greece's financial sector and the necessity for external stakeholders to contribute to Greek stability. The emphasis on restoring confidence and acknowledging challenges points to a dovish stance overall, aiming for stability rather than immediate tightening or easing.
description: Speech by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at a conference organised by The Economist "Greece: a comeback to the financial markets? A glimpse into Europe's financial landscape", Frankfurt am Main, 31 May 2017.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Scars or scratches? Hysteresis in the euro area
Key quote: And unlike 'classical' hysteresis, these scratches are currently reducing price pressures, warranting our currently very accommodative monetary policy stance.
Rationale: Benoît Cœuré is acknowledging the presence of economic challenges related to hysteresis and the need for accommodative monetary policy. However, he is circumspect about the effectiveness of policy in addressing structural issues and mentions the need to avoid overheating the economy. This cautious stance leans somewhat dovish, suggesting a continuation of current policies rather than any aggressive easing or tightening.
description: Speech by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the International Center for Monetary and Banking Studies, Geneva, 19 May 2017.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Dissecting the yield curve - central bank perspective
Key quote: This implies, and with this I would like to conclude, that the recent measurable increase in long-term yields has not affected our monetary policy stance: current financial conditions remain highly supportive of the ongoing recovery.
Rationale: Benoît Coeuré emphasizes that despite yield movements, the ECB's monetary policy remains accommodative, and there is no immediate concern to change the supportive stance, indicating a somewhat dovish position.
description: Welcome remarks by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the annual meeting of the ECB's Bond Market Contact Group, Frankfurt am Main, 16 May 2017.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Bond scarcity and the European Central Bank's asset purchase programme
Key quote: For monetary policy, the prevailing financial conditions should remain consistent, as they have been so far, with the monetary policy stance intended by the Governing Council.
Rationale: The speech discusses the European Central Bank's asset purchase programme and its effects on bond markets, while emphasizing monitoring and suggesting consistency with the current monetary policy stance. This implies a neutral position with no immediate need to alter rates.
description: Speech by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Club de Gestion Financière d'Associés en Finance, Paris, 3 April 2017.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Central bank communication in a low interest rate environment
Key quote: The latest incoming data have shifted the balance of risks for growth towards neutral territory in my view. But at the same time, measures of underlying inflation in the euro area remain subdued and our projected path of inflation still remains highly conditional on our policy stance.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the importance of clear communication and forward guidance in a low interest rate environment, and highlights ongoing uncertainties, particularly regarding inflation expectations. This suggests a somewhat dovish stance, prioritizing accommodation and communication over immediate tightening measures.
description: Speech by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at an event organised by Bruegel, Brussels, 31 March 2017.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview with Le Parisien
Key quote: The ECB has conducted a very expansionary monetary policy to stimulate inflation and employment, a necessary step for the euro area.
Rationale: Benoît Cœuré's comments focus on the benefits of the euro and the necessity of the ECB's expansionary monetary policy without suggesting immediate changes, indicating a neutral stance likely supporting holding the current policy rate.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, and Le Parisien, conducted by Ms Séverine Cazes and Mr Boris Cassel and published on 7 February 2017.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Outlook for monetary policy in the euro area
Key quote: The Governing Council continues to expect interest rates to remain at present or lower levels for an extended period of time, and well past the horizon of our net asset purchases.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the need for ongoing monetary stimulus and expresses caution about removing stimulus given that inflation is still reliant on ECB measures and that core inflation remains subdued. It suggests maintaining current policy until clear signs of sustainable inflation are evident, which aligns more with a dovish stance, but given existing measures are working, the probability leans towards holding rates rather than further cuts.
