description: Speech by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, to the Association d'Économie Financière, Paris, 2 February 2017.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview with Radio Classique
Key quote: Inflation is increasing, but for a reason which is very simple and easy to identify, which is the increase in commodity prices, or rather the end of a period marked by sharp falls in commodities.
Rationale: Cœuré suggests the rise in inflation is due to temporary factors such as commodity prices, which does not justify ending ECB's policy or increasing interest rates. He indicates that very low rates and quantitative easing will continue, signaling a somewhat dovish outlook.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, and Radio Classique, conducted by Mr Nicolas Pierron on 23 January 2017.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview with CNBC
Key quote: It's too early to have the discussion on when it ends, and even when we taper.
Rationale: Benoît Cœuré emphasizes that despite improvements in growth and inflation, it is premature to discuss ending QE or tapering, indicating a preference to maintain current monetary policy stance until more data is available, rather than raising rates, suggesting a 'Hold' bias.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, and CNBC, conducted by Ms Julia Chatterley in Davos on 20 January 2017.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview in Börsen-Zeitung
Key quote: The euro area will need monetary support for an extended period of time, but the amount of purchases can be reduced.
Rationale: Coeuré acknowledges that while the economic recovery is on track, there are still risks and uncertainties, particularly with core inflation remaining subdued. Thus, while there's a motion toward reducing asset purchases, a cautious approach is advised, denoting a somewhat dovish stance.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in Börsen-Zeitung, conducted by Mr Mark Schrörs and Mr Detlef Fechtner on 20 December 2016, and published on 31 December 2016.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview with Europe 1
Key quote: The euro area is recovering, it's getting better but it still needs its medicine - an accommodative monetary policy with low rates.
Rationale: The speech acknowledges improvements in the eurozone economy but emphasizes the continued need for accommodative monetary policy, indicating a somewhat dovish stance with a focus on supporting growth and inflation. The speaker seems likely to vote to hold rates at the next meeting, given the cautious optimism and recognition of ongoing economic risks.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, and Europe 1, conducted by Mr Jean-Pierre Elkabbach on 9 December 2016.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Greece - progress achieved and challenges ahead
Key quote: The important challenges Greece still faces today can only be addressed by a steady implementation of the agreed policies and strong political support from all stakeholders.
Rationale: The speech provides an assessment of the challenges and progress of Greece's economic program, focusing on structural reforms and fiscal sustainability. While acknowledging significant challenges, there is an emphasis on stability and the potential for positive outcomes, suggesting a neutral stance on monetary policy.
description: Keynote speech by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the American-Hellenic Chamber of Commerce conference on "Greece and the global disruptive environment: A look into the future", Athens, 28 November 2016.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview in Efimerida ton Syntakton
Key quote: Growth is returning in the euro area and this is largely due to monetary policy measures, notably our asset purchases, low interest rates and targeted lending operations.
Rationale: The speech focuses on the ongoing monetary policy measures and their positive impact on growth, suggests confidence in current strategies, and implies no immediate need for further easing or tightening—leaning towards a dovish stance with a likelihood of holding rates.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in Efimerida ton Syntakton, conducted by Mr Vasilis Georgas, and published on 26 November 2016.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Addressing Europe's economic and political challenges
Key quote: Monetary policy undeniably played a key role in stabilising the economy in Europe after the crisis.
Rationale: The speaker acknowledges the role of monetary policy in stabilizing the economy and emphasizes the need for fiscal policies to complement it. The speech does not indicate a change in policy direction, suggesting a neutral stance.
description: Introductory remarks by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at TUM Speakers Series/HEC Débats organised by the Technical University of Munich, Munich, 21 November 2016.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview in Le Progrès de Lyon and EBRA newspaper group
Key quote: The ECB's monetary policy will remain very accommodative until inflation is firmly on a path towards 2%.
Rationale: Cœuré emphasizes the continued need for an accommodative monetary policy to support the recovery and drive inflation towards the target, indicating a somewhat dovish stance. However, with the acknowledgment of strengthening recovery, it suggests a likelihood to hold rates rather than cut.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, conducted by Mr Frank Viart of Le Progrès de Lyon and published by EBRA newspaper group (L'Alsace, Les Dernières Nouvelles d'Alsace, Le Républicain Lorrain, L'Est Républicain, Vosges Matin, Le Bien Public, Le Journal de Saône-et-Loire, Le Progrès de Lyon, Le Dauphiné Libéré and Vaucluse Matin) on 11 November 2016.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Low interest rates are not inevitable
Key quote: A highly accommodative monetary policy remains appropriate, and will continue to be appropriate until inflation is firmly back on track and heading towards 2%.
Rationale: Benoît Cœuré emphasizes the need for a highly accommodative monetary policy given the current economic recovery phase and low inflation. He stresses that monetary policy should remain supportive until inflation is firmly on a path to 2%, suggesting dovish sentiment, although a shift to even more accommodative measures is unlikely. Therefore, next policy move is more likely to be a hold on rates.
description: Opinion piece by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in Les Echos, 9 November 2016.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Monetary policy in a low-growth environment
Key quote: Monetary support for the recovery will continue until inflation is sustainably adjusting to our objective.
Rationale: The speech is somewhat dovish because it emphasizes the continued need for accommodative monetary policy due to low growth and inflation risks. However, it acknowledges the effectiveness of current unconventional measures and the limits to low rates, suggesting a hold on further rate cuts.
description: Speech by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the 4th Frankfurt Conference on Financial Market Policy, organised by the Sustainable Architecture for Finance in Europe Policy Centre, Goethe University, Frankfurt am Main, 28 October 2016.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview in Süddeutsche Zeitung
Key quote: It will be a long time before we can even start to think about exiting our accommodative monetary policy.
Rationale: Benoît Cœuré emphasizes the continuation of asset purchases and acknowledges downside risks, suggesting a cautious approach to monetary policy adjustments, which implies a somewhat dovish stance. The statement indicates a readiness to extend accommodative policies if necessary, suggesting a high likelihood of holding rates.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in Süddeutsche Zeitung, conducted by Mr Markus Zydra on 22 September 2016, and published on 26 September 2016.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: The European Central Bank's operational framework in post-crisis times
Key quote: The ECB's operational framework and its monetary policy strategy are robust and sufficiently flexible to deal with the current challenges.
Rationale: The speech discusses both potential challenges and the flexibility of the ECB's current framework, showing no immediate inclination towards policy changes, suggesting a neutral stance.
description: Speech by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City Economic Symposium "Designing resilient monetary policy frameworks for the future", Jackson Hole, Wyoming, 27 August 2016.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Benoît Coeuré: Interview in Le Monde
Key quote: Negative rates are only one of the tools of our policy. They reinforce the effectiveness of asset purchases and thus increase the positive impact of our actions on growth.
Rationale: The speech acknowledges the use of negative interest rates and asset purchases as tools to stimulate growth, suggesting a slightly dovish stance. However, there is no indication of an immediate need to cut rates further, indicating a probable hold in the next meeting.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in Le Monde, conducted by Ms Marie Charrel on 27 June 2016, and published on 1 July 2016.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview with France 24
Key quote: Monetary policy has helped to boost growth in the euro area. Of course, it is not enough. You need reforms, you need productivity, you need projects to finance.
Rationale: The speech acknowledges both the positive impact of current monetary policy and the necessity for fiscal actions and structural reforms to complement it. There is no indication of any immediate change in policy, suggesting a 'hold' stance with a moderate level of certainty.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, with France 24, conducted by Ms Stéphanie Antoine on 8 June 2016, and broadcast on 9 June 2016.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview in The Yomiuri Shimbun
Key quote: In order to prevent euro area inflation from being too low for too long, the ECB has brought short-term interest rates to levels close to zero or negative, and is providing forward guidance on the future monetary policy stance.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the challenges of low growth and low inflation and highlights aggressive monetary easing measures, including negative interest rates and quantitative easing. Coeuré mentions there is currently no plan to cut rates further, suggesting a dovish stance focused on maintaining the current accommodative policies.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in The Yomiuri Shimbun, conducted by Mr Tadashi Isozumi in Japan.and published on 20 May 2016.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Benoît Coeuré: Government bond markets in a changing environment
Key quote: But even more importantly, our measures are essential to restore a more robust economic environment where inflation is in line with our mandate.
Rationale: The speech discusses the ECB's unconventional monetary policies like negative rates and asset purchases, justifying them as necessary to restore economic robustness. The tone is somewhat dovish, suggesting no rush to tighten policy.
description: Keynote address by Mr Benoît Coeuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Government Borrowers Forum, Paris, 3 May 2016.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Benoît Coeuré: People are not only savers
Key quote: At present, inflation in the euro area is around 0% and is expected to remain low for a considerable period of time. In this environment, we had to act decisively and provide significant monetary stimulus.
Rationale: The speech defends the ECB's low interest rate stance, affirming the need for monetary stimulus to support economic conditions and gradually raise inflation. This indicates a somewhat dovish position, though recognizing challenges, suggests the ECB may hold rates steady to continue support.
description: Opinion piece from Mr Benoît Coeuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, for the Frankfurter Allgemeine Sonntagszeitung, 1 May 2016.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview in Il Sole 24 Ore
Key quote: We announced a very strong package in March and have not implemented all the measures yet. All conventional and non-conventional instruments are available, but we are not having that discussion now.
Rationale: Benoît Cœuré signals that the ECB is not in a rush to implement further measures, indicating a preference to hold and observe the effects of previous policy actions. This points to a somewhat dovish stance as they wait to assess the outcomes before deciding on further action.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in Il Sole 24 Ore, conducted by Mr Alessandro Merli on 25 April and published on 27 April 2016.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview with Politico
Key quote: Negative interest rates are not our main instrument, they just support our overall policy.
Rationale: Benoît Cœuré emphasizes that while the ECB is concerned about banks' profitability, they are committed to bringing inflation back to target and have multiple instruments at their disposal. The speech suggests a cautious stance, likely resulting in holding the current policy rather than making cuts or hikes.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, and Politico, conducted by Mr Pierre Briançon on 23 March 2016, and published on 30 March 2016.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: The future of the euro area
Key quote: To preserve price stability, we have adopted an accommodative monetary policy stance that has no precedent.
Rationale: The speech reflects a commitment to a continued accommodative monetary policy, highlighting the ECB's recent substantial measures to support economic recovery and bring inflation back to target. It emphasizes the need for additional economic reforms beyond monetary policy, suggesting a dovish stance overall.
description: Remarks by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at Le Cercle Europartenaires, Paris, 21 March 2016.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: From challenges to opportunities - rebooting the European financial sector
Key quote: Our commitment to our price stability mandate is vital to anchor expectations of nominal growth.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the importance of reducing uncertainty and maintaining an accommodative monetary policy to support nominal growth and price stability, which suggests a dovish stance. However, there is recognition of the challenges faced by financial institutions, which slightly moderates the dovishness.
description: Speech by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the SZ (Süddeutsche Zeitung) Finance Day 2016, Frankfurt am Main, 2 March 2016.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Interview in Rheinische Post
Key quote: Rates will have to stay low until we see that the inflation rate in the euro area is moving towards our objective of just below 2%.
Rationale: This speech reflects concern about low global growth and downside risks to inflation. Cœuré mentions maintaining low rates for an extended period to support inflation and recovery, indicating a dovish stance. The probability that he would vote to 'Hold' is slightly higher because while he acknowledges new downside risks, no immediate action is suggested before the March assessment.
description: Interview with Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in Rheinische Post, conducted by Ms Birgit Marschall and Mr Georg Winters and published on 13 February 2016.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Time for a new Lamfalussy moment
Key quote: The Governing Council will review and possibly reconsider its stance when it meets in March.
Rationale: The speech highlights a range of economic challenges and the need for structural reforms and political convergence in Europe, but maintains a neutral tone regarding immediate monetary policy changes, indicating a likelihood of holding rates.
description: Speech by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Professor Lamfalussy Commemorative Conference, Budapest, 1 February 2016.

author: Benoît Cœuré
title: Rebalancing in the euro area - are we nearly there yet?
Key quote: Euro area countries have made substantial progress with rebalancing in recent years. But many still have a way to go to make rebalancing sustainable.
Rationale: Throughout the speech, there is a focus on structural reforms and the need for continued internal and external adjustments to achieve sustainable growth. While progress has been made, the many challenges outlined paint a cautious tone, leaning towards not making immediate aggressive rate changes but instead holding current policies to allow ongoing adjustments to take root.
description: Speech by Mr Benoît Cœuré, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, to the Danish Economic Society, Kolding, 15 January 2016.

author: Sabine Lautenschläger
title: Interview with Market News
Key quote: In my opinion, based on the current data, it is much too early for a huge package.
Rationale: Sabine Lautenschläger expresses skepticism about the need for a large monetary stimulus package, indicating her preference for holding off on aggressive measures like restarting the asset purchase program. She emphasizes the importance of seeing more data before deciding on further actions, which suggests a cautious and somewhat hawkish stance.
description: Interview with Ms Sabine Lautenschläger, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, and Market News, conducted by Mr Luke Heighton on 28 August 2019 and published on 30 August 2019.

author: Sabine Lautenschläger
title: Interview in Der Standard
Key quote: Our monetary policy has made an important contribution to boosting employment and wage growth.
Rationale: Sabine Lautenschläger emphasizes the necessity of the ECB's past measures, including low interest rates, to combat deflation and stimulate employment and wage growth, indicating a somewhat dovish outlook towards continued accommodative policy.
description: Interview with Ms Sabine Lautenschläger, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, in Der Standard, conducted by Mr András Szigètvari on 27 March 2019 and published on 1 April 2019.

author: Sabine Lautenschläger
title: Interview with Politico
Key quote: I'll wait for the projections coming in March before I change my view. I'm data-driven in this, and I think that as we are still in the environment we projected.
Rationale: The speaker maintains a data-driven approach and is not showing immediate concern or eagerness to change the current rates, indicating a neutral stance. She awaits further projections before making any decisions, suggesting a 'Hold' strategy for rates.
description: Interview by Ms Sabine Lautenschläger, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank and Vice-Chair of the Supervisory Board of the European Central Bank, with Politico, conducted by Politico on 14 January 2019 and published on 17 January 2019.

author: Sabine Lautenschläger
title: Interview with Deutschlandfunk
Key quote: I will be the first to vote in favour of further normalisation of monetary policy once the necessary conditions are in place.
Rationale: Lautenschläger notes that the ECB will maintain its accommodative policy due to ongoing economic growth needs and current inflation projections, indicating a somewhat dovish stance by suggesting that interest rates are unlikely to be raised soon and emphasizing the importance of waiting for favorable data.
description: Interview by Ms Sabine Lautenschläger, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank and Vice-Chair of the Supervisory Board of the European Central Bank, with Deutschlandfunk, conducted by Mr Klemens Kindermann and broadcast on 30 December 2018.

author: Sabine Lautenschläger
title: Interview with Agence France-Presse
Key quote: It is time to gradually normalize monetary policy.
Rationale: The speaker indicates a confidence in ending net asset purchases and hints at raising interest rates next year, suggesting a move towards tightening monetary policy. However, due to the current data-driven approach and near-term uncertainties, an immediate rate change might not occur, thus 'Hold' is the likely prediction.
description: Interview by Ms Sabine Lautenschläger, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank and Vice-Chair of the Supervisory Board of the European Central Bank, with Agence France-Presse, conducted by Agence France-Presse on 22 November 2018 and published on 26 November 2018.

author: Sabine Lautenschläger
title: Guardians of stability - central banks, supervisors and the quest for financial stability
Key quote: As regards monetary policy, we will work to maintain price stability.
Rationale: The speech primarily focuses on the importance of financial stability alongside price stability, without explicitly advocating changes to interest rates or monetary policy. While it acknowledges risks from an accommodative monetary stance, it does not suggest an immediate policy change, suggesting a neutral stance towards holding the policy rate.
description: Speech by Ms Sabine Lautenschläger, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank and Vice-Chair of the Supervisory Board of the European Central Bank, at the Central Bank of Malta, Valletta, 12 October 2018.

author: Sabine Lautenschläger
title: Interview with Welt am Sonntag
Key quote: I am very much in favour of normalising monetary policy. That implies that we should gradually increase interest rates again.
Rationale: Sabine Lautenschläger emphasizes the importance of normalizing monetary policy and suggests gradually increasing interest rates, which is a hawkish stance. However, she also stresses the need to be careful not to disrupt growth, indicating a balanced approach, slightly softening the hawkish tone.
description: Interview by Ms Sabine Lautenschläger, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank and Vice-Chair of the Supervisory Board of the European Central Bank, with Welt am Sonntag, conducted by Ms Anja Ettel and Ms Anne Kunz on 30 July 2018 and published on 5 August 2018.

author: Sabine Lautenschläger
title: Monetary policy - end of history?
Key quote: So, June might be the month to decide once and for all to gradually end net asset purchases by the end of this year.
Rationale: The speech indicates confidence in the economic expansion, yet acknowledges low inflation. Lautenschläger suggests a gradual exit from unconventional monetary policy and indicates a potential rate hike in mid-2019. This positions the speech as somewhat hawkish, signaling a shift toward normalization without immediate rate increases.
description: Speech by Ms Sabine Lautenschläger, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank and Vice-Chair of the Supervisory Board of the European Central Bank, at the Center for Financial Studies Colloquium, Frankfurt am Main, 29 May 2018.

author: Sabine Lautenschläger
title: Between low interest rates and bond purchases - has European monetary policy reached a dead end?
Key quote: My opinion is clear: we should begin to scale back our bond purchases at the beginning of next year.
Rationale: Sabine Lautenschläger emphasizes the need to start reducing bond purchases, signaling a shift towards tightening monetary policy. However, there's no mention of an immediate need to increase rates, suggesting a more cautious approach to removing stimulus.
description: Speech by Ms Sabine Lautenschläger, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank and Vice-Chair of the Supervisory Board of the European Central Bank, at the Hohenheim University, Stuttgart, 9 October 2017.

author: Sabine Lautenschläger
title: Monetary policy - what's next?
Key quote: Hence, it is time to take a decision now on scaling back our bond purchases at the beginning of next year.
Rationale: The speech acknowledges the need for ongoing monetary accommodation but emphasizes readiness to scale back bond purchases, indicating a shift towards less accommodative policy. However, given the current conditions, the prediction is to hold rates in the near term, while laying the groundwork for future tightening.
description: Statement by Ms Sabine Lautenschläger, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank and Vice-Chair of the Supervisory Board of the European Central Bank, at the Eurofi Financial Forum, Tallinn, 15 September 2017.

author: Sabine Lautenschläger
title: Interview with Mannheimer Morgen
Key quote: The expansionary monetary policy has both advantages and side effects. As time passes, the positive effects get weaker and the risks increase. So it's important to prepare for the exit in good time.
Rationale: Lautenschläger acknowledges the need to prepare for an exit from the expansionary monetary policy due to increasing risks, indicating a somewhat hawkish stance. However, she also notes that inflation is not yet at the target, suggesting a more cautious approach, likely voting to hold rates in the upcoming meeting.
description: Interview by Ms Sabine Lautenschläger, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank and Vice-Chair of the Supervisory Board of the European Central Bank, with Mannheimer Morgen, conducted by Mr Rolf Obertreis on 25 July and published on 29 July 2017.

author: Sabine Lautenschläger
title: Stability and growth in the euro area - who plays the leading role?
Key quote: Nonetheless, I consider it imperative that monetary policy should return to normal as soon as can be justified.
Rationale: Lautenschläger acknowledges the need for a loose monetary policy in the past but highlights concerns about potential risks like asset bubbles. She emphasizes a return to normal monetary policy, indicating a somewhat hawkish stance. However, given that inflation is not yet on a stable path, she might favor holding rates at the next meeting.
description: Speech by Ms Sabine Lautenschläger, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank and Vice-Chair of the Supervisory Board of the Single Supervisory Mechanism, at the IEP (Institut für Europäische Politik) Mittagsgespräch, Berlin, 30 June 2017.

author: Sabine Lautenschläger
title: Interview with Deutschlandfunk
Key quote: I am one of the most optimistic ones, who want to return to a normalisation of the very expansive monetary policy as soon as possible.
Rationale: Although Ms. Lautenschläger recognizes the importance of moving towards policy normalization, she emphasizes caution against premature tightening given uncertainties about inflation. She is optimistic but stresses the need to ensure inflation trends confirmatively before changing the policy, indicating a dovish stance with a focus on holding rates until more data is available.
description: Interview by Ms Sabine Lautenschläger, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank and Vice-Chair of the Supervisory Board of the Single Supervisory Mechanism, with Deutschlandfunk, conducted by Mr Klemens Kindermann and published on 19 February 2017.

author: Sabine Lautenschläger
title: The test of progress - Europe, the euro and the future
Key quote: I am thus optimistic that we can soon turn to the question of an exit. That's why we need to be ready to act when the time comes.
Rationale: Lautenschläger acknowledges the improvements in the euro area economy and the rise in inflation but emphasizes the need for caution regarding temporary inflation spikes. Her overall stance suggests careful optimism without a clear push for immediate changes, indicating a likelihood to hold rates steady.
description: Speech by Ms Sabine Lautenschläger, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank and Vice-Chair of the Supervisory Board of the Single Supervisory Mechanism, at the Übersee-Club Hamburg, Hamburg, 24 January 2017.

author: Sabine Lautenschläger
title: Two years and three days of European banking supervision - what has changed?
Key quote: But that doesn't change the fact that I'm very sceptical as far as further interest rate cuts or additional expansionary monetary policy measures are concerned - over time, the benefits of these measures decrease, while the risks increase.
Rationale: The speech acknowledges the challenges of low interest rates and suggests skepticism towards further cuts, indicating a cautious approach to monetary expansion. The focus is on the structural issues facing banks and not aggressively advocating for rate changes, suggesting a bias towards holding rates.
description: Speech by Ms Sabine Lautenschläger, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank and Vice-Chair of the Supervisory Board of the Single Supervisory Mechanism, at the Banking and Corporate Evening of the Deutsche Bundesbank s Regional Office in Bavaria, Munich, 7 November 2016.

author: Sabine Lautenschläger
title: Interview in Süddeutsche Zeitung
Key quote: In the long term, the low interest rate environment can represent a considerable challenge, in particular for banks in the traditional lending business.
Rationale: The speaker highlights the increased resilience of banks and suggests that the measures in place are adequate, suggesting neither an urgent need for rate cuts nor a pressing case for hikes. The tone is slightly towards maintaining stability rather than easing monetary conditions, indicating a 'Hold' stance.
description: Interview with Ms Sabine Lautenschläger, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank and Vice-Chair of the Supervisory Board of the Single Supervisory Mechanism, in Süddeutsche Zeitung, conducted by Ms Meike Schreiber and Mr Markus Zydra and published on 2 November 2016.

author: Sabine Lautenschläger
title: Interview in Börsen-Zeitung
Key quote: At the moment, I do not see any need for any additional stimulus.
Rationale: Sabine Lautenschläger expresses confidence in the current policy direction and sees no need for additional stimulus or rate cuts. She emphasizes a balanced approach, considering both benefits and potential risks of the current monetary policy, and indicates that current policies appear effective.
description: Interview with Ms Sabine Lautenschläger, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank and Vice-Chair of the Supervisory Board of the Single Supervisory Mechanism, in Börsen-Zeitung, conducted by Mr Mark Schrörs and published on 30 September 2016.

author: Sabine Lautenschläger
title: Monetary policy in uncertain times - the European Central Bank and the crisis
Key quote: Against this background I have my doubts about the benefits of further interest rate cuts - especially when we compare the benefits with the costs.
Rationale: The speech recognizes the role of negative interest rates in supporting the economy and the risks of reducing interest rates further. The emphasis is on caution and patience rather than aggressively pursuing additional rate cuts.
description: Speech by Ms Sabine Lautenschläger, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank and Vice-Chair of the Supervisory Board of the Single Supervisory Mechanism, at a Parliamentary evening, Strasbourg, 13 September 2016.

author: Sabine Lautenschläger
title: The euro - idea and reality
Key quote: The ECB alone cannot create growth and prosperity for all. For that, structural reforms are necessary - at national and European level.
Rationale: The speech primarily focuses on structural reforms and the role of European integration, emphasizing that monetary policy alone cannot solve underlying issues. It does not indicate a clear move towards altering the policy rate, suggesting a neutral stance towards holding rates steady.
description: Speech by Ms Sabine Lautenschläger, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank and Vice-Chair of the Supervisory Board of the Single Supervisory Mechanism, at the Europa Forum Luzern, Luzern, 2 May 2016.

author: Vítor Constâncio
title: Interview with Spiegel Online
Key quote: The Governing Council of the ECB decided that the Eurosystem will continue to purchase assets at a rate of €30 billion each month until the end of September, and that interest rates should remain at their current levels beyond the end of the purchase programme.
Rationale: Constâncio stresses the continuation of asset purchases and maintains that interest rates will stay at current levels beyond the purchase program. This indicates a somewhat dovish stance with a likelihood of holding rates at the next meeting.
description: Interview with Mr Vítor Constâncio, Vice-President of the European Central Bank, and Spiegel Online, conducted by Mr Stefan Kaiser and Mr Henning Jauernig on 22 May 2018 and published on 29 May 2018.

author: Vítor Constâncio
title: Interview in the Financial Times
Key quote: Presumably, interest rates by then would not be sufficiently high for a reduction in rates to be a sufficient response.
Rationale: The speech suggests potential for future monetary easing and acknowledges limitations if rates need to be lowered. However, there is no immediate call for rate cuts, favoring steady policy for now.
description: Interview with Mr Vítor Constâncio, Vice-President of the European Central Bank, in the Financial Times, conducted by Ms Claire Jones on 11 May and published on 16 May 2018.

author: Vítor Constâncio
title: Past and future of the European Central Bank monetary policy
Key quote: At present, we have started a very cautious withdrawal of monetary accommodation.
Rationale: The speech provides a retrospective analysis of ECB monetary policy without signaling a need for immediate policy changes. Constâncio highlights the continuation of a cautious approach, indicating a tendency to maintain current policy measures rather than shift towards tightening or loosening.
description: Speech by Mr Vítor Constâncio, Vice-President of the European Central Bank, at the Conference on "Central Banks in Historical Perspective: What Changed After the Financial Crisis?", organised by the Central Bank of Malta, Valletta, 4 May 2018.

author: Vítor Constâncio
title: Presentation of the European Central Bank Annual Report 2017 to the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the European Parliament
Key quote: This recalibration preserved the ample degree of monetary accommodation required to secure a sustained return of inflation rates towards our aim.
Rationale: While the euro area growth was strong, inflation remained subdued. The ECB's approach emphasized patience, persistence, and prudence, extending asset purchases and supporting monetary accommodation to ensure inflation targets are met.
description: Introductory remarks by Mr Vítor Constâncio, Vice-President of the European Central Bank, to the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the European Parliament, Brussels, 9 April 2018.

author: Vítor Constâncio
title: Interview in La Repubblica
Key quote: We see no inflation risks. We should not choke off growth too soon.
Rationale: The speech indicates a continued accommodative stance due to weak inflation and gradual policy adjustments, reflecting a somewhat dovish position with no immediate changes expected.
description: Interview with Mr Vítor Constâncio, Vice-President of the European Central Bank, in La Repubblica, conducted by Ms Tonia Mastrobuoni on 15 January and published on 17 January 2018.

author: Vítor Constâncio
title: Challenges for euro area monetary policy in early 2018
Key quote: It is therefore possible for us to scale back our net asset purchases, while keeping our policy sufficiently accommodative to support those inflation dynamics.
Rationale: While the speech acknowledges the need to reduce asset purchases, it emphasizes maintaining some level of accommodation to support inflation dynamics, indicating a somewhat hawkish stance but with a likelihood of holding rates steady.
description: Speech by Mr Vítor Constâncio, Vice-President of the European Central Bank, at the 32nd International ZinsFORUM, Frankfurt am Main, 6 December 2017.

author: Vítor Constâncio
title: Economic recovery and the new phase of monetary policy
Key quote: Monetary policy will have to continue to be very accommodative, assuring favourable financial conditions to foster growth and spur wages and prices.
Rationale: The speech describes the continuation of accommodative monetary policy due to subdued inflation, highlighting the need for patience and persistence in maintaining current policies while acknowledging economic recovery and remaining challenges.
description: Keynote speech by Mr Vítor Constâncio, Vice-President of the European Central Bank, at the Opening Conference of the 20th Euro Finance Week, Frankfurt am Main, 13 November 2017.

author: Vítor Constâncio
title: The evolving risk landscape in the euro area
Key quote: Monetary policy, even when recalibrated, will continue to keep a very accommodative stance in order to attain the price stability objective in a self-sustained way.
Rationale: The speech highlights the ECB's commitment to maintaining an accommodative monetary policy despite economic recovery, suggesting a cautious approach to policy changes, which leans towards a dovish stance.
description: Speech by Mr Vítor Constâncio, Vice-President of the European Central Bank, at the Bank of Portugal Conference on Financial Stability, Lisbon, 17 October 2017.

author: Vítor Constâncio
title: Growth in a more resilient Euro area
Key quote: Despite robust growth dynamics, inflation developments have been subdued.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the continued need for substantial monetary accommodation to achieve inflation targets, suggesting a dovish stance but with recognition of ongoing economic improvement, leading to a likely hold on rates.
description: Remarks by Mr Vítor Constâncio, Vice-President of the European Central Bank, on a panel entitled "The Global Economy: Prospects for Broad-Based Growth", at the 32nd Annual G30 International Banking Seminar, Washington DC, 15 October 2017.

author: Vítor Constâncio
title: Developing models for policy analysis in central banks
Key quote: The protracted recovery seems to give ground to the old view of monetary policy effectiveness being asymmetric and weaker in recessions.
Rationale: Vítor Constâncio's speech emphasizes the need for updated macroeconomic models at the ECB, suggesting a balanced approach to monetary policy while acknowledging limitations in conventional policy's effects during recessions. This indicates a neutral stance with a likely prediction to hold current rates.
description: Opening speech by Mr Vítor Constâncio, Vice-President of the European Central Bank, at the Annual Research Conference, Frankfurt am Main, 25 September 2017.

author: Vítor Constâncio
title: Role and effects of the ECB non-standard policy measures
Key quote: By keeping a sufficient degree of monetary policy accommodation we can be confident that our goal will eventually be reached, in accordance with our mandate.
Rationale: The speech highlights the importance of maintaining monetary accommodation and the use of non-standard measures to support the economy and fight deflation. It acknowledges the success of these measures while remaining cautiously optimistic about inflation goals. This tone suggests a wait-and-see approach, favoring holding rates.
description: Remarks by Mr Vítor Constâncio, Vice-President of the European Central Bank, at the ECB Workshop "Monetary Policy in Non-Standard Times", Frankfurt am Main, 11 and 12 September 2017.

author: Vítor Constâncio
title: Growth, adjustment and resilience in the euro area
Key quote: It is clear that the euro area recovery is becoming increasingly robust.
Rationale: Constâncio acknowledges the ongoing recovery in the euro area and the need for structural reforms but does not signal a shift in monetary policy. His emphasis on resilience and the challenges ahead suggests a steady approach, hence a neutral stance regarding policy changes.
description: Remarks by Mr Vítor Constâncio, Vice-President of the European Central Bank, at the Forum Villa d'Este, Cernobbio, 1 September 2017.

author: Vítor Constâncio
title: Inequality and macroeconomic policies
Key quote: First, given the slow-moving nature of inequality, one could argue that the prevailing monetary policy regime, defining long term goals, is likely to be the most important factor through which central banks may influence the distribution of income and wealth.
Rationale: The speech discusses how inequality and long-term factors are influenced by monetary policy, but does not suggest immediate changes to monetary policy. The implications for policy are tentative and acknowledge the limitations of monetary policy in addressing inequality, suggesting a 'Hold' approach.
description: Intervention by Mr Vítor Constâncio, Vice-President of the European Central Bank, at the Annual Congress of the European Economic Association, Lisbon, 22 August 2017.

author: Vítor Constâncio
title: Interview with CNBC
Key quote: If we want to bring inflation to our target of below but close to 2%, then we have to persist in the type of monetary policy that we have been adopting.
Rationale: Constâncio's emphasis on persistence in current monetary policy and the acknowledgment of slack in the economy suggest a cautious approach to tightening. Despite market perceptions of hawkishness, the overall tone is more supportive of continuing accommodative measures.
description: Interview with Mr Vítor Constâncio, Vice-President of the European Central Bank, and CNBC, conducted by Ms Annette Weisbach in Sintra on 27 June, published 28 June 2017.

author: Vítor Constâncio
title: The future of monetary policy frameworks
Key quote: The continuation of such monetary stimulus remains important to ensure a sustainable adjustment of the inflation process towards levels consistent with the ECB price stability objective.
Rationale: Constâncio emphasizes the importance of maintaining monetary stimulus to support the euro area's recovery and achieve the ECB's inflation target, indicating a dovish stance. However, the speech also discusses the need to evaluate future monetary strategies, suggesting openness to change and innovation but stressing caution.
description: Lecture by Mr Vítor Constâncio, Vice-President of the European Central Bank, at the Instituto Superior de Economia e Gestão, Lisbon, 25 May 2017.

author: Vítor Constâncio
title: Presentation of the European Central Bank Annual Report 2016 to the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the European Parliament
Key quote: Our monetary policy stance is appropriate and a reassessment is not warranted at this stage.
Rationale: Constâncio acknowledges the improvements in the economy but notes that monetary support is still essential. This indicates a somewhat dovish stance, aiming to hold rates while supporting the economic recovery.
description: Introductory remarks by Mr Vítor Constâncio, Vice-President of the European Central Bank, to the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the European Parliament, Brussels, 10 April 2017.

author: Vítor Constâncio
title: Effectiveness of Monetary Union and the Capital Markets Union
Key quote: But it is too soon to declare complete success: we have yet to secure a sustained convergence in inflation towards our goal of close to but below 2% over the medium term.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the need to continue monetary accommodation due to insufficient inflation convergence and highlights the positive effects of current policies without signaling any immediate change. The focus is on maintaining support rather than tightening policy, suggesting a 'Hold' decision with moderate confidence.
description: Speech by Mr Vítor Constâncio, Vice-President of the European Central Bank, at the EUROFI Conference, Malta, 6 April 2017.

author: Vítor Constâncio
title: Effectiveness of Monetary Union and the Capital Markets Union
Key quote: The ECB's monetary policy measures have been a key contributor to these positive developments, and the only expansionary macroeconomic policy in support of the recovery.
Rationale: The speech highlights the positive contributions of the ECB's monetary policy, including reductions in bank lending rates and improved financing conditions, suggesting a supportive stance rather than tightening or easing further. This suggests a bias towards maintaining current policy, hence 'Hold', but with some dovish undertones due to continued reliance on expansionary measures.
description: Contribution of Mr Vítor Constâncio, Vice-President of the European Central Bank, for the magazine of the Eurofi conference in Malta (5-7 April 2017), 4 April 2017.

author: Vítor Constâncio
title: Interview in Bankfokus
Key quote: We need more expansionary macroeconomic policies as well as reforms in competition and in the regulation of markets to foster the supply side of the economy.
Rationale: Constâncio emphasizes the need for more expansionary policies beyond monetary measures, suggesting a slightly accommodative stance, but not strongly dovish as he does not advocate for monetary policy changes. Hence, he is likely to advocate for holding rates.
description: Interview with Mr Vítor Constâncio, Vice-President of the European Central Bank, and Bankfokus, conducted by Mr Pär Krause and published on 13 December 2016.

author: Vítor Constâncio
title: Euro area - economic outlook and financial sector challenges
Key quote: Securing sustained economic growth and employment cannot be dependent on monetary policy alone.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the need for continued expansionary monetary policy and highlights ongoing risks and challenges. The speaker acknowledges the necessity for supportive financial conditions and indicates confidence in the ECB's measures, while also recognizing the need for additional fiscal policy and structural reforms.
description: Speech by Mr Vítor Constâncio, Vice-President of the European Central Bank, at the 19th Euro Finance Week: Opening conference, Frankfurt am Main, 14 November 2016.

author: Vítor Constâncio
title: Challenges for future monetary policy frameworks - a European perspective
Key quote: Central bankers should, however, avoid such hubris and accept that, at present, the contributions of fiscal, regulatory and competition policies are necessary to foster investment and improve the supply side of our economies.
Rationale: Constâncio discusses the limitations and potential negative effects of monetary policy tools like negative interest rates, and stresses the need for other policies to support economic growth, indicating a somewhat dovish stance.
description: Speech by Mr Vítor Constâncio, Vice-President of the European Central Bank, at the 19th Annual International Banking Conference "Achieving Financial Stability: Challenges to Prudential Regulation", Chicago, 4 November 2016.

author: Vítor Constâncio
title: Securing sustained economic growth in the euro area
Key quote: Monetary policy has done most of the expansionary effort to support the recovery. Yet, securing sustained economic growth and employment cannot be dependent on monetary policy alone.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the importance of non-monetary policy measures and structural reforms for economic growth, while acknowledging that monetary policy has largely supported the recovery. This suggests a somewhat accommodative stance, yet the speaker does not argue for immediate further easing, leaning towards holding rates.
description: Speech by Mr Vítor Constâncio, Vice-President of the European Central Bank, at the G30 Meeting, Washington DC, 9 October 2016.

author: Vítor Constâncio
title: The challenge of low real interest rates for monetary policy
Key quote: Monetary policy is therefore part of the solution and not part of the problem. By ensuring low interest rates, monetary policy is supporting and accelerating the recovery...
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the importance of maintaining low interest rates to support economic recovery and counteract low equilibrium rates, which suggests a dovish stance but also signals the necessity to potentially hold rates to monitor their impacts.
description: Lecture by Mr Vítor Constâncio, Vice-President of the European Central Bank, at the Macroeconomics Symposium, Utrecht School of Economics, Utrecht,15 June 2016.

author: Vítor Constâncio
title: The outlook for the global economy
Key quote: The continuation of our accommodative monetary policy needs to be supported by a determined implementation of structural reforms.
Rationale: Vítor Constâncio's speech emphasizes the importance of accommodative monetary policy to support recovery and achieve inflation targets. The mention of economic fragility and the need for structural reforms, along with the aim of steering inflation closer to 2%, suggests a somewhat dovish stance, likely leading to a hold in policy rates.
description: Remarks by Mr Vítor Constâncio, Vice-President of the European Central Bank, at City Week, London, 9 May 2016.

author: Vítor Constâncio
title: International headwinds and the effectiveness of monetary policy
Key quote: Against this background, it is important to emphasise that, while having to resort to nonstandard tools, monetary policies also remain effective in fighting the global liquidity trap even against international headwinds.
Rationale: The speech highlights the need for expansive monetary policy to combat low growth, low inflation, and liquidity traps, indicative of a dovish stance. While acknowledging monetary policy's effectiveness, the emphasis on ongoing challenges suggests a likelihood of holding rates to assess effects of current policies.
description: Speech by Mr Vítor Constâncio, Vice-President of the European Central Bank, at the 25th Annual Hyman P Minsky Conference on the State of the US and World Economies at the Levy Economics Institute of Bard College, Blithewood, Annandale-on-Hudson, New York, 13 April 2016.

author: Vítor Constâncio
title: Presentation of the European Central Bank Annual Report 2015 to the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the European Parliament
Key quote: The ECB has done and, within its mandate, will continue to do whatever is needed to pursue its price stability objective which now implies also trying to foster growth.
Rationale: Constâncio acknowledges weak inflation dynamics and global uncertainties, highlighting the ECB's accommodative measures and openness to further action, suggesting a somewhat dovish stance but uncertainty on raising rates leads to a 'Hold' prediction.
description: Introductory remarks by Mr Vítor Constâncio, Vice-President of the European Central Bank, to the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the European Parliament, Brussels, 7 April 2016.

author: Vítor Constâncio
title: In defence of monetary policy
Key quote: To normalise inflation in the euro area we urgently need higher growth that can reduce negative output and unemployment gaps, using all really available policies.
Rationale: The speech is defending the use of monetary policy amid calls for other policies. It highlights the effectiveness of monetary policy in preventing deflation, implying support for accommodative measures and potentially further rate cuts if needed.
description: Opinion piece by Mr Vítor Constâncio, Vice-President of the European Central Bank, 11 March 2016.

author: Christine Lagarde
title: Follow the money: channelling savings into investment and innovation in Europe
Key quote: Today, I have laid out a framework to refocus our efforts, with the aim of providing the precision and direction we need to break the deadlock.
Rationale: The speech focuses on issues related to capital markets union and investment in Europe, rather than directly addressing monetary policy or interest rate decisions. The emphasis is on structural reforms to channel savings into investments, not on policy rate adjustments.
description: Speech by Christine Lagarde, President of the ECB, at the 34th European Banking Congress: "Out of the Comfort Zone: Europe and the New World Order"

author: Christine Lagarde
title: The economic and human challenges of a transforming era
Key quote: The rapid pace of technological change triggered by the digital revolution has left us trailing behind. We need to adapt quickly to a changing geopolitical environment and regain lost ground in competitiveness and innovation.
Rationale: The speech does not directly address monetary policy or interest rates, focusing instead on broader economic and geopolitical themes. Given the lack of focus on monetary policy, the speaker would likely hold the current policy rate.
description: Speech by Christine Lagarde, President of the ECB, at "Les Essentiels des Bernardins", Paris

author: Christine Lagarde
title: Welcome address at the tenth anniversary of the Single Supervisory Mechanism
Key quote: It is a pleasure to welcome you to this event celebrating the tenth anniversary of the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM).
Rationale: This speech primarily focuses on the achievements of the Single Supervisory Mechanism and the European banking sector's stability and integration. It does not discuss monetary policy or provide insights on potential changes to interest rates, making it more relevant to banking supervision than monetary policy decisions.
description: Welcome address by Christine Lagarde, President of the ECB, at the tenth anniversary of the Single Supervisory Mechanism

author: Christine Lagarde
title: Competition policy in a changing world
Key quote: Competition policy in Europe has always played an important role in ensuring the functioning of our Economic and Monetary Union.
Rationale: The speech is primarily focused on competition policy and its impact on economic frameworks, not directly on monetary policy or interest rate decisions.
description: Speech by Christine Lagarde, President of the ECB, at an event to mark the 15th anniversary of the Autorité de la concurrence

author: Christine Lagarde
title: Lessons from Ljubljana in uncertain times
Key quote: In today’s uncertain world, Europe must learn “to stand and withstand”.
Rationale: The speech focused on cultural and economic resilience lessons from Slovenia, without directly addressing monetary policy or providing guidance on interest rates.
description: Speech by Christine Lagarde, President of the ECB, at the official dinner of Banka Slovenije in Ljubljana, Slovenia

author: Christine Lagarde
title: Technology as a new frontier for macroprudential policy
Key quote: Macroprudential policy must evolve to meet these new frontiers.
Rationale: The speech addresses macroprudential policy and technological risks rather than monetary policy, so it is not directly relevant to assessing the ECB's next interest rate decision. However, it hints at potential risks to financial stability that could influence future policy considerations.
description: Welcome address by Christine Lagarde, President of the ECB and Chair of the European Systemic Risk Board, at the eighth annual conference of the ESRB

author: Christine Lagarde
title: Central banks in a changing world: the role of the European Central Bank in the face of climate and environmental risks
Key quote: As central bankers, we are now facing a fundamentally different environment: one characterised by more instability, more volatility and more uncertainty about the very structure of the economy.
Rationale: Christine Lagarde focuses on climate and environmental risks throughout her speech, highlighting the ECB's role in addressing these within its mandate. There is no direct mention of adjusting interest rates or the current economic outlook, suggesting a neutral stance on monetary policy.
description: Speech by Ms Christine Lagarde, President of the European Central Bank, at the Maurice Allais Foundation, Paris, 7 June 2024.

author: Christine Lagarde
title: Unlocking the power of ideas
Key quote: It is by generating new ideas, and creating the conditions in which they can spread and flourish through our economy, that we can drive future growth.
Rationale: The speech by Christine Lagarde mainly focuses on the role of ideas and innovation in driving economic growth, particularly in the context of Europe facing global economic changes. It does not directly address monetary policy or interest rates.
description: Speech by Ms Christine Lagarde, President of the European Central Bank, at Yale University, New Haven, Connecticut, 22 April 2024.

author: Christine Lagarde
title: Building confidence in the path ahead
Key quote: We are not yet sufficiently confident that we are on a sustainable path towards our inflation target.
Rationale: The speech indicates that while progress has been made towards achieving the inflation target, there remains uncertainty about domestic price pressures and sustainable disinflation. It suggests a cautionary approach, implying a hold on interest rates until more data affirms alignment with inflation projections, but it hints at potential future rate cuts contingent on confirming disinflationary trends.
description: Speech by Ms Christine Lagarde, President of the European Central Bank, at "The ECB and Its Watchers XXIV" conference, organised by the Institute for Monetary and Financial Stability, Frankfurt am Main, 20 March 2024.

author: Christine Lagarde
title: Welcome address - fifth European Central Bank Forum on Banking Supervision
Key quote: European banking supervision has not only empowered our monetary policy response to the pandemic, but also facilitated our fight against inflation by readying banks for the new environment.
Rationale: The speech primarily discusses banking supervision and its interaction with monetary policy but does not indicate any immediate changes to monetary policy stance. It acknowledges the strong position of banks in the current environment, which supports maintaining the current policy rate.
description: Speech by Ms Christine Lagarde, President of the European Central Bank, at the 5th European Central Bank Forum on Banking Supervision "Europe: banking on resilience", Frankfurt am Main, 30 November 2023.

author: Christine Lagarde
title: Hearing of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the European Parliament
Key quote: We remain determined to ensure the timely return of inflation to our 2% medium-term target.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the determination to return inflation to target by maintaining current interest rates. Although there are challenges like geopolitical tensions and climate crisis, there isn't a strong indication towards changing rates but rather a focus on holding them for stability.
description: Speech by Ms Christine Lagarde, President of the European Central Bank, at the Hearing of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the European Parliament, Brussels, 27 November 2023.

author: Christine Lagarde
title: A Kantian shift for the capital markets union
Key quote: Faced with such an immense financing challenge, the moment for action is now. So I encourage all of us to be bold and not to let this moment pass.
Rationale: The speech primarily focuses on the development of a Capital Markets Union in Europe, its challenges, and the necessary steps to achieve it. It does not directly address monetary policy or implications for interest rate changes.
description: Speech by Ms Christine Lagarde, President of the European Central Bank, at the European Banking Congress, Frankfurt am Main, 17 November 2023.

author: Christine Lagarde
title: The European Systemic Risk Board's first general warning one year on
Key quote: To date, Europe's financial system has avoided the worst-case scenario of severe systemic risks materialising at the same time. But policymakers need to remain proactive and alert to financial stability risks as and when they arise.
Rationale: Lagarde's speech mainly focuses on financial stability and macroprudential policy rather than immediate monetary policy changes. While she acknowledges some risks, she doesn't indicate an immediate need for a policy rate change, suggesting stability in the current policy, which supports a 'Hold' prediction.
description: Welcome remarks by Ms Christine Lagarde, President of the European Central Bank and Chair of the European Systemic Risk Board, at the 7th Annual Conference of the European Systemic Risk Board "Financial stability challenges ahead: emerging risks and regulation", Frankfurt am Main, 16 November 2023.

author: Christine Lagarde
title: Welcome address - ECB conference on monetary policy
Key quote: Now, based on our current assessment, we consider that the key ECB interest rates have reached levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to the timely return of inflation to our medium-term target.
Rationale: Christine Lagarde's speech suggests that the ECB believes current rates are at a level conducive to meeting inflation targets if maintained for a prolonged period. The emphasis on maintaining current interest levels indicates a neutral stance, likely favoring holding rates steady.
description: Welcome address by Ms Christine Lagarde, President of the European Central Bank, at the European Central Bank Conference on Monetary Policy: bridging science and practice, Frankfurt am Main, 4 October 2023.

author: Christine Lagarde
title: Towards an orderly energy transition
Key quote: For the ECB, the most important contribution we can make is to maintain price stability.
Rationale: The speech focuses on the challenges and strategies of a green energy transition rather than monetary policy. There are mentions of maintaining price stability and the impact of climate policy on inflation, suggesting a neutral stance without clear signals on adjusting interest rates.
description: Opening remarks by Ms Christine Lagarde, President of the European Central Bank, at the joint IEA-ECB-EIB High-Level International Conference on "Ensuring an orderly energy transition: Europe's competitiveness and financial stability in a period of global energy transformation", Paris, 29 September 2023.

author: Christine Lagarde
title: A Mediterranean Odyssey -  from ancient origins to future strength
Key quote: For our part, at the ECB we are committed to maintaining price stability for the euro area. That is why since July last year we have raised interest rates ten times, and why we acted again last week to reinforce progress towards our inflation target.
Rationale: The speech focuses on broader economic and ecological challenges rather than monetary policy specifics, but it does affirm the ECB's commitment to price stability. Given the emphasis on maintaining stability and recent rate hikes, this suggests a neutral stance with a leaning towards holding rates steady at the next meeting.
description: Speech by Ms Christine Lagarde, President of the European Central Bank, and Mr Luis de Guindos, Vice-President of the European Central Bank, at the Mediterranean Meetings, Marseille, 21 September 2023.

author: Christine Lagarde
title: Strengthening resilience in a changing geopolitical landscape
Key quote: Our monetary policy plays an important anchoring role for the CESEE region, as the euro is widely used in trade invoicing and financing.
Rationale: The speech primarily focuses on geopolitical issues, particularly concerning the CESEE region, and does not provide specific insights into monetary policy direction or interest rates.
description: Welcome address by Ms Christine Lagarde, President of the European Central Bank, at the 9th ECB conference on central, eastern and south-eastern European countries, Frankfurt am Main, 17 July 2023.

author: Christine Lagarde
title: Remarks at the Summit for a new global financing pact
Key quote: Third, central banks around the world can and must, within their mandates, support the greening of the financial system.
Rationale: This speech primarily focuses on climate change and the roles of governments and financial institutions in supporting the transition to a green economy. There is no direct discussion related to monetary policy or interest rates, so the content is not relevant for a monetary policy analysis.
description: Speech by Ms Christine Lagarde, President of the European Central Bank, at the Summit for a new global financing pact, Paris, 23 June 2023.

author: Christine Lagarde
title: North Rhine-Westphalia State Prize - laudatory speech
Key quote: Dear Angela, you were an exceptional leader in exceptional times.
Rationale: The speech is a laudatory address in honor of Angela Merkel and does not discuss monetary policy or economic conditions, therefore it is not related to central banking or monetary policy decisions.
description: Laudatory speech by Ms Christine Lagarde, President of the European Central Bank, for Angela Merkel at the award ceremony for the North Rhine-Westphalia State Prize, Cologne, 16 May 2023.

author: Christine Lagarde
title: Empowering women in a changing global economy
Key quote: It is a pleasure to be here at the WTO to discuss women and the economy on such an important occasion: International Women's Day.
Rationale: The speech by Christine Lagarde focuses on the topic of women's empowerment in the economy, particularly in relation to trade and geopolitical tensions. It does not pertain to monetary policy or provide insights into the ECB's stance on interest rate decisions.
description: Speech by Ms Christine Lagarde, President of the European Central Bank, at the International Women's Day event organised by World Trade Organization (WTO), Geneva, 8 March 2023.

author: Christine Lagarde
title: Macroprudential policy in Europe - building resilience in a challenging environment
Key quote: At the same time, monetary policy is adjusting to ensure that high inflation does not become entrenched, and that inflation returns to 2% over the medium term.
Rationale: The speech focuses on maintaining financial system resilience and adaptability in facing challenges, without signaling any immediate changes in monetary policy, suggesting a neutral stance.
description: Welcome remarks by Ms Christine Lagarde President of the European Central Bank and Chair of the European Systemic Risk Board (ESRB), at the Sixth ESRB annual conference "Addressing financial stability challenges", Frankfurt am Main, 8 December 2022.

author: Christine Lagarde
title: Digital euro - a common European project
Key quote: The digital euro is more than just a Eurosystem initiative, it is a common European project.
Rationale: The speech is primarily focused on the digital euro project and does not address current monetary policy, inflation, or interest rates directly. As such, it is not related to immediate monetary policy discussions.
description: Video address by Ms Christine Lagarde, President of the European Central Bank, to the High level conference "Towards a legislative framework enabling a digital euro for citizens and businesses", Brussels, 7 November 2022.

author: Christine Lagarde
title: Leadership in times of crisis
Key quote: We are fully committed to ensuring that inflation stabilises at 2% over the medium term - which is what our mandate requires.
Rationale: The speech primarily addressed leadership in times of crisis and did not focus extensively on monetary policy. It acknowledged the current challenges of high inflation, suggesting a commitment to the ECB's inflation target, which aligns with maintaining current policy rather than signaling a shift towards tightening or easing.
description: Speech by Ms Christine Lagarde, President of the European Central Bank, at Manager Magazin's Top100 women in German Business, Hamburg, 27 April 2022.

author: Christine Lagarde
title: A new global map - European resilience in a changing world
Key quote: The Russia-Ukraine war has not only cast a shadow over Europe, it has also raised several questions about where the global economy is heading in the 21st century.
Rationale: Christine Lagarde addresses significant economic challenges and vulnerabilities due to geopolitical tensions, emphasizing the need for strategic autonomy and diversification. This suggests a cautious approach to monetary policy given the uncertainties, hence a 'Somewhat hawkish' stance leaning towards holding rates steady.
description: Speech by Ms Christine Lagarde, President of the European Central Bank, at the Peterson Institute for International Economics, Washington DC, 22 April 2022.

author: Christine Lagarde
title: Welcome address marking the change in office of the President of the Deutsche Bundesbank
Key quote: But people can trust that our commitment to price stability is unwavering, which is critical for the firm anchoring of inflation expectations and for confidence in the currency.
Rationale: The speech largely focused on the transition and history of the Bundesbank and ECB, but emphasized the importance of price stability and the ECB's commitment to it. This indicates a neutral stance on monetary policy, suggesting a likelihood to hold the interest rates steady given the circumstances.
description: Welcome address by Ms Christine Lagarde, President of the European Central Bank, at a virtual ceremony marking the change of office of the President of the Bundesbank,11 January 2022.

author: Christine Lagarde
title: Dynamic regions at the heart of a strong Europe
Key quote: We should not overreact to supply shortages or rising energy prices, as our monetary policy cannot directly affect those phenomena.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the transitory nature of current economic disruptions and the importance of carefully managing economic reopening. Lagarde also stresses the need to anchor inflation expectations without making aggressive policy changes, suggesting a neutral stance toward interest rate changes for now.
description: Speech by Ms Christine Lagarde, President of the European Central Bank (ECB), at Wirtschaftsinitiative FrankfurtRheinMain e.V., Frankfurt am Main, 5 October 2021.

author: Christine Lagarde
title: Climate change and central banks - analysing, advising and acting
Key quote: The strategy review has provided us with a framework to evaluate how our policy implementation could evolve to further incorporate climate considerations without prejudice to our primary mandate.
Rationale: The speech is focused on climate change and its implications for financial systems and central bank operations, rather than directly discussing current monetary policy or interest rate decisions. As such, it's not related to the core aspects typically considered in characterizing monetary policy stances as hawkish or dovish.
description: Speech by Ms Christine Lagarde, President of the European Central Bank, at the International Climate Change Conference, Venice, 11 July 2021.

author: Christine Lagarde
title: Financing a green and digital recovery
Key quote: But as the pandemic passes, we need to shift the focus from preserving the economy to transforming it.
Rationale: The speech focuses on financing green and digital recovery, and the development of a Green Capital Markets Union. It is not specifically about monetary policy, interest rates, or current economic conditions.
description: Speech by Ms Christine Lagarde, President of the European Central Bank, at the Brussels Economic Forum 2021, Frankfurt am Main, 29 June 2021.

author: Christine Lagarde
title: Towards a green capital markets union for Europe
Key quote: The green transition offers us a unique opportunity to build a truly European capital market.
Rationale: The speech focuses on green finance and the creation of a capital markets union, with little reference to immediate monetary policy actions or interest rates. Therefore, it is categorized as not directly related to monetary policy, suggesting that Lagarde would likely advocate for holding rates given the broader contextual focus.
description: Speech by Ms Christine Lagarde, President of the European Central Bank, at the European Commission's high-level conference on the proposal for a Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive, Frankfurt am Main, 6 May 2021.

author: Christine Lagarde
title: 20th anniversary of the entry into circulation of euro banknotes and coins
Key quote: The introduction of euro banknotes and coins in 2002 was a milestone in European history.
Rationale: The speech focuses on the historical and symbolic importance of the euro and the introduction of new banknotes, with no discussion on monetary policy or interest rates. As such, it is not directly related to central bank policy decisions on interest rates.
description: Speech by Ms Christine Lagarde, President of the European Central Bank, at the plenary session of the European Parliament, Strasbourg, 14 February 2021.

author: Christine Lagarde
title: Climate change and central banking
Key quote: Climate change is one of the greatest challenges faced by mankind this century, and there is now broad agreement that we should act.
Rationale: The speech mainly addresses the role of central banks in terms of climate change, which is not directly related to immediate monetary policy decision-making like setting interest rates. Therefore, it cannot be categorized along the hawkish-dovish spectrum typically used to anticipate interest rate changes.
description: Keynote speech by Ms Christine Lagarde, President of the European Central Bank, at the ILF conference on Green Banking and Green Central Banking, Frankfurt am Main, 25 January 2021.

author: Christine Lagarde
title: Fostering sustainable growth in Europe
Key quote: To meet these goals, decisive policy actions are needed. Those policies lie beyond the remit of monetary policy, but will certainly affect the environment in which central banks operate.
Rationale: The speech centers on fostering sustainable growth through innovation and education, acknowledging structural changes accelerated by the pandemic. While it highlights the need for decisive policy actions, it does not call for any immediate changes in monetary policy, suggesting a neutral stance on current rates.
description: Keynote speech by Ms Christine Lagarde, President of the European Central Bank, at the European Banking Congress, Frankfurt am Main, 20 November 2020.

author: Christine Lagarde
title: Payments in a digital world
Key quote: The Eurosystem has so far not made a decision on whether to introduce a digital euro.
Rationale: The speech focused on digital payments and the potential for a digital euro, rather than current monetary policy or interest rates.
description: Speech by Ms Christine Lagarde, President of the European Central Bank, at the Deutsche Bundesbank online conference on banking and payments in the digital world, Frankfurt am Main, 10 September 2020.

author: Christine Lagarde
title: Climate change and the financial sector
Key quote: The ongoing review of our monetary policy strategy creates an opportunity to reflect on how to address sustainability considerations within our monetary policy framework.
Rationale: The speech focuses on climate change and its impact on the financial sector rather than discussing traditional monetary policy aspects such as interest rates or inflation targeting.
description: Speech by Ms Christine Lagarde, President of the European Central Bank, at the launch of the COP 26 Private Finance Agenda, London, 27 February 2020.

author: Christine Lagarde
title: Frankfurt and Europe in a new decade
Key quote: You might be disappointed - or perhaps relieved - to learn that I won't be talking about monetary policy this evening.
Rationale: The speech explicitly states that it will not discuss monetary policy, making it irrelevant for assessing hawkish or dovish positions. Thus, it doesn't offer insight into changes in interest rate policy.
description: Speech by Ms Christine Lagarde, President of the European Central Bank, at the New Year's Reception of the City of Frankfurt, Frankfurt am Main, 16 January 2020.

author: Christine Lagarde
title: Welcome address
Key quote: These banknotes are part of our economy, our identity and our culture - and we at the ECB have an immense responsibility to ensure that people maintain their trust in them.
Rationale: The speech focuses primarily on the symbolic and cultural significance of euro banknotes, rather than discussing monetary policy or economic indicators that would suggest a particular stance on interest rates.
description: Welcome address by Ms Christine Lagarde, President of the European Central Bank, on signing the euro banknotes, Frankfurt am Main, 27 November 2019.

author: Christine Lagarde
title: Laudatory speech for Dr Wolfgang Schäuble
Key quote: This event is not about the ECB. It's not about monetary policy or other economic policies.
Rationale: The speech is a laudatory address for Dr. Wolfgang Schäuble and explicitly states that it is not related to monetary policy or any economic policies. Therefore, it is categorized as not related to monetary policy.
description: Laudatory speech by Ms Christine Lagarde, President of the European Central Bank, for Dr Wolfgang Schäuble, at the VdZ Publishers' Night, Berlin, 4 November 2019.

author: Philip R Lane
title: The 25th anniversary of the Euro50 Group: looking ahead to the 50th anniversary
Key quote: The challenge for central bankers will be to calculate and re-calculate the appropriate monetary policy stance that is robust to the emergence of these various scenarios.
Rationale: The speech focuses on the structural changes affecting monetary policy and emphasizes the need for adaptation and analysis without suggesting immediate policy shifts, reflecting a balanced approach likely resulting in a hold decision at the next meeting.
description: Remarks by Philip R. Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the ECB, at the 25th Anniversary of the Euro50 Group event at the Banque de France

author: Philip R Lane
title: Opening remarks at the ECB-IMF-IMFER conference
Key quote: From my perspective, it is essential that the ECB both supports these research developments and incorporates the emerging insights into the policy process.
Rationale: The speech is focused on research developments and their applications to monetary policy, but does not provide hints of an immediate policy stance change. This suggests a balanced view or 'Neutral' stance on monetary policy, hence the prediction to 'Hold' rates.
description: Welcome address by Mr Philip R Lane, Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, at the Joint European Central Bank, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the IMF Economic Review Conference 2024, Frankfurt am Main, 23 July 2024.

author: Philip R Lane
title: Statistical implications of the Eureopean Central Bank's monetary policy strategy review
